QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to his statements at the Victorian conference of the Australian Labor Party last weekend in support of the resolution sponsored by Mr Halfpenny critical of the Government's record on living standards. Is it a fact that in the course of his remarks the Minister said the Government was guilty of double standards in asking ordinary workers to accept a fall in living standards while at the same time finding well paid jobs for ex-politicians? I ask whether he went on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: Those symptoms reflect the fact that the body language of the Government, the stance of the Government, particular decisions that were made, said to the electorate that as far as the Government is concerned we were going to have one set of standards . . . while for that electorate to whom we preached restraint there was another set of standards.
To which particular set of Government decisions was the Minister referring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bradfield for his question. I am very interested to see that he is taking such a keen interest in the internal debates of the Victorian conference of the Australian Labor Party. In the particular resolution to which the honourable member refers, there was no reference to the previous record of the Government. Essentially, that resolution was directed towards the development of economic policy and principal elements of policy in the coming term of government. Indeed, it was an assumption by a number of speakers in that debate that the record of this Government had been admirable. Let me simply refer to some of the essentials of that. In the kind of conditions which have operated in recent years the fundamental of economic policy has been clearly the question of managing to ensure that there is growth in employment, reduction in unemployment and a fair distribution of the burden during very difficult economic times. Indeed, in terms of that debate, that was taken for granted.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the agenda that faces the Government during the current term, which on our side of politics is open to debate throughout the Party, the concern was that there be a fair wages policy; a fair taxation policy and that, in terms of the social wage or social expenditure, those on lower incomes ought to be given appropriate assistance. As I said then and in other debates in the House, I repeat that the record, and indeed the stance of this Government, is no better reflected in any other area than in the area of social security. We have done a great deal to ensure that the expenditure that is outlaid is directed towards those who need assistance. On the other hand, we have been able to bring about a number of very significant reforms. Indeed, John Halfpenny referred to the very significant reform of family assistance as being a model for what he would expect to see the Government achieve in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to this Government's concern for the status of women, both in the home and in the workplace. Can the Minister inform the House about the impact of the Government's economic policies on the employment prospects of women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lilley raises a very important point concerning the circumstances of women in the work force. It is perhaps by now reasonably well known that this Government, during its period of office, has created over one million jobs throughout Australia. What is perhaps less well understood is the advantage that that has bestowed, particularly on women.

ANSWER.PARA: There has also been an enormous difference in the prospects for women in the work force during this period as opposed to the period of our predecessors. During our period of government there has been a 5 per cent annual growth in female employment, whereas during the period of the Fraser Government the figure was a mere 1.6 per cent. In other words, we have created jobs for women at three times the rate of that achieved under the period of our predecessors.

It is, of course, well known that this Government has had to contend with some very great economic problems during its period of government. It has been the experience that under those circumstances women often suffer in relation to their position in the work force. So it is a very considerable achievement that during these difficult times, women have actually fared better than they have at any time in our past.

In the excess of one million jobs that we have created, 57 per cent have gone to women. This has meant that the unemployment rate for women has declined from 10.2 per cent when we came to office to 8.1 per cent now. As a result of this change, there has been an important improvement in the participation rate of women. Indeed, this rate has increased by five percentage points during our time in office and has now reached 50 per cent for the work force as a whole. There have also been substantial improvements in the area of teenage employment. The female unemployment rate for teenagers has fallen by 20 per cent during our time in office.

I suppose the most graphic way of putting this great achievement of the Government is to say that one in five women who are now in the work force have achieved that position during the period of this Government. That is, this Government has been responsible during its period of office for putting in the work force one in every five women who are currently employed. This is a performance which we intend to continue. Our policies in relation to education and training are designed to ensure that in the future, as now, women will have at least an equal opportunity to join the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to the situation of families with four children where family income is, for example, about average weekly earnings-that is, about $450 a week. In this case, if income increases by $100, the family actually loses $110. I ask the Minister: Was that one of the things to which he was referring when he is reported to have said, regarding living standards, outside Parliament House this morning, `I am sure those things that have caused us concern in the past won't be repeated.'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is no. Going to the question of family living standards, which is the thrust of what the honourable member is feigning some concern about, let me say that, in the conditions under which this Government has operated, the Government has nothing to apologise for with respect to family living standards. Above all else, its record in terms of protecting the living standards of low income families stands over and against the record of any previous government.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the living standards of low income families, the Government not only is in the process of meeting its commitments but also has already exceeded the estimates of assistance under the family package. Whilst initially we talked about assisting something like 510,000 low income Australian families through that package, I can say now that over 535,000 families have been assisted. More than one million children are beneficiaries under that particular program.

That is an illustration of the way in which the social wage-that is, assistance provided by way of government through family allowances-reinforces the other forms of assistance that are made available. At a time in which there has been a reduction in real unit costs and a real reduction in wages, the Government has given considerable attention to the social wage and the provision of a range of forms of assistance which go to middle income families such as those referred to by the honourable member. I will not go through those various programs, but they do amount to very significant assistance.

If there is some suggestion in the honourable member's question that, in terms of the targeting of assistance to very low income families, there are high withdrawal rates, let me say simply that that is a product of targeting. If what we are concerned to do in times of restraint is to provide significant assistance to people who are in poverty or are very close to it, inevitably there will be higher withdrawal rates in relation to those payments. But this Government has nothing to apologise for in terms of family assistance. Indeed, the Government is more than matching the commitments that it has made so far. In terms of its agenda for this term in government, no doubt it will continue to build on the very strong record that it established in the previous term.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the statement issued by the Business Council of Australia (BCA) yesterday detailing proposals to cut $2,500m of government spending. Can the Treasurer inform the House as to whether the Government's commitment to provide personal tax cuts in this parliamentary term is conditional in any way on achieving spending cuts of that size?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already addressed in earlier remarks the proposition from the Business Council that $2.5 billion should be cut out of Commonwealth outlays in the coming budgetary year, 1988-89. I made that point in the context that, even though the Government accepts that fiscal restraint will need to be the order of the day for this coming year and for some years into the future, cuts of this order are not now appropriate, given the great burden of the fall in the public sector borrowing requirement which has been carried on the Commonwealth's behalf. That being said, both the Prime Minister and I have said that over the course of this Parliament we will be looking at providing personal income tax cuts which will not be relying upon these draconian cuts to public outlays, particularly in the most sensitive sectors of the Commonwealth's transfer payments, et cetera.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps a more interesting development than the recital by the Business Council of Australia of $2.5 billion of reductions is the fervour with which the shadow Treasurer has greeted these announcements. In a Press statement he released yesterday he said:
While the Business Council's call to reduce government expenditure is welcome, it does not go far enough.
The BCA's report supports the thrust of Opposition policy.
Or the converse; Opposition policy supports the thrust of the BCA. He said:
However, the BCA's target of $2.5 billion in expenditure cuts is somewhat short of the mark.
As the recent string of electoral disasters . . . has shown, ordinary Australians are hurting. The decline in living standards must be turned around.

Let me turn to some of the specific proposals which do not go far enough, in the mind of the shadow Treasurer, in terms of some areas, particularly the aged and social security. For instance, they include means testing of the pharmaceutical safety net, with exemptions for exceptional medical cases; raising the safety net to 30 prescriptions per individual and 50 per family; tapering the safety net arrangements if concessional prescription rates before were free; levying a small charge on pensioner prescriptions of, say, 50c up to a limit of $50 per annum, saving $35m, the aim being not to reduce pensioners real incomes but to discourage overprescription; raising the maximum payable by the general public to $15 per prescription item-total $100m. Does the shadow Treasurer endorse that proposal? Obviously he does, yet he says that it does not go far enough.

The proposals also include speeding up the phasing in of new nursing home arrangements and tightening means and assets testing for community service programs and nursing homes and hostel contributions by asset testing nursing home benefits and varying subsidy according to income-$100m. Obviously that is endorsed and does not go far enough. The proposals recommend, under age pensions on page 26, imputing a yield to assets based on current market value, as was done before 1976, and applying income tests to the higher of the actual or imputed returns; as originally recommended by Professor Gruen, restructuring the assets test for those owning their own house to include the value of the owner-occupied home. The shadow Treasurer is endorsing this. In the policy speech in 1984 he said that `Labor's assets test is un-Australian and I won't have a bar of it'. Today he is saying that these proposals do not go far enough. He now wants to include the value of the owner-occupied home. According to the proposals, savings will depend on the exemption limit chosen, but $100m is possible even with a generous limit. They further include over five years raising the female pensionable age for new pensioners to 65 and to 60 for female service pensions, to make the eligible age the same as for males-$50m savings in the long run. Obviously that is too meek and mild a proposal. It is not tough enough. It is not hard enough. He wants more.

We come to the family allowance. The proposal is to abolish the family allowance and increase the income-tested family allowance supplement to $32 per week for children under 13 and $38 per week for children over 13, and to ease the income test-net savings of $100m. `It is too easy', he says. We ought to do more. Alternatively, it is proposed to lower the income test for the joint family allowance to $40,000. That is to lower the income test for joint family income to $40,000, saving $100m, but the shadow Treasurer wants to do better that that. It is very interesting that this reaction should come from the shadow Treasurer at this time because we never have any specificity from the Opposition about expenditure cuts. That term might be over the heads of some of the plebeians on the other side but most of us understand what the term means. There is no specificity from the Opposition on these issues. Those opposite want to run around the country talking about what they would cut. They have talked about how there is waste and extravagance. There is so much waste and extravagance that the Business Council can come up with specified cuts to only $2.5 billion, with this kind of specification. So this debate about how the whole system is awash with money and how the money is wasted and not going to the right places is fine, but when we try to cut some money out of it we come back to this specific program review on expenditures. Those opposite understand that but they are saying that the Government is not cutting enough out of outlays without saying where the cuts should be. Now that the Business Council has said this, those opposite have endorsed it and said it does not go far enough.

Where else do those opposite want to go? Let us invite the shadow Treasurer to tell us what other spending cuts he endorses over and above these expenditure cuts. Does he believe that we ought to be cutting these outlays in this way for such people as the elderly people in nursing homes and families by taking away the family allowance while, at the same time, he is crying crocodile tears about ordinary Australians hurting, saying the decline in living standards must be turned around? Apparently, that is a decline in living standards other than for the elderly in nursing homes, for women of pensionable age or for families with children. Apparently those opposite do not care about these people's living standards going down as they promote these cuts. But those opposite are crying crocodile tears about living standards when they expect and look for respectability in business forums by saying, `We have to have a tighter approach to public outlays. We have to cut living standards'. Those opposite are running around saying politically that the decline in living standards will be turned around except for all these people-the weakest people in the community-who will be bashed by proposals from the Business Council and from those opposite.

The shadow Treasurer talks about these things while the Opposition urges the abolition of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and all the other Labor fairness tax measures. Those opposite say that things should be taken away so we will be back to the rorts for their mates, for the crowd they represent-by having no capital gains taxation-and for tax cuts to be funded by cuts to the incomes of the poorest people in our society. That is where those opposite stand. For those opposite to say that they will endorse the cuts suggested by the Business Council but they want more, and to be hiding their light under a bushel about the specificity of the cuts while they try to score off the Government about living standards, says a lot about their credibility-they do not have any. That is why the Business Council regards those opposite as a joke-a collective joke-and why the rest of Australian business also so regards them, because business knows that those opposite did not have the courage in government in the past to do these things and would have no courage to do them in government in the future.

I say to the shadow Treasurer: let us have a list of the program cuts. I expect and challenge him to now publish a list which supports the thrust that the cuts are somewhere short of the mark. Let us have an honest debate about expenditure cuts and proper support by the Commonwealth for the aged, the weak and the infirm. Let us have a decent debate. If the shadow Treasurer says, `We want tax cuts paid by program cuts', he should tell us where the cuts should be. He has not bobbed up since Christmas. Last year, when he had the slow start, everyone said, `Well, he is not overreaching himself. That is good'. But he is still not. A year down the track he is still not overreaching himself. He bobs up today to endorse the Business Council and he has endorsed all these 30-odd pages of cuts to public outlays in the most sensitive areas of the Commonwealth's responsibility, to provide tax cuts-no doubt skewered to the top end of the tax system, as those opposite always seek to do.

I conclude on this point: Let the shadow Treasurer put together a list of the program cuts he thinks a coalition government would implement to cut outlays by $2.5 billion. Let him tell us then how he would cut taxes paid for by those reduced outlays. Then, and only then, can we have an honest debate in this country about fiscal policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security to tell the House why he believes the Prime Minister should drop privatisation from the Government's agenda.
—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: the question is clearly out of order. It does not come within the Minister's responsibilities.
—The Minister can choose to answer it. I agree with the honourable member for Calwell that the question does not actually come within the portfolio of the Minister for Social Security.

—Unlike the Opposition, let me say, our side of politics is prepared to debate serious issues. Indeed, when the debate is resolved at the Australian Labor Party Federal Conference this year it will be crystal clear what the Party's and the Government's position will be. It is interesting in that context to note that the Treasurer has just directed to the shadow Treasurer a very legitimate question. It is simply this: `If you think the Business Council of Australia has not gone far enough in terms of what it wants to do in relation to Government expenditures, let us be very specific; let us hear what you have to say are the areas that you believe ought to be carved into'. It is an issue that will be resolved at the Federal conference this year. I do not think that my personal view is of any relevance to the House.

—I ask the Minister for Trade Negotiations whether his attention has been drawn to the editorial in last Thursday's Australian Financial Review which deals with the need to increase our exports of processed minerals. Can the Minister tell the House what the Government is doing to attack protectionism in minerals and metals markets as part of the current round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question. I have seen the editorial referred to. I must say that the editorial does not appear to be based on a thorough reading of the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) paper to which it refers. If the editorial writers had read that paper carefully they would have seen on pages 42 and 43 that the Government launched a major attack on the problem of protectionism in these markets several months ago. Indeed, we have made the most significant and far-reaching proposal on resource products yet to be tabled in the GATT talks in Geneva. Unlike the Australian Financial Review, EPAC has noted this initiative. The details of those actions within the GATT context are in the EPAC report. The proposal put forward by Australia calls for radical reductions in protection for these minerals and metals based on, firstly, the elimination of tariffs and non-tariff measures protecting these markets. Secondly, it calls for an immediate freeze and roll back to zero of export subsidies. Thirdly, it seeks the elimination of all subsidies which disrupt trade in those products. Our far-reaching proposal recognises that although tariffs in many of these markets are relatively low they nevertheless have a significant potential to discourage processing in mineral exporting countries such as Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In other markets such as steel there are much more significant non-tariff barriers which impact on Australia, including quotas, subsidies and voluntary export restraints. Furthermore, in coal markets, highly competitive producers such as Australia find themselves faced with massive subsidies to domestic producers in some key markets. In some of these markets government approved subsidies for domestic coalmining are estimated to be as much as 1 1/3 times our annual coal export earnings. As far as advice from the Australian Financial Review that we should seek allies among other resource exporting countries is concerned, this is another area where the Government is some way ahead of it. We have been actively seeking such concerted approaches, although I must note that the problems in these areas are not as well known as those in the agricultural markets.

We have taken up bilaterally with the governments concerned the need to eliminate trade distorting production subsidies in particular and Ministers and officials of this Government have continually stressed to their counterparts in Germany and Japan the need to reduce coal subsidies. I consider that the key task at this stage is to draw attention to the adverse consequences of these policies for both producers and consumers, so that agreement can be reached for a global attack on the problem. In this regard, the contributions of EPAC and of the mining and processing industries, which have supported those steps and endorsed the Government's action, have been very welcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister agree with the comments of his Cabinet Minister Senator Richardson who says that he is not keen on the Government's arrival tax and that, for a very small amount of money, Australia had got itself an awful lot of derision around the world? Additionally, is he aware of the comments of the former Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta, about this tax, which he described as silly and creating ill will for no good reason? In light of these comments and the unanimous voice of the tourist industry, coupled with the fact that hundreds of thousands of people have refused to pay it, will the Prime Minister now admit that this tax is ill-conceived, harmful, and the worst possible way to promote Australia? Will he scrap it now, before any more damage is done to our tourist industry?

—The cries from the Opposition about what is happening in the tourist industry of course, like anything that it says in any area of policy, deserve only to be treated with derision in this country. If we look at its performance in the area of tourism and compare it with what has been achieved under this Government, it will be laughed out of court. Having said that, it would be foolish not to acknowledge that the impost to which the honourable member refers has caused problems. Of course it has, and that is why there have been discussions with the industry by the relevant Minister. Those discussions have not yet produced an acceptable alternative way of dealing with this matter. The discussions will go on and if there is a better way of achieving the objective, of course the Government will seek to do that. We are not going to simply lightly dispose of a charge, which is there for good reason, but if there is a better way of achieving the objective, of course we will do it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: REGIONAL OFFICES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of a call by Senator Amanda Vanstone for him to explain why some regional offices of his Department are closed to the public on half a day a week? Will the Minister explain why this is so and explain the broader significance of Senator Vanstone's call?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a Press release that was put out by Senator Vanstone, I think about a week ago. Since the 1986 Budget there have been close to 200 significant policy or procedural changes in the delivery of income security programs by the Department of Social Security. Further, the Department has taken on some additional functions, such as the payment of education allowances provided for by the Victorian Government as part of its social justice strategy. The Department is about to take on a broad range of new functions under the child support scheme. From their experience in answering queries in their electorate offices, all honourable members will be aware of the large amount of information needed to advise members of the public adequately about their social security entitlements.

ANSWER.PARA: Some regional offices of my Department are closed on Wednesday afternoons for staff training and consultation purposes. Staff in these offices are the ones who have direct front line contact with the social security clients. As honourable members will be aware, my Department is committed to ensuring that these staff, who deal with and implement the large number of changes that have occurred throughout the system, have a thorough understanding of new policies and procedures and have the necessary time to keep on top of the large amount of paper work and data processing that is required. Closures of regional offices occur only after consultation with the community. Provision is made for dealing with emergencies which may occur when an office is closed. This leads to an improvement in the standard of service to clients in the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is when you can get it.

—As far as social security is concerned, I think that under this Government's administration we have, as Fred Gruen pointed out, squared the circle-unlike the period in which honourable members opposite were in office, when there was a dramatic increase in social security expenditure. That was not because there was any real improvement in the level of benefits; indeed, real declines were occurring in the level of most benefits over time. Expenditure blew out essentially because they could not manage the economy, and ultimately successive Ministers were unable to manage the social security system. It is rather extraordinary that honourable members opposite continually talk about the need to produce cuts. The Leader of the Opposition was, I think, at one time talking about cuts of about $11 billion-no doubt $2 billion or $3 billion out of social security from cuts of that order. He was able to talk about that, whereas under his administration as Treasurer and under the administration of successive Ministers for Social Security from the benches opposite there was a great deal of talk about the need to cut expenditure. The reality is that there was a massive blow-out in social security expenditure at a time in which the real level of benefits which were being paid to individuals was declining. That is what the Opposition is all about-a kind of dual rhetoric. There is a rhetoric for when Opposition members are talking to the welfare community, as the honourable member for Bradfield does from time to time, when they say, `Isn't it sad that benefits are not increasing rapidly enough?', or, `Isn't it sad that the Government is not doing more?'; but when they talk to the Business Council they talk about the need for massive cuts, which ultimately must come off the social security budget.

ANSWER.PARA: As to this Government's record in terms of policy and administration, we have sought to review policy sensibly and rationally, and as a result of that review we have delivered very significant increases in the level of benefits to people; but in terms of administration, we have pursued a policy of very rigorous administration which has enabled us to fund, in part, the very significant increases we have delivered.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What were the circumstances in which the Minister obtained access to the confidential personal files of former Ambassador Cumes?
—By requesting them in my ministerial capacity.
—Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to a story on the front page of today's Australian Financial Review headed `AFP's Monaco move cuts tax by $150 million'? Is there any validity in that story?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the story in today's Australian Financial Review. I might say that it is for the Commissioner of Taxation, not the Treasurer, to determine the tax implications involved in reported transactions when all the facts have been made available by the relevant parties. Because of the secrecy provisions of the taxation laws, I am prevented from discussing the affairs of AFP Investment Corporation Ltd, or any other company with the Commissioner of Taxation. Further, I do not think it appropriate for me as Treasurer to comment on the taxation arrangements of any particular company.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I can make three points about the likely tax effectiveness of the general scheme described by the facts in the Australian Financial Review story. First, on the facts available, it is extremely unlikely that roll-over relief from capital gains tax would be available under the present law. In any case, relief would be available only if the assets remained taxable Australian assets for capital gains tax purposes-that is, I cannot see how the scheme, as described in the article, could defeat the present law. Secondly, if for some reason the scheme did turn out to be effective against the capital gains tax, there is the question of whether it would fall foul of part IVa, the general anti-avoidance provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Third, in the extremely unlikely event that the scheme were for some reason to get through both those hoops it would be open to the Government to introduce specific legislation to address it. I do not need to remind the House that in cases of blatant tax avoidance schemes the Government reserves the right to introduce remedial legislation. However, as I indicated, I do not foresee such action being required in cases of the kind so described.
