—I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy whether he is aware of claims that the current strong recovery in farm incomes will `impose considerable tax burdens on many farmers still battling heavy overdrafts and high interest payments'. Can the Minister advise the House of the truth of this suggestion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question and for the close interest he takes in the situation of the farmers and graziers in his electorate. I am aware of the claim by the Deputy Leader of the National Party in the terms quoted by the honourable member. It would seem that the Deputy Leader of the National Party has no knowledge of the Australian tax system as it affects farmers. In the first instance, the sentence quoted implies that interest payments are not fully tax deductible when, of course, they are. So, anyone who is battling high interest payments automatically receives tax relief. Of course, interest rates have been coming down.

ANSWER.PARA: More fundamentally, the Deputy Leader of the National Party seems to have totally forgotten the existence of tax averaging which allows primary producers-and very few others-to offset the tax effect of fluctuating incomes. I think we need to have a look at the effect of tax averaging. A taxpayer earning a taxable income equivalent to average farm cash flow would face an average tax rate this year of some 23.7 per cent if it were not for averaging. But with averaging, the same taxpayer faces an average tax rate of only 18.6 per cent. So averaging is worth some $1,260 in cash terms to such an individual this year. I ask honourable members to focus on that figure of 18.6 per cent because that is why all of the calls for a flat tax of 25 per cent would really knock the farm sector around.

The total value to the farm sector of averaging was around $100m in 1985-86. With this year's strong surge in farm incomes, that figure could easily double this year. Whatever justification there may or may not be for various proposals for re-introducing tax-related income equalisation deposits, it is clear that they could never be worth anywhere as near as much to the sector as income tax averaging currently is.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the honourable gentleman ensure, in accordance with universally accepted principles of ministerial propriety, that Ministers do not use their access to personal confidential files for the purpose of launching public and political attacks on current or former public servants or, indeed, on other persons identified in such files?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable gentleman that we have been in government for over five years. We will be there for a great--
—Too long.

—The honourable member's judgment is `too long', but the people have had the opportunity to make a judgment. The next time we go to them, they will make the same judgment. So honourable members opposite should just get used to the fact that they are going to be on that side of the House for a very long time. I am making the point that we have been in office now for over five years. There is no basis for any implication coming out of the mouth of the temporary Leader of the Opposition that this Government has other than a firm understanding of and commitment to the proper principles of government in this area. I repeat--

—As I say, Madam Speaker, the giggle or laugh machine gets going when honourable members opposite have no cerebral contribution to make. We are used to that. I repeat in regard to the instance that was raised in the question by the honourable member for North Sydney that there is no basis from that circumstance from which the Leader of the Opposition or those opposite can draw any general inference. My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade was confronted by circumstances in which not only were the interests of the gentleman concerned involved but also the interests and integrity of a much greater number of existing public servants. The gentleman in question sought to proceed in a way which impugned not merely the integrity of Ministers but also the integrity of a very large number of his own fellow public servants. In that situation, the Minister made a judgment which, in those circumstances, was valid.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat: we have been in office now for more than five years. It is simply indisputable that neither the Leader of the Opposition nor anyone else on that side of the House has any basis on that record of government for suggesting that we, in government, do not have a very clear understanding of and a commitment to the proper principles in this matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-Notice has been received from the honourable member for North Sydney of his intention, at the next sitting, to move:
That this House censures the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade for the following reasons-
(1) The Minister's gross abuse in the recent defence debate of the privilege of this House of absolute freedom of speech;

(2) that the Minister has demeaned his position as Minister and misused his powers by gaining access to a confidential personal file of a former officer of his Department for the purposes of a premeditated parliamentary attack on him;

(3) by these actions he has gravely compromised the system of confidential personal assessments which are crucial to the operations of his and other departments and has attacked the right of Australians to basic protections of privacy.
Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the member for North Sydney moving forthwith the motion of censure of which he has given notice for the next sitting.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move-

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade for the following reasons-
(1) The Minister's gross abuse in the recent defence debate of the privilege of this House to absolute freedom of speech;

(2) That the Minister has demeaned his position as Minister and misused his powers by gaining access to a confidential persons file of a former officer of his Department for the purposes of a premeditated parliamentary attack on him;

(3) By these actions he has gravely compromised the system of confidential personal assessments which are crucial to the operations of his and other departments and has attacked the right of Australians to basic protections of privacy.

This motion of censure of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) is brought on four grounds: firstly, by his conduct in the recent debate on defence, he debased the parliamentary forum and grossly abused the absolute freedom of speech we have as members of this House and treated with contempt the reciprocal duty each member has to exercise that freedom wisely and with restraint. Secondly, he has demeaned his position as Minister and misused his powers by plundering the confidential personal file of a former officer of his Department for the personal and private purpose of the public vilification of that individual by a premeditated and vicious parliamentary attack of him. Thirdly, by these actions he has gravely compromised his Department's system of confidential personal assessments which are crucial to the way that Department and other departments make decisions on staffing and promotion. Fourthly, there is a broad fundamental principle that has been attacked by the Minister's conduct-the right of Australians to basic protections of privacy.

I remind the House of the answers given today in Question Time. I asked the Minister about the circumstances under which he got access to the confidential personal file of former Ambassador Cumes. There was no quibble that it was confidential and no quibble that it was personal. He said, `By requesting them in my ministerial capacity'. So he got those files in his ministerial capacity. I then asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a question. I asked him whether it was government policy, when Ministers, in their ministerial capacity, have gained access to confidential personal files, for the contents of such files to be publicly disclosed. The Prime Minister answered it in the way we know well from him. He said that he had full confidence in the actions and decisions of the Minister, that there was no suggestion that this was an indication of some general policy-will he tell us what the policy is if this is not general policy?-and that the Minister had made a very clear statement of his reasons when he came before this House in the defence debate some time ago. We will go to those in a few minutes.

A third question was asked of the Prime Minister, by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). In answer to that question, which was one that sought some reassurances on the question of policy, the Prime Minister gave us his usual homilies on a number of subjects. One of the things he said was that this Government has a firm understanding of and commitment to proper policy in this area. He was saying that the integrity of these files could and should be compromised so the Minister could make the personal attack on Dr Cumes that he did make. What the Prime Minister said was that the Minister was safeguarding the interests of a whole lot of public servants. The Minister got access to the files in his ministerial capacity. He got access to personal confidential files and, so far as this Government is concerned, that is okay. It is okay to get access to those files and it is okay to use those files on the floor of the House. That is what I shall now come to.

Let me remind the House of the facts. The victim of this parliamentary attack was Dr J. W. C. Cumes, an officer in the Department of Foreign Affairs for 40 years. He entered as a cadet in 1944 and remained there until his retirement in 1985. The public record tells us that among the posts held during his professional service with the Department were first assistant secretary and three ambassadorships, the last as Ambassador to the Netherlands for the years 1980 to 1984.

This former officer has recently published a book on the operation of the Australian political system. In it he makes critical comments about a number of Ministers, including the present Foreign Minister. The Foreign Minister is given mixed reviews. He is praised by the author for showing sincerity and good sense, and the author says of him that he might underestimate his own intelligence. He is also described as vain and pretentious, a bully to those who work under him, and a brooding, devious man who suddenly pounces on his unsuspecting victim with unforgiving zeal. Extracts from the book were published in the Australian newspaper on Saturday, 12 March. It is hurtful to be described in such unflattering and dismissive terms, even though no less harsh criticism is something many members of this House have to endure. The author could not expect a free ride, but the Minister made no immediate response.

Twelve days later the Minister intervened and spoke in the debate on defence. I did not hear his speech; I read it later on the final day of that sitting period. This is the first day since that final day that the Minister has been in the House. His speech had nothing to do with defence issues or with foreign affairs issues that relate to defence policy. His speech was made for one private, personal purpose: to use the parliamentary forum, with the absolute immunity from legal action and the wide publicity it attracts, to vilify and damage the character of this former officer.

The response given by the Minister on the floor of this House was not the kind of dismissive, contemptuous gesture that is often employed in such a case. It was brooded over, premeditated, researched and detailed. His speech covered over four Hansard columns, which must be some kind of record in the politics of parliamentary abuse.

To so debase the privilege of this House by this unique exercise in parliamentary spite was bad enough. After all, the Minister is a person who has been prepared to come to this House and state his conviction in the need for restraint, for decency, for dignity. On a previous occasion, concerning Senator Primmer, he said:

The situation has arisen where we are witnessing, effectively, trial by Hansard, conviction by innuendo and I believe, an inexcusable smudging of the character of the people to whom I have referred. It may well have been that Senator Primmer felt justified in initiating action on these matters. Certain information was conveyed to him.
He went on to say:
I say that allowing for the fact that when we deal with people from outside this Parliament the standards are a little different in that they are not here to protect themselves . . .

As, incidentally, his victim was not. The Minister in his reply used for the source of his parliamentary attack something which was quite unforgivable. This was Dr Cumes's personal departmental file. That personal departmental file included assessments made on him at various times during his 40 years service with the Department. So far as I am aware, this is the first that any Minister, let alone a Minister with 27 years service in this House who has held three major ministries, the present one for five years, has used confidential departmental personal files. Remember that there was no quibble by him-they were confidential. They were personal to Ambassador Cumes. He obtained these personal and confidential departmental files by using his ministerial powers. Remember-he said it-that he sought these files as Minister and as the responsible Minister he was the only Minister who could have asked for those files. He has used these files, after compelling their production, for the public slaughter of a former long-serving officer of his own Department.

Let me now remind the House of the use made by the Minister of these confidential files and the reasons given by him for his actions. As to his reasons, he presented himself to the House as completely disinterested, a man unmoved and unmotivated by personal anger, who wished only to act in the public interest. He wanted, amongst other things, to defend the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. We know how deeply it is that the Minister wishes at all times to defend in this House Prime Minister Fraser's reputation! He also said of himself, `I also attract commentary of a rather severe nature. I offer no assessment, however, of the justice or otherwise of that'. Here we have a disinterested man, doing his best in trying circumstances. He said he wanted to answer Dr Cumes's criticisms, to set the record straight. The Minister said:
. . . I think for the sake of getting a balanced assessment-
note the judgmental term `balanced assessment'-
of this matter, in particular to make judgment of his adequacy and his own objectivity to do so, there are some things I should put on the record.

Again, we see that judgmental term-on the record. The use then made by the Foreign Minister of this former officer's personal files was extraordinary, even by the standards of a government which has never sought to impose any restrictions on Ministers and their supporters who resort to personal vilification and abuse. The Foreign Minister, in his speech, said of Dr Cumes:
I have taken the opportunity of looking at his file.

Indeed he had. It is evident that he went through Dr Cumes's personal file with an almost obsessional and neurotic zeal, in what he has told us was a balanced hunt for the truth-and who believes that?

In this plundering of the confidential file he quotes from reports at all levels; from a departmental head, a deputy secretary, former departmental assessments of his victim's capabilities and qualities, and comments from dissatisfied subordinates of this former officer. He also refers to an in-confidence report and, at the same time, manages to identify the person who gave that in-confidence report as a deputy secretary. The Minister's quest for unvarnished truth takes him back 31 years. It passes belief that a rational, sensible man would disinter comments made 31 years ago by a departmental assessor in this malicious hunt for statements derogatory to Dr Cumes. The Minister gives the exact date of his researches-11 January 1957-and the quote, amongst other things, says:
. . . he is not suited to representational work.

That is one opinion that the Department certainly has not observed because Dr Cumes has been sent on three occasions as ambassador overseas. Can honourable members imagine going back 31 years in this obsessional hunt for material damaging to this former officer? Extraordinarily, one might think, not a word in this former officer's favour is to be found. Here we have this balanced hunt for the truth and the Minister seeking only to set the record straight, and not a single word in Dr Cumes's favour is to be found. Having selected his quotes, the Minister went in for the kill. He put the case for the prosecution in the following words:
What the record-
note again the judgmental use of the word `record'; the Minister is simply a recording angel putting down the pluses and the minuses, although there are no pluses-

shows is simply this: Dr Cumes, for all of the pretensions he is engaged in, was indeed a personally vain and pretentious man, was a bully to the staff who worked under him at a series of missions, was incapable of good labour management of those individuals, was lazy and uninvolved and was very much a failure.

Remember Dr Cumes's criticism of the Minister: vain, a bully, brooding and devious. How would we describe a man who engaged in the squalid plundering of a confidential file, who intervenes in the defence debate under the devious and transparently false excuse of setting the record straight for the public good and who uses the immunity and the forum of Parliament for his public attack? What was the message for other officers or former officers of his Department? It was one of naked intimidation. Be warned: this could happen to you. Many would think that by his own actions, the Minister has demonstrated the validity of the criticisms made of him by this former officer. But that is not the issue. I am not here to impugn the personality of the Minister, but to censure his conduct. Nor am I here to defend his victim, whom I have never met.

Let me say something now about the nature of the files the Minister used. Personal assessments are a cardinal feature of the foreign service and, in varying degrees, of other departments of the Australian Public Service. They are the means by which professional judgments are made for the purpose of employment and promotion decisions within the department. These assessments of the merits, capabilities, strengths and weaknesses of officers may be written, oral or by way of formal assessment. For example, they may be the yearly formal assessments which the department conducts. The assessments go into a confidential personal file. The practice has been for these formal assessments when they are made yearly to go into a designated X-file system-personal files kept in a locked room under the charge of one clerk, although one wonders these days where the personal files are to be found. Are they all to be found in the Minister's office?

Of course, the special feature of overseas service in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade makes such a system doubly necessary. This system goes to the heart of the operation of the Department because on its operation depends the making of balanced, orderly, professional judgments on staffing and promotion questions. It depends for its operation on two conditions: first, it depends on the ability of those who make the assessments to speak frankly, confident that what they have said will be treated in confidence on a strictly demonstrated need to know basis, otherwise they simply will not speak or will fudge it; secondly, to preserve the system's worth and integrity, to avoid unfair damage to individual reputations and to preserve privacy, it is essential that confidentiality is in fact preserved. Can there be any dispute about these propositions? Can there be any dispute that the Minister's conduct has breached in the most contemptible way the whole basis on which these files are kept? So confidential and so sensitive are these kinds of records that their disclosure is explicitly prohibited. Under the Freedom of Information Act no member of this House would be able to get to Dr Cumes's personal file.

Under guidelines issued by the Public Service Board in 1985 an elaborate system of protection against disclosure of personal information, except within the Public Service on a demonstrated need to know basis, is laid down. Let me quote the opening words of the first principles which depend on the privacy principles enunciated by the Law Reform Commission and adopted by this Government. They state:

Departments and the Board have an important responsibility to protect the privacy of personal information about staff, former staff and applicants for employment. This responsibility includes obligations to safeguarding the confidentiality of personal records.

These guidelines have been directly subverted by this Minister. If Ministers are going to subvert these kinds of guidelines, if, under the guise of a disinterested exercise in parliamentary decency, they are going to use personal records, what officer of what department is safe? The answer is none. The Minister has violated not only the guidelines of his own Department but also the privacy principles which were adopted by that Department and which have been adopted by this Government. Do honourable members remember that we had before this House a privacy Bill? Remember who adopted those privacy principles? It is those privacy principles which have been violated by this Minister.

In this exercise we must ask ourselves the question: Was it intentional? The answer is: it most certainly was intentional. Was damage done? The answer is: damage was most certainly done. Were officers of his Department compromised? The answer is: officers of his Department were most certainly compromised because they had given these assessments and expressed opinions on the basis that these expressions of opinion would be kept where they should have been kept, confidential.

However, there is a wider question. We have received from this Government over the years assurances about confidentiality and privacy. Remember that it has been this Government, above all governments, which has sought to intrude into the affairs of Australians. I refer to the Australia Card and the Health Insurance Commission. Remember the refrain: this is a government that will protect the privacy of Australians. Well, we have had, of course, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) on this subject. We may now hear the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on this subject. We have heard the Prime Minister on this subject, speaking about the probity of his Government and its commitments to privacy. Where is it? Every Australian will know that, by the action this Minister has taken, by his support by the Prime Minister and by the support he will be given in a party line vote, this Government can never be trusted with confidential information about Australians, because when it comes to their political interest they will use it, and in this case the Minister cannot even dignify it with political interest. It was a naked exercise in political spite-nothing less, nothing more-and on those grounds this Minister deserves to be censured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, with pleasure, second this motion moved by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), because the issues raised by the Opposition in this censure motion are matters of the very greatest concern and of the very greatest seriousness to the Australian people. This motion raises fundamental issues concerning the privacy generally of all Australians and it also more particularly raises the issue of the integrity of the Australian Public Service. There will be many people in the Public Service today, and former public servants such as me, who will be deeply concerned about the implications of the particular decision that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) took some three weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue at the heart of this debate is not Dr Cumes himself, who was the subject of the Minister's vitriolic attack. We are not standing here to defend Dr Cumes's record. I worked with Dr Cumes for some two months. I know him well enough. Our job is not to defend his record; it is to raise the issue of fundamental principle which the Minister, supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has set in motion. Both the Minister and the Prime Minister have now set new standards on the issue of privacy. They have set new standards concerning the privacy of the individual and they have set new standards for the practice of the Public Service. We have now what could be described as the Hayden doctrine. If a retired public servant criticises the Government or Ministers, be they past Ministers or present Ministers, then the Public Service personal privacy provisions are automatically suspended. The Prime Minister admitted this in answering questions from the honourable member for North Sydney and from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he said that these issues of principle relating to privacy are related to particular circumstances. So in some circumstances privacy is all-important and in other circumstances, where the Minister may have got a bucketing from a former public servant, those principles become simply irrelevant.

I know most members of this House, be they on this side or the other side, would regard that doctrine as completely incomprehensible. But as the honourable member for North Sydney suggested, it reminds us of the famous quote from the honourable member for Bonython, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett):
We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right.

That is a quote that comes back again and again to haunt the Labor Party and is so relevant in these particular and appalling circumstances. This whole issue also challenges the basis of the assessment system in the Public Service on which the whole structure of promotions and appointments within that organisation is based. One cannot possible expect an objective assessment process within the Public Service to work if there is a fair chance that the assessments made by officers are subsequently going to be published. In this particular instance they have been published, all because of an attack on the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade which is simply typical of the many attacks that a politician has to live under. I suspect that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade was particularly stung by the memorable phrase from Dr Cumes that he, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, missed the prime ministership by a whisker and in that happening Australia can renew its rather battered claim to be a lucky country.

If that is an example of the approach of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the fundamental issue of the privacy of the individual, we can see how lucky we were that that did not eventuate but how unlucky we are that the Minister sits in a senior position in the Cabinet. What the Minister has done is to use the files of a former senior public servant, Dr Cumes, and in doing so he has gone beyond the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, beyond the Public Service guidelines on privacy and beyond the provisions of the Archives Act 1983. Let us consider, to begin with, the Freedom of Information Act. That Act, introduced by the Fraser Government, of course recognises the principle of privacy. When we look at section 41 we see this principle quite clearly. Section 41 provides:
A document is an exempt document-
that is, exempt from the provisions of the Act-
if its disclosure under this Act would involve the unreasonable disclosure of information relating to the personal affairs of any person (including a deceased person).

That is perfectly clear. The intention and the wording of the Act are perfectly clear, yet the Minister has transgressed that provision of the Act. He has gone further than any other person could possibly go through the use of the Freedom of Information Act. Let us consider the Public Service guidelines, set out in a personnel manual, that were drawn up by the Public Service Board in cooperation with the Attorney-General's Department. Those guidelines cover this extraordinarily important issue of the privacy of individuals within the Public Service-they are designed to protect that privacy. I draw the attention of the House to some of those guidelines. Guideline 3.7 provides:

Where access is requested to documents which discuss the work performance of particular staff members and the person making the request is not the subject of the record, then access should be refused.
That is perfectly clear, and the Minister has simply transgressed that important guideline. Section 5 of the guidelines, `Internal use and disclosure to third parties', provides:
It is the responsibility of departments to protect the privacy of their staff by safeguarding the confidentiality of personal records held.
That is something that did not happen in this case. Further:

Where staff members or other parties inside or outside the Service provide information for staff management purposes they can reasonably expect that such information will be used only for the purpose which governed the collection of the information (or a purpose incidental to or connected with that purpose).
Those guidelines are perfectly clear. They further provide:
Disclosure for other purposes without the staff member's consent-
and, of course, Dr Cumes did not consent to this childish exercise-
would be a denial of the staff member's reasonable expectation of privacy.

That is perfectly clear and that provision was grossly transgressed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The guidelines go on and on, detailing precisely under what circumstances the privacy of the individual can be affected. The guidelines further provide:
Accordingly, record holders should not release personal information on staff or transfer any record on a staff member to any person within the department or to an outside department or body . . .

That is, except in certain circumstances which relate, for example, to internal administrative purposes or routine uses consistent with the purpose for which the information was collected-that is not the case here-or for a disclosure authorised by the staff member in relation to, for example, information that is already in the public domain. In this case it is hardly information that falls into that category because `information in the public domain' is defined by the Public Service guidelines as being information such as that relating to the office held by the officer, the designation and the classification of that officer, and the officer's name and date of appointment to the Public Service.

The guidelines are perfectly clear in that respect and in many different sections they have tried to secure-and, in the past, have successfully secured-the privacy of the individual public servant. Those guidelines are not apparent to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. He has transgressed the guidelines; he has ignored them.

Finally, when one looks at the end of the guidelines, one sees some information privacy principles that are based on the 10 information privacy principles recommended in the 1983 Law Reform Commission report on privacy. I would have thought that that was pretty relevant and important information for the Minister to take into account. The section called `Disclosure of personal information' states:
A person should not disclose personal information about some other person to a third party unless-
(a) the record subject has consented to the disclosure-
we know that has not happened in this case-

(b) the person disclosing the information believes on reasonable grounds that the disclosure is necessary to prevent or lessen a serious or imminent threat to the life or health of the record subject-
we know that does not apply in this case-
(c) the disclosure is required (or specifically authorised) by law.

We know that does not apply in this particular circumstance. Yet again, wherever one looks in the official documentation one sees that the Minister has seriously transgressed the fundamental principles of privacy, both in the regulations of the Public Service and, implicitly, in legislation that has passed through the Parliament.

Let us look at the Archives Act 1983. As honourable members know, that Act describes the 30-year rule. That is, after 30 years, in general, official documents can be disclosed to the public. However, there is one exception to that. After 30 years, private personal information concerning public servants cannot be disclosed to the general public. Even under the Archives Act, what the Minister for Foreign Affairs has done is simply beyond the pale. That legislation makes perfectly clear that the personal records of individual public servants must be properly protected for a very, very long time, far exceeding the 30-year rule. In using the privileges of Parliament, the Minister has chosen to ignore that provision.

What is more, the Minister is responsible for the administration of his own Department, and this whole issue raises some very important questions relating to that administration. For example, I have already made the point that Dr Cumes did not give his consent for the Minister to use his personal records in that way. Indeed, I understand that the Minister did not have the courtesy of making Dr Cumes aware that he was to dive into his personal record and read out assessment reports and notes on file that go back as far as 31 years.

Secondly, why did not the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade protect the file from a voracious Minister who was simply going to use it to promote his own political purposes and to bolster his own flagging ego in the face of sustained fire? Why did not the Department protect that file against what is described in the Public Service regulations as accidental or improper release? This was not accidental release; this was improper release of the worst kind.

At the end of the day, what we have from this Government is a new doctrine on privacy-a new approach to the issue of privacy-and that is where we come back to the Prime Minister's support for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in Question Time. Apparently the principles of privacy, which are outlined in the Freedom of Information Act and the Archives Act and set out perfectly clearly in the Public Service guidelines on the protection of privacy, have been suspended in relevant circumstances. That is a reprehensible change to a fundamental doctrine of privacy. When this Government was introducing the identity card and this side of the House was expressing its concern about the privacy of the individual under the identity card, Government Ministers, from the Prime Minister down, continued to try to reassure the Parliament and the Australian community that the protection of the privacy of the individual would be absolute, regardless of the enormous amount of information collected through the ID card. Yet we know that privacy is not properly protected. We know that, as the Minister for Community Services and Health has said, the Labor Party regards privacy as `a bourgeois concept' which can apparently be suspended when the egos of Labor Ministers are somehow piqued by former public servants.

This is a fundamentally important issue. The issue of privacy is one of the most important that this country needs to address at any time. On this side of the House we are serious about privacy. We are serious about protecting the privacy of the individual. That is why we have brought this censure motion to the House. The Minister has behaved in a quite reprehensible and disgraceful way on this occasion and I regard his position as completely indefensible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid the last word has not been said on this subject, no matter what the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), having spoken on the issue, may conclude. It seems to me that the Opposition, having resorted to raising this matter, is desperate to talk about any subject, except John Stone, a consumption tax and Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland, because these are much more telling issues of concern within their own ranks which have created widespread division.

SPEECH.PARA: When I listened to the commentary of the honourable member for North Sydney-the attack he launched against me-I immediately thought of the comment made by Denis Healey, a member of the House of Commons, about a conservative politician who had launched an attack upon him. He said that being attacked by that particular politician was like being `savaged by a dead sheep'. I should have thought that a dead sheep was more ferocious than the honourable member for North Sydney! The honourable member for North Sydney wanders around the chamber like an aimless sleepwalker and burbles on like a guppy blowing bubbles at Question Time without being quite clear what it is he is seeking to pursue.

The honourable member for North Sydney has declared great concern for Dr Cumes and his reputation. Having declared great concern for Cumes and his reputation, he then set about repeating the criticisms I had made-a great help to Dr Cumes. Having repeated the criticisms, which I admit are rather severe but which come directly from the record and were made by objective assessors of Dr Cumes's performance over the years, the honourable member for North Sydney said that he was unable to refute the allegations made against Dr Cumes and, in fact, did not care to try to do so. The honourable member for Mayo went further. He confessed that he had worked with Dr Cumes on one occasion and, having worked with him, he certainly was not prepared to put up any defence of him. Not only could he not put up a defence, but also it would have been unwise for him to do so because after my address on 23 March he was regaling members indiscriminately, on this and on the other side of the chamber, with his views of Dr Cumes. As severe as my comments may have been-and they were merely a replication of what is on the record-they pale into rather moderate terms compared to what the honourable member for Mayo had to say about Dr Cumes, based on his own experience of him and his assessment of the man personally.

All the honourable member for North Sydney has achieved, wittingly or unwittingly, is a regeneration of perhaps some public attention and media commentary from this debate on the book that has been published-a book, the sales of which are badly flagging and which is on the verge of being remaindered. Knowing that the honourable member for North Sydney is a trusting innocent soul, an aimless sleepwalker, as I described him, in the parliamentary institution, someone has come along and said to the honourable member, `Hey, here's a good idea. Why don't you take it up and really get stuck into Hayden. You know how ferocious you can be'. I have it on good authority that the person who approached him then went off and said to certain people interested in seeing the book's sales pick up a bit, `I got him hook, line and sinker. He's going to chase it up'. The honourable member has managed to reinforce the criticisms of Dr Cumes's view. Perhaps there may be some slight flutter of a very marginal interest in the book.

What are the real reasons for the honourable member for North Sydney being so passionate on this extraordinarily unusual subject for an Opposition to want to move a censure motion on? After all, there are many issues affecting the country one way or another which one would have thought would have been to the fore of concern of a group of people who presume-the great pretenders-that they are an alternative government, certainly an alternative government, but a government whose time has not yet come and will not come for a long time. What was the real reason? The real reason was simply this: one of the main people I defended was Malcolm Fraser. On 23 March I said:

I cannot speak for Prime Minister Fraser but I will say this from my knowledge of him: he would not be as ill-informed, as inadequately briefed, nor as oafish as he is painted in that particular account.

I stand by that in spite of any differences I might have had with Malcolm Fraser over time. We were both in the House together. There were differences on issues and differences on priorities. Nonetheless, one develops respect for one's opposite number in this chamber. I developed a great deal of respect for Fraser's integrity on a number of issues. What were those issues? What is the issue in particular on which I defended Fraser that so irks the honourable member for North Sydney? It is the championing of the black people's rights in South Africa. It is Fraser's opposition to apartheid. It is the way in which Fraser made it clear that he was appalled at this disgraceful behaviour by the honourable member for North Sydney who could not bring himself to say that the six people who are to be hanged in South Africa should not be hanged, that there was clear evidence that evidence given before the court hearing had been fixed by the police.

Those honourable members who saw the debate between him and me on television on this matter were struck-and members of the Opposition, as much as members on the Government side, have mentioned this to me too-by his discomfiture whenever he was pressed to make a declaration on simple human principles that capital punishment was an unacceptable form of punishment, let alone declaring that, as there had been a confession by one of the key prosecution witnesses that he had given false evidence central to the conviction of at least some of these people, he should denounce the result of that court hearing and require that the executions not be proceeded with. He did not. He was not prepared to do it. Members of his own back bench had to get up in the Parliament, disgusted with his lack of common compassion and sense of responsibility for so failing to do this, and make it clear that they distanced themselves from his behaviour.

That is what it is all about. Fraser is not forgiven by people on the Opposition benches who are soft on apartheid, who are apologists for the white supremacist government of South Africa. The honourable member for North Sydney happens to be one of those who are soft on apartheid. That is why he is cranky. Let me make another point about the honourable member for North Sydney. If the honourable member for North Sydney and the honourable member for Mayo are concerned about disclosure of personal and confidential matters, why is it that not once did they acknowledge that the rather severe and very personal criticisms made of Fraser were based on absolutely confidential briefing sessions between professional advisers in the Public Service and Fraser as Prime Minister of Australia? For instance, on one occasion in Brussels, Cumes was there. Cumes gives his account of what took place. If one read it, one would presume that Malcolm Fraser must have been a real knuckle-head.

How would ever a man of such limited ability, incomprehension and laziness, who obviously did not even read the brief, ever become Prime Minister of Australia? That is the nub of it, and that is the nub of it all the way through. Cumes has resorted to disclosing matters of great confidentiality to make personal assessments about people on the basis of what he says, of his very coloured account. The honourable member for North Sydney has set himself up as a champion for Cumes. I am pleased that Cumes at last, in his long but faulty career in the diplomatic service, has found a champion. According to his personal file, he could not seem to find them over the years that he was in the diplomatic service. He certainly cannot find one in the honourable member for Mayo who, a fortnight ago, was running around the lobby in Parliament House telling people what he thought of Cumes. That is what he said today. He said, `I worked with him and I will not defend him'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they feel on your side of the House?
—Order!
—It is irrelevant to the principle.
—You breached the principle. Are you going to address the issue?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your defence against this personal onslaught from members of the Opposition, particularly the honourable member for Mayo. If people are going to go public like this, they will have to expect that questions will be asked. For instance, Mr Richard Woolcott, our distinguished Ambassador in the United Nations in New York, was asked a question on this matter at the National Press Club. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't want to comment on the principles involved, except to say that if you write this sort of book, attacking ministers and senior colleagues, I think you'll have to expect there'll be some reaction.
Pru Goward, on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program in Canberra, had this to say:
I'm afraid Dr Cumes has broken the Queensberry rules . . .

Of course he broke the rules. What did he do when he broke the rules? He set himself up, put himself forward, as some sort of authority on the qualities of other people. What he did was to tell people that his credibility was up for challenge. That is what he did. If one sets oneself up as an authority, and particularly on very personalised judgments about other people, one immediately puts one's qualifications for this claim out in the marketplace. One's credibility is up for challenge. That is one of the simple facts of life.

The circumstances of this case are quite unusual. Cumes used his position as a former public servant to make wholesale and highly public personal attacks on political personalities of both political persuasions and on former public service colleagues. He has drawn on his experience of private and confidential relationships for this purpose. It is highly questionable, to say the least, for a retired public servant to use his privileged position in this way. In these circumstances, it is not at all unreasonable for me to challenge the way in which he, in fact, violated privilege. What I have done is to call into challenge his claim to be accepted as an authority to make judgments on others, his capacity for objectivity and his reputation. All of these things are important. Let me read from the record some of the things that people on the other side do not want to defend. This is what the record says:
We do not consider that Dr Cumes has the personal and professional attributes that would warrant further consideration on his application in competition with other candidates.
It also says:
His working hours at the office are short and erratic as is his participation in the work of the Mission.

The honourable member for North Sydney would find nothing wrong with that, but there you are. I am reminded that it has taken just on a month for the honourable member for North Sydney to finally get himself cranked up and bring the issue into the House, to get his cognitive processes functioning. He is an aimless sleepwalker; he is also a slow thinker. I am reminded of a story that a judge from the Supreme Court of New South Wales told me: the honourable member for North Sydney when he was practising was frequently rather slow moving off his chair in his clients' interests. One day he was so slow that the particular judge said to him, `What is wrong, Mr Spender? Is the seat of your pants stuck on a blob of chewing gum on the chair?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a liar.

—Oh, John, that is very personal. He is a slow thinker and a slow mover. He did not defend, nor did the honourable member for Mayo. The honourable member for Mayo made it clear that he knew of Cumes and he would not defend him because he knew that what was said was right. On one occasion at a conference a delegate complained that Cumes had not read the brief but insisted on laying down the law to the delegation, sometimes in ways that conflicted with the agreed Australian position. This is another one:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . `in confidence' report that Cumes has more or less given up work except when absolutely necessary and that this mode of conduct will continue in The Hague. I therefore see very little profit in your writing in detail to him.

The list goes on and on. What has the Opposition done? It says that it is so worried about Cumes, his reputation and privacy, that it has given the matter a second run. Hardly anyone noticed it in the newspapers on the first occasion. Unlike the honourable member for North Sydney, I did not run around telling the newspapers that I intended to talk. He did today. As soon as he got up, the Press people all walked out; they knew what was going to happen. I did not tell them. The Opposition has had a re-run today. What did the honourable member for North Sydney do-that great defender of human rights who will not defend six black people who are about to be hanged on falsified evidence, who ducked and weaved when the questions were put to him, who pretends to be a great human rights representative but who always backs out when questioned? What did he do? He guaranteed that all this got a fresh run. Of course, the honourable member for Mayo, being much smarter than the honourable member for North Sydney-if there was any justice he would be sitting on the front bench and the honourable member for North Sydney would be sitting at the back-knew damned well that there was an opportunity to even up a few old scores from years back when he was in Brussels with Cumes. So he was very happy to have the issue brought before the House. He was very happy to say, `I know Cumes. I worked with him and, by golly, because of that I would never defend him'. There are special circumstances in this case and I have outlined them. The reputations of a lot of people were sullied by Cumes. If Cumes is going to do that, if he is going to breach conventions and violate principles, he has to expect to cop it back, because people are going to protect themselves.

I would also like to refer to the recent March issue of the European Community's EC News, Volume 6, No. 2, which seeks to justify the flag swapping practice. The EC News states:

``Flagswapping'' of nuclear materials is not a secret or illegal practice: it is compatible with the bilateral agreements that Euratom has concluded with Australia, Canada and the United States. The prior agreement of these third countries is required only in respect of ``flagswaps'' involving nuclear materials outside the Community.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to debate the Appropriation Bill No. 3 (1987-88) and cognate Bills and to support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I would like to address a few comments to the Department of Transport and Communications, in particular the areas of transport and aviation. I should note at the outset that an additional appropriation for 1987-88 from Appropriation Bill (No. 4), is $507,000 and for Appropriation Bill (No. 3), $3,282,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that I want to say about transport and aviation is that inefficiencies and outdated management and union work practices in the transport network are costing Australian families and consumers around $10,000m a year. This whole situation in regard to the transport network which is so important for Australia, which is so important for Australia's foreign trade and the movement of goods and people around the Commonwealth, is a disgrace. Furthermore, there is emerging evidence that the country's infrastructure is beginning to deteriorate. Certain roads in northern New South Wales and northern Victoria are actually being turned back from bitumen to gravel because of insufficient funds being allowed for their maintenance. We also have difficulties with our ports, bridges and railways. Unless something is done to address the whole question of Australia's infrastructure we will continue to be uncompetitive in terms of world markets. That will mean that we will continue to be unable to sell more to the world than we buy from it. That means we will continue to have difficulties with our external debt. That means that we will leave to our children an Australia that is so heavily in debt as to make it very difficult for them to discharge their obligations to the rest of the world.

Federal road funding has been held at $1,245m for the last four years and so the Commonwealth's contribution to roads around Australia, the Commonwealth's contribution to those arteries on which our cars and trucks move, has actually dropped by 40 per cent in real terms. We understand that the Government is now considering absorbing at least the local government road funding portion of that $1,245m into the general purpose grants to the States. The Government should know that this move is being very strongly opposed by local government, which sees the move as leading to a situation where the States will not pass on the funds to local government and so there will be less money available to local government to spend on this very valuable piece of Australian infrastructure. Road safety, particularly given lower road funding, continues to be of concern to the community. Road accidents round Australia cost the community some $5,000m a year. It is only by giving greater attention to our roads, by spending a relatively greater amount on their construction and maintenance, and by having roads where safety is of importance, that we will be able to get under control this extraordinary cost to the community of some $5,000m a year.

That said about roads, the rail systems of Australia, particularly in Victoria, are costing taxpayers $3,000m a year, and the major causes of this disgraceful situation are inefficiencies, restrictive work practices, union power and lazy management. We are in a situation where in most rail authorities around Australia sick leave is rostered. It is just disgraceful that the owners-and they are the governments-and the managements, which are put there by the owners, do not do something about these restrictive work practices that are costing Australian consumers and families about $3,000m a year. We also understand-and perhaps all will be revealed to us in the May mini-Budget-that the Government is torn between the choice of not funding State rail losses, and that may be possible simply by the Commonwealth saying to the States, `If you insist on running your railways at such extraordinary losses, the general taxpayer will not fund those', or by deducting from the general purpose grants to the States an amount that equals the rail losses.

It is not easy to find out what is going on in the State railways, because the accounts are prepared in such a way as not to give a true picture of their financial situation. It seems to me that if the directors of those rail authorities were directors of public companies, the National Companies and Securities Commission would be directing those directors to bring their accounts into line with normal accounting practice, so that those in the community who take an interest in that kind of thing could determine exactly how much money the railways were losing. As I said, the Government is apparently torn between not funding the State rail losses-something that could be achieved by taking those rail losses from the general purpose grants to the States-or part privatisation of the existing rail network. We have the extraordinary situation where Australian National, which runs the railway that is owned by the Federal Government and which transports freight in Tasmania and freight and people in South Australia, is apparently considering taking over the Western Australian rail network or, as a minimum, working in closer co-operation with it.

What we need to see from the Federal Government is some statement relating to what the Government proposes to do about this extraordinary drain on the community's resources, what it proposes to do about bringing its own railway system into a profitable situation, and what it proposes to do to put appropriate pressure on the States for the States to do the same thing, so that the rail networks around Australia will run efficiently, run on time, run with the goods and people who want to use them, and run profitably.

The slow rate of change to lower manning levels and higher technology ships is costing our community hundreds of millions of dollars and making it difficult for Australian flag ships to be internationally competitive. Over the past 10 years-in a program, incidentally, introduced by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt)-a slow rate of change to lower manning levels has been introduced in ships that operate around Australia and on Australian flag ships that operate internationally. There has been a slow rate of change, but that rate of change has been so slow as to discourage the owners of those ships from making the necessary investment in ships with greater technology, with more effective communications network, and those would mean lower fuel costs.

The slow rate of change of manning levels has meant that there is a disincentive for owners to invest in higher technology ships, and so we have this double effect of manning levels that are in some cases 2 1/2 times those of ships of similar nations operating around the world, and the fact that the owners are not investing in higher technology ships, and hence it makes Australian flag ships quite costly on the coastal routes and it means that they cannot be competitive internationally. The National Farmers Federation, in a recent submission to Government, made it clear that it believes that the situation on manning and low technology ships as far as coastal shipping is concerned is costing the community some $400m and also that the slow rate of change to lower manning levels makes it very difficult for Australian flag ships to be internationally competitive.

If we want to develop an overseas shipping fleet that can compete with the rest of the world, if we want to develop an Australian flag shipping fleet that will take our goods competitively to the rest of the world, something has to be done about a much faster rate of change in manning levels and making sure that the owners of the ships move to higher technology ships so that Australia can derive the benefit of that investment and those lower manning levels. The Government has called for 17 separate reports on the waterfront and shipping in the last five years, and none of them have produced any positive result nor will the current Government reviews of international liner shipping and coastal shipping produce any positive results.

Everybody knows about the difficulties on Australian flag ships and on the waterfront. Everybody knows what has to be done. Yet the Government is simply calling in report after report, when it knows very well what has to be done to resolve the situation. On the waterfront, on that cosy cartel called the Australian waterfront, overmanning, outmoded work practices, political strikes and ineffective management are costing the country $2,000m a year and severely damaging our international trading reputation.

What goes on on the Australian waterfront is an absolute disgrace to the Australian community. The restrictive work practices, the inability of management to focus on the issues and the difficulties with the use of coercive power by the trade union bosses, all of these are contributing to a situation on our waterfront which is an absolute scandal. Our waterfronts are our opening to the world. Our waterfronts are the exit and entry point from which we must get our overseas trading situation under control. People overseas will not buy from Australia if they perceive that their supply of raw materials or manufactured products is going to be held up because of difficulties on the waterfront. We must do something about the waterfront; we must do something to encourage more competition; and we must do something to leave employers and employees free to negotiate their own agreements on the waterfront, which would lead to greater productivity for the benefit of the owner, higher wages for the benefit of the workers and, most of all, reliability, because those agreements would be conducted and agreed to in such a way as to provide sanctions that would be enforceable in the civil courts. In that respect, since this Government has stolen so many of the Opposition's policies, I direct the Government's attention to our industrial relations policy which, if implemented on the waterfront, would make a very positive contribution to resolving the difficulties that are penalising average Australians.

Continued restraints on the availability of capital are restricting Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd in their ability to compete with Ansett Airlines of Australia and internationally respectively. It is now well known, and the Government is conducting a public debate between its factions on this matter, that both Australian Airlines and Qantas require a great deal of money-perhaps $1 billion between them over the next few years-to re-equip their fleets and to update their aircraft so that they can be competitive. The continued deregulation of domestic aviation in Australia will mean that, unless Australian Airlines has more capital with which to re-equip its fleet, it will be gently squeezed out of business. That is a situation that we in Australia cannot allow. Qantas, which requires the bulk of the $1 billion, operates in the difficult and competitive international market and requires more money to re-equip its fleet so that it can compete internationally.

In recent days the Government has come up with an absolutely madcap scheme to merge Qantas, Australian Airlines and Air New Zealand. It did not take Ansett too long to recognise that, if that merger went ahead, the cross-subsidisation that would result between the international operations of the merged group and domestic aviation would put a great deal of pressure on Ansett and would have the potential to force Ansett out of business. As soon as Ansett-quite rightly-started to kick up a fuss about that, Australian airlines was excluded from the megamerger. Now we are left in a situation where the Government is still talking to the New Zealand Government about the possibility of merging Air New Zealand and Qantas. I can cite what the Leader of the New Zealand National Party said recently and publicly. Honourable members may know that at present the National Party is 20 per cent ahead in the New Zealand polls. Talking to us here in Australia, the Leader of the National Party said, `We may love you, but you are not going to take our airline', and subsequently he said, `If you do take it, when we come to power we will take it back'. That is what New Zealand thinks about the megamerger, that madcap scheme to bring together the three airlines.

I refer to the Government's superannuation plans, because the number of resignations of senior experienced pilots from the three Australian airlines-Ansett, Australian Airlines and Qantas-in the past few months as the Government dithers about with its superannuation plans has increased quite sharply. We now have a situation where about 10 per cent of Qantas's senior pilots and executive staff have decided that, rather than risk having their accrued superannuation benefits taken away under the provisions of the May mini-Budget, they will leave-and they have retired.

In terms of road funding, which has dropped by 40 per cent in real terms in the past four years; in terms of the railway systems, which are costing Australia $3,000 a year; in terms of overmanning and lower technology ships; in terms of the cosy cartel called the Australian waterfront, which is costing Australians $2,000m a year; in terms of the absolute mess into which the Government had led us in relation to the domestic and international airline industries; and in terms of the mess that the Government has produced in respect of transport and aviation, the Government is to be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be remiss of me in these debates on Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) if I did not reply quickly to some of the statements made by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Deakin came in with a catalogue of alleged work practices that take place on the waterfront-this Marlon Brando of the waterfront who will put everything right, except for one thing. The Opposition would like to lift the restrictions on foreign crewing of coastal ships. It does not believe that the marketplace alone is the way to determine policies that affect the lives and welfare of Australian families.
