I turn now to the thrust of the Appropriation Bills by referring to a statement by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) that Australia is on the verge of achieving an economic miracle. In an unusually optimistic economic outlook for an employer group, the CAI's monthly Industrial Review, which landed in my room this morning, said that the Australian economy, after a year of strong growth, appears set to stage a truly Lazarus-like recovery. It is said by rational people that behind every miracle is a rational explanation. We do not have to look far to find what is behind the CAI's economic miracle, and that is because a lot of hard work, hard thinking and decent policies have been put into effect by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Hawke Government. The CAI went on to say that we have had success over the last year or so. Unlike the pseudo recovery from 1983 to 1986, this time we have seen recovery accompanied by interest rates falling rather than rising, the dollar moving up rather than down, inflation receding rather than on the increase.

I challenge the statement that there was a pseudo recovery in the first three or four years of the Hawke Government. In those early years, the Hawke Government inherited a disaster and, given the lags of 12 to 18 months in the effect of previous policies, it took a while to get on top of and turn around the disaster that was upon us. One could say that it was one of the deepest recessions that Australia has suffered, under the last years of the Fraser Government, since the great depression. To turn that around when there was the huge adverse terms of trade turnabout where $11 billion was lost per annum in overseas income to this country, and to turn around record levels of unemployment of 10.2 per cent, allowing for lags of the Fraser Government, and inflation in double digit levels, one can only marvel at the economic miracle that is nearly upon us but at the economic miracle of the early years, and perhaps right through the first five years of the Hawke Government.

The turnabout-getting confidence and stability in the economy-has been brought about by correct fiscal and monetary policies and restructuring Australian industry, and the good effects will be carried on in coming years. This Government was not anxious to cut demand on government services and spending but, if it was to be responsible, it needed to do so. Even government sucks in imports; even government competes for resources. If the Government was to control inflation, maintain employment and keep a curb on our adverse current account levels-historically that has always been the case-it had to act responsibly. It did not go for a huge cutback in government spending; it acted in a responsible manner such that employment actually grew. In fact, this Government has created 1,011,000 jobs since it took office on 5 March 1983. Where growth was negative in the last years of the Fraser Government, it has increased by between 2 1/2 and 5 per cent. In 1985-86 it was 4.5 per cent. It has now dropped slightly to 2.5 per cent, but there is every reason to believe that the Budget prediction of a 2.8 to 3 per cent economic growth rate will be achieved.

On the unemployment front the Government has managed in these tight times to reduce the level from 10.2 per cent, as I said, to 7.4 per cent. It has even dropped a further one per cent and stabilised over the past 12 months. If our participation rates of employment had been maintained over that period instead of encouraging more people into the work force, which we want to do, we might very well have seen an effective unemployment rate of nearer 4.3 per cent. Inflation fell from double digit figures to 7.5 per cent and is now running at 6 per cent; that is despite the inflationary impact of the devaluation of the Australian dollar.

That is a rational explanation for the CAI's economic miracle. But, of course, the Government does not expect the Opposition, through the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), to be laudatory about these achievements. In fact, he turned on the CAI and said that the Government had not presided over an economic miracle. One would expect him to say that. Indeed, he had to say it; yet he has given no evidence to support his statement. He claims that talking too much about the achievements of the Government is counterproductive. So this is an example of not just talking down the economy, which is the Opposition's usual forte, but of saying nothing. It has put the gag on, because if the truth is told and it is pointed out that there have been economic achievements under this Government, the unions would be encouraged to put in for gigantic wage claims. So: `It is better to say nothing. Do not be truthful; keep it all quiet'.

Last week in this debate, the honourable member for Kooyong said that the comments made by the Director-General of the CAI were misleading and that the wage budget restraints under Labor had not set Australia on the path to recovery. In effect, he said that the unions had not, through the accord, and through the cooperation of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, tightened their belts, that they had not gone without wage increases. In fact, he indicated, as most employer groups do, that there should be no increases and that every application before the Arbitration Commission should be knocked on the head and it should cut into wages. The Opposition would like to see a real drop in wages, not just a drop in the growth of wages. It would like to see families trying to exist on a lesser income. If we went back to the Opposition's economic policies, that would be in the face of inflation.

In looking around and in urging our business leaders, the honourable member for Kooyong-the would-be Treasurer-finally found an ally in the New South Wales Employers Federation, which said that the trumpeting of the achievements, the statements by the CAI about an economic miracle, was an invitation to the union movement to pursue a wages campaign. So, here we have amongst business-the confreres of the honourable member for Kooyong-this new principle to hide or distort the truth: `Do not tell the people the facts; they might want something out of it'. Members of this House, and the people, should ask themselves why the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), take this approach. Why are they silent? Why do they not recognise the economic miracle that was pointed out by the CAI? They do this because they have no policies themselves. If they had an alternative strategy, one could take the criticism and their alternatives. But no, it is silence; gag them. Just as they gagged their coalition partners on the consumption tax, they now want to gag business and stop other people on the Opposition front bench from saying anything about the achievements of this Government because they have no wages policy except, of course, the time honoured-or time dishonoured-policy of union bashing. The honourable member for Deakin got up and talked about union activities on the waterfront. He outlined no policies; he just bashed the unions. The Liberals believe that somewhere out there people will believe them. But if they do not have a wages policy, what else can they say?

Also, of course, the Liberals have lost the confidence of business. Small business and big business no longer see the Liberal Party of Australia as their supporter because it has failed to show any understanding at all about what restructuring of the Australian economy is about. It has also failed to show any understanding of how to maintain the fight against the twin evils of inflation and unemployment without reducing demand. As all car manufacturers in this country have found, if wages are not maintained, demand for goods and services cannot be maintained. The money is not there. If there is inflation in any section of the economy, such as the car industry, there is even less demand for goods. The ordinary wage and salary earner in Australia is not stupid. Ordinary business is not stupid. They all know that one must have an incomes policy if one is to bring about that fight against inflation and unemployment and still maintain employment and demand. Thus, the Liberals have lost the support of business because they have no alternative polices in the wages or incomes areas. The very split-the very division in their ranks-on just one aspect of tax policy means that business has less time for them and the ordinary Australian no time for them. That one aspect is, of course, the question of consumption tax.

Let us suppose that the Opposition had been in government during these last five years. Let us think of the tragedy that would have prevailed in this country if the Fraser Government or another Liberal government under the honourable member for Bennelong had continued in office. I will tell honourable members what would have happened. Because it would have relied on union bashing, deregulation, market forces, slashing of essential government programs and selling off the important government-owned infrastructure of this country, this ideology-led coalition would have plunged this country even further into depression. It believes solely in a price mechanism, user-pays principle. When unemployment increases, when dole queues lengthen, when social security benefits and pensions are cut-and that is what the coalition would do because honourable members opposite talk about $11 billion to $13 billion being cut off government programs-then the standard of living, the welfare of ordinary Australians, young and old, working or maybe not working, and pensioners, will plummet.

How dare the honourable member for Kooyong attack the trade unions and say they have not contributed to the `economic miracle' that the CAI pointed to. Ordinary wage and salary earners have tightened their belts and have accepted a 5 per cent drop in real incomes over the last couple of years because they had faith that the fruits of what the Government was all about would be delivered. It is not easy for the ACTU and for the Keltys and Creans of the world to sell that message on behalf of the Government. It can only be sold successfully if the ordinary worker knows that there is light at the end of the tunnel-and the CAI says that there is a light at the end of the tunnel; it calls it `a miracle'-and that the Government is also providing the social wage, which is the other side of the coin, the other side of the contract which is known as the accord. The workers know that we have now reached a point where the Government can readjust its progress forward. It can continue the successful fight to bring about the CAI's miracle and can now devote more government energy, ideas and resources to producing more of the other side of the equation; that is, of the accord.

Rather than not being part of this miracle, the trade union movement and the ordinary wage and salary earners have been central to it. The central instrument of the cooperation between the labour movement and this Government has been the accord. It should not be belittled. It has been, as any flexible instrument needs to be, under strain from time to time but the promises must be delivered. So I would take off my hat-if we still wore them in Parliament-to the ordinary working men and women of Australia. But they will not stand by and see a cut in their wages while there is an increase of some 14 to 20 per cent in executive incomes. They will not stand by and see inflation occur under a coalition government. They will not stand by and see cuts in their wages and salaries if business will not invest.

Some of the best news, which has come to this House and to the people, shows that over the last six months there has been a dramatic upturn in the amount of business investment in this country. This Government wants to see equity and fairness. It has obtained the cooperation of working men and women because it is a better economic manager; because it has controlled inflation; because industrial disputes are halved; and, more importantly, because the greatest generator of poverty in this country-unemployment-has been well and truly contained. In fact, employment has increased. The success from here on will be maintenance of the social wage, delivery of the other side of the accord and a rejection of calls, such as that by the Business Council of Australia, that there be a $2.5 billion slash in government spending in the next Budget. I endorse the Bills before the House and compliment the Government, as the CAI puts it, on its `economic miracle'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and to support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). I would like to deal with a couple of points that have been raised by speakers from the other side. In particular I hope to say something about taxation and, if there is time available, to comment on this so-called `economic miracle'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by informing the House that I find these Bills a little incongruous. As the second reading speech suggested, these Bills seek approval for additional appropriations to meet `essential and unavoidable increases in expenditure' in the course of the fiscal year. What I find disturbing and incongruous is that there are no similar approval processes for additional taxation. Indeed, under the current processes this Government has been subjected to very little scrutiny of its initiatives in the area of taxation. Quite frankly, the Government has got away with murder, given the magnitude of the tax increases that it has been able to rip out of the average Australian since it has been in office.

I was fascinated to listen to some of the comments made earlier in the debate by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). He attempted to suggest that this is not a high taxing government. He attempted to create the impression that the Opposition is beating this up and that, by world standards, his standards, or whatever, the tax burden in Australia is not excessive. I might suggest that he talk to some of his colleagues who are a little more straightforward and honest in this matter-for example, Senator Cook who, on 1 May 1985, is quoted in the Sun-News Pictorial as saying:
The Labor Party is a high-taxing party. It needs to be to carry out its reforms.

There is far too little of that sort of honesty in this Government when it comes to assessing its relative economic performance and, in particular, its performance in the area of taxation. It prefers to perpetuate the myth that it is a low taxing Government. And that is precisely what I would like to focus on. I would like to take the opportunity to accept the challenge to talk about the Hawke Government's record on taxation. To my mind it is a record of broken promises, arrogance and hypocrisy. It is a record of taxation by stealth. It is a record of taxation by inflation. It is a story of inefficiency; it is a story of inequity.

Even the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not above the exercise of trying to mislead this House as to the true nature of this Government's performance on tax. In this regard, I refer the House to the 1987-88 Budget Speech wherein the Treasurer made some very interesting comments when introducing the section on revenue. He says:
. . . we have adhered to our election commitment not to increase taxes or introduce new taxes.

He was, of course, speaking about that particular Budget. He then says that he has been able to cut spending and taxes at the same time. I would imagine that he did this in one of his economic miracles! But in the very next paragraph he goes on to explain exactly how this all hangs together. He states:

The capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and related measures like many things that are new, were controversial at inception, but are now fulfilling their proper structural function by massively broadening the tax base.
I suggest that it is hard to claim that he has not increased tax when he is also simultaneously claiming some merit for broadening the tax base.

We can look at the issue of the burden of taxation in a number of ways. I will run through a few of these for the House. I guess the first way to look at this matter is to concentrate on the overall level of Budget revenue which, if we look at the record of this Government, has risen in real terms in every single year that this Government has been in office at an average real rate of increase of 4.7 per cent. This rate of real increase is significantly greater, of course, than that of the Government's predecessors which the Government seems to like to bucket on occasions. In 1983-84 the real increase was 1.6 per cent; in 1984-85, a whopping 10.4 per cent real increase; in 1985-86, a 5.2 per cent real increase; in 1987-88 a 4.1 per cent real increase; this year it looks like the real increase will be about 2 per cent against the Budget estimate of 1.2 per cent and about the same order of magnitude is implicit in the Forward Estimates for the next year.

Another way of making the point is to suggest that if Budget revenue had not been increased in real terms, if it had remained constant in real terms over the life of this Government, the Government would have collected about $10 billion less than it has actually collected. Not surprisingly therefore, total tax revenue has risen relative to gross domestic product under this Government. That is something that will withstand the test of time irrespective of the fact that the honourable member for Fraser tried to create the impression that that statistic had not increased over the life of this Government.

The Government claims to have been fiscally responsible, to have restrained expenditure and virtually to have balanced its Budget. Indeed, it is now looking to a small Budget surplus this year. We can all guess exactly how it did this. The Government did this-that is right-by increasing taxation. Over the life of this Government, total budgetary revenues have risen by about $33.8 billion-that is, by about 60 per cent, which is well in excess of the total increase in inflation over the life of this Government of about 39 per cent. Over the life of this Government there has been a cumulative real increase in taxation of over 20 per cent.

Against that, outlays over the same period have gone up by about 29.4 billion. So the difference between $29.4 billion and $33.8 billion is, of course, the Budget deficit that the Government claims to have eliminated. So the Government has only eliminated the Budget deficit by increasing the overall tax burden significantly. In fact, if we recognise the possibility of a Budget surplus this year of, say, $1 billion, we can see that the Government will have achieved a cumulative net increase in taxation over and above expenditure of about $5.5 billion by the end of this financial year. So I suggest to the honourable member for Fraser and to other Government's supporters who have spoken in this debate that they go back and have a long hard look at their own Budget Papers. They should not just focus on a selective statistic, but take a particularly hard look at the Government's overall revenue performance.

One should not of course just concentrate on aggregate Budget revenue. If one looks at the components of revenue, one gets an even more disturbing picture of the Government's performance. Income tax is, of course, the place to start. Income tax has risen by about 79 per cent over the life of the Hawke Government, which is a cumulative real increase of about 40 per cent. Not surprisingly, the tax burden on individuals and families in this country has jumped dramatically. For example, back in March 1983 a single taxpayer on average weekly earnings paid about a 22.9 per cent average tax rate. Today that rate is now around 26 or 27 per cent. His weekly tax bill has gone up from $85 to about $137. Similarly, the average tax rate of a single income family on average weekly earnings over the same period-from March 1983 until recently-has gone up from about 17 1/2 to about 22 1/2 per cent, or their weekly tax bill has gone up from $65 to around $117. That sort of increase in tax is what this Government would have us believe is significant tax reform. The fact is that the tax burden on individuals has jumped dramatically.

Apart from new taxes, such as capital gains taxes and fringe benefit taxes, the main reason for this increase in taxation has been taxation by inflation or, as some people would call it, bracket creep. Average income has generally risen over the life of the Hawke Government. Although there have been some adjustments to the tax scales-and these alone have been debated-individuals have generally been pushed into higher income tax brackets. So individuals today face significantly higher marginal tax rates on every dollar that they earn than they did in 1982-83 when this Government came to power. The marginal tax rate for the examples I quoted before was 30 per cent when the Government took office. It is now 40 per cent. I suggest to the honourable member for Fraser and others that they have a long hard look at that sort of statistic as well.

The honourable member for Fraser was inclined to suggest that there were not any disincentive effects associated with the current level of taxation. I think a jump in the marginal tax rate from 30 to 40 per cent is sufficient reason to suggest why people do not want to work harder, whey they do not want to work overtime or accept promotion. There are a host of other examples of why the tax system carries a considerable disincentive effect.

The Government has raised about $20 billion since its tax reform package was introduced in 1985. It has given back about $6 1/2 billion in tax cuts. So out of every $4 it has raised, it has let us keep $1 and has taken back $3 for itself. This is hardly a record of tax reform. The fact is that the average income earner today is squarely in the middle of the 40 per cent tax bracket. This is a major rip-off. It is not surprising that this rip-off is concentrated on the pay as you earn taxpayer. He is the one who suffers most. It is little wonder that that group in particular, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is now conceding, has started to mount the argument that this Government has lost touch with the average Australian. I am fascinated at the way in which the Government likes to bucket the performance of the Fraser Government on taxation. If we had kept the same average tax rate during the life of the Hawke Government as we had under the Fraser Government, the present Government would have collected something like $17 billion less in tax.

Let me now leave the question of income taxes and have a look at indirect taxes, an area about which, I gather, there has been a fair bit of debate in recent times. Perhaps I should begin by focusing the minds of honourable members squarely on the fact that our existing indirect taxes are, in fact, consumption taxes. The Government, of course, has set out to try to make the Opposition appear to be in particularly difficult economic and political circumstances; it is suggesting that we are looking to have a new tax, that we are looking to introduce a consumption tax. Of course, what we are trying to do is review and reform the whole area of taxation. But, while the Government has been trying to paint us into a corner on this, the facts are that we already have a phenomenal number of consumption taxes in this country. There should be no misunderstanding: we already have a substantial set of consumption taxes. The magnitude and incidence of these taxes should be a matter of great concern to all Australians.

I am fascinated that the Hawke Government apparently can find some satisfaction in the present discriminatory and unfair system of consumption taxes. In some cases, it has changed those taxes to its considerable benefit. As a result this is now an area that needs fundamental reform; and it is an area that has a certain inevitability about it for reform, given its unfairness and inequity. It is no good for the Government to stick its head in the sand and poke fun at us. It is a problem that as a government it is going to have to deal with. It is an area that needs genuine reform.

The existing consumption tax system is very selective, unfair and inequitable. In some cases the rates of tax are quite draconian and there are glaring loopholes in the way the tax has impacted. For example, over the life of the Hawke Government sales tax, which is the key consumption tax in this country, has gone up by 110 per cent, from about $3.5 billion to $7.5 billion in the current year. This 110 per cent increase is significantly greater than the increase in inflation. Indeed, it is nearly three times the increase of 39 per cent in the inflation rate over that period. It is more than double the 50 per cent increase in wages, salaries and supplements and almost double the 60 per cent rise in consumer expenditure over that period. There has therefore been a very significant increase in revenue taken from the Australian tax paying public through this very hefty consumption tax alone. This year sales tax receipts were estimated to go up by about 12 per cent. According to the latest Niemeyer statement, the revenue from that tax alone is likely to increase by about 18 per cent.

So just as there has been an income tax rip-off under the Hawke Government, there has also been a substantial consumption tax rip-off. In addition as I have said, the existing sales tax is quite inequitable. As we have said on previous occasions, there is, for example, a sales tax on ice cream and flavoured milk but not on pornographic magazines. There is a consumption tax on orange juice but not on $1,000 ball gowns. Moreover we all know that the cash economy is rampant. There is also a very strong argument that tourists are getting off lightly in this country, by not paying their fair share of our tax revenue. And finally there is a whole host of services and other loopholes which are not covered by the existing sales tax system.

As well as looking at sales tax, let us look at excises. It is in this area that we see some fairly draconian rates of effective tax, sometimes in excess of 100 per cent on certain key commodities. Do honourable members remember what this Government did about excises in August 1983? It decided to index them. This decision took excise rates out of the regular annual review of the budgetary process. So people have now lost sight of the effective tax rates on commodities such as petrol, cigarettes, liquor and so on. As such this is a very effective example of taxation by stealth on the part of this Government.

Another area of consumption tax, and one that is very important to this Government, is that of customs duties. Honourable members should recognise that those duties also have a consumption tax equivalent. A recent Industries Assistance Commission report on the level of protection in manufacturing suggested that a `consumption tax equivalent' of about 7.6 per cent was already built into our system of customs duties. I ask honourable members to think about its existing system of consumption tax. How is it that honest and clean living Paul can come into this House and tip buckets on the Opposition for considering the need to reform such a taxation system when, mostly by stealth, he continues to rip the revenue out of the system through a whole range of substantive and inequitable consumption taxes?

Corporate tax is another area that has recently received some attention by the Treasurer. Honourable members will remember that at about the time of the last Budget he started to build up expectations about how much could be done in the corporate taxation area and how, to do this, he intended to have a corporate tax review. The suggestions emanating from those quarters at that time were that there would be a review of taxation of superannuation funds and a review of accelerated depreciation allowances available to business, and that both these would be put back in the pot with a view to producing a lower corporate tax rate. Since then, in the aftermath of the stock market crash and a number of other developments, the Treasurer has been trying-most recently in a speech to the Committee for Economic Development of Australia-to downplay expectations as to how much can now be achieved in the corporate tax area. Simultaneously, he has tried to mount an argument that corporate taxation in Australia is not really too high by world standards. There is little doubt, particularly on the part of those who pay it, but more generally by international assessments that we have one of the highest effective corporate tax rates in the world. So again, corporate tax is an area that requires genuine reform. It has been an area of total neglect under this Government. It is an area that will need to be looked at seriously.

So, Mr Deputy Speaker, this Government's record on tax is one of absolute hypocrisy and arrogance. It is a record of taxation by stealth. It is a record of taxation by inflation. It is a story of inequity and inefficiency. It is a story of broken promises and hypocrisy. Honourable members might remember some of the statements made in the past several years by leading spokesmen for the Government. For example I refer them to this statement by the Prime Minister in his election speech on 16 February 1983:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.
Of course, a capital gains tax was imposed in September 1985. Again the Prime Minister, in a rural policy speech on 20 February 1983, said:
Labor has pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine.

And of course, we know that a wine sales tax was imposed in August 1984. Similarly, at a Press conference on 15 April 1983 the Prime Minister said `there has been no basis for the speculation' that lump sum superannuation tax payments would be increased. Of course, lump sum superannuation tax increased in May 1983, just one month after he made that statement. Finally, on 11 December 1984, speaking on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program PM, the Prime Minister said:
. . . let me make it clear that this is not a country which needs an increase in the tax burden and under my Government it's not going to get it.

On the basis of that record, I suggest to the House that Government spokesmen should sit in the House and hang their heads in shame. It is a record of unbelievable dishonesty in the area of taxation when it comes to dealing with and informing the Australian public. Yet there is an inevitability about tax reform. Instead of bucketing us in the Opposition for taking the time and the care and for making the effort to conduct a thoroughgoing review of taxation, after which we will come out with a sensible and viable taxation policy alternative, I suggest that the Government spokesmen get back into their own back rooms and do a bit of the essential work that is required to reform our tax system to one that is consistent with sustainable economic growth in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) allow for a wide-ranging debate on services provided by the Federal Government to the Australian people. In the time allowed to me, I will discuss some aspects of higher education and research being carried out in north Queensland. The Hawke Government has long maintained that the higher education system has a central role to play in the process of economic and social adjustment racing Australia. We recognise that Australia and, indeed, the world are now going through enormous changes in virtually every facet of our society. We believe we must respond to the challenges of these events if we are to share in the benefit from the enormous changes that are happening. Most higher education authorities have welcomed these new challenges. They are being challenged to examine their role in the social, cultural and economic lives of Australians and then to examine how effectively they are discharging those roles.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fundamentally important to the improved development of higher education in Australia that universities be dynamic and innovative. They must continue to explore new areas of research and devise new avenues in teaching in a way which will ensure that graduates are competent to accept responsibly their obligation to help shape the future of Australia. One of Australia's most dynamic and innovative universities, James Cook University of North Queensland, is located in my electorate. Its Vice-Chancellor is the distinguished Australian scientist and educationalist Professor Ray Golding. Over the past years James Cook University has been grappling with many of the challenges to which I have already referred and has, in fact, already taken steps to be able effectively to respond to the needs of the North Queensland region and the nation.

This year, Australia's bicentennial year, the James Cook University of North Queensland will celebrate 27 years of university teaching and research in Townsville-first as a university college and then, from 1970, as the James Cook University of North Queensland. It is a university which has its own distinctive character. It has developed a national and international reputation for its research and teaching in a number of areas. It serves a population of approximately half a million Australians and an area four to five times the size of Tasmania. It is Australia's only university located in the tropics, and for the people of north Australia it is their university. Its current student enrolment is approximately 4,300, and by 1990 student enrolment should exceed 5,000, provided that Government funding continues to meet legitimate growth demands.

This debate gives me an opportunity to inform honourable members of major scientific and education advances being made in Australia's only university in the tropics. Both sides of politics claim that it is vital for the prosperity of Australia that basic university research be given the utmost financial and structural support. Industry looks increasingly to universities to provide a source of skilled manpower and a knowledge base upon which to build collaboration between universities and industry. This is essential. As I have indicated, universities must be dynamic if they are to capitalise on the cooperation between the academic and industry. Above all, universities must be able to respond quickly to new challenges and to the promotion of new technology.

I am pleased to inform honourable members that James Cook University is making significant progress in this direction. It has developed research and teaching strengths with a special emphasis on programs in the broad categories of topics of special relevance to north Queensland, the Pacific region and the tropics in general. Special research training and teaching strengths at the university include biological sciences, with a special emphasis on the tropics; business management; tourism and travel studies; computing and information sciences; earth sciences, with special reference to the mineral industries of north Queensland; engineering and technology, with special emphasis on the tropics, and on cyclones and other natural disasters; living in the tropics, with special reference to archaeology, history, geography, education and culture of north Queensland; marine sciences, with special emphasis on mariculture and studies of the Great Barrier Reef; tropical health and medicine; tropical veterinary science; and tropical agriculture.

Last year the James Cook University established the Anton Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine, and the first chair of tropical health and medicine at an Australian university. This appointment has been taken up by Professor Hedley Peach. Forming part of the Anton Breinl Centre is the new federally funded tropical health surveillance unit at James Cook University. The university is to receive approximately $2.6m from the Hawke Government over the next five years. The centre will have a broad focus of activities-for example, looking at the health of Aboriginal, Torres Strait Islanders and other Australians; examining communicable and non-communicable diseases of the tropics; focusing on both lifestyle and the environment as causes of disease; and the mounting and evaluating of intervention programs. The establishment of the Anton Breinl Centre owes much to the wisdom and foresightedness of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). The people of north Queensland will be forever grateful to him for his support for the establishment of the Anton Breinl Centre.

Medical research was first established in Australia in the tropics. The Institute of Tropical Medicine in Townsville was set up under the directorship of Dr Anton Breinl in 1910. James Cook University has acknowledged history by setting up the Antol Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine, of which the new Commonwealth health surveillance unit will be a vital part. In addition to the university, Commonwealth and State departments of health, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and medical specialists in the Townsville region will develop further the existing network of research.

Tropical medicine has many facets, from the development of new drugs and vaccines, through diagnostic laboratory services, to the delivery of health services to people who actually live in the tropics. While all of these will be part of the new research network, it is the actual medical service to people which promises to give extra strength and interest to these new developments. The existence of efficient health services in the tropics is likely to be of considerable interest in other tropical areas where most of the world's population lives. New systems and technologies will be transferable to developing countries for the benefit of human populations just as agriculture and veterinary technologists have already been exported from tropical Queensland to many other parts of the world.

But there is so much to do in our own country. Torres Strait Islanders have a higher incidence of a number of health problems than other Australians. Some of these health problems are proving difficult for doctors to treat and their aetiology is so poorly understood that it is difficult to mount preventative programs. Two such related health problems are pneumonia and middle ear disease. The death rate from pneumonia among Torres Strait Islanders is almost three times that of the rest of Queensland, and the incidence of middle ear disease among these people is far higher than among Caucasian Australians.

There are a number of infectious agents which can cause pneumonia and middle ear disease: viruses, bacteria, mycoplasma and chlamydia trachomatis. By not knowing which are the most important agents it is impossible to provide advice to medical officers regarding treatment regimens. Medical scientists are only just beginning to appreciate the role of chlamydia in respiratory disease and middle ear problems. Chlamydia trachomatis is known to cause a severe pneumonia in young children, and in most cases where it has been looked for, a coincident genital chlamydial infection has been found in the mother. Preliminary work at the Menzies School of Health Research in Darwin is pointing to a link between genital chlamydial infection and otitis media in Aborigines. Genital chlamydial infection is extremely prevalent in the Torres Strait and it is therefore very possible that chlamydia contributes significantly to the high prevalence of pneumonia and middle ear diseases. Medical scientists need to know whether this is so. Chlamydial pneumonia and probably middle ear disease will respond to the correct antibiotic but the correct antibiotic to be used can be established only by careful testing of the sensitivity of the organism to antibiotics in the laboratory. If chlamydia turns out to have an important role in respiratory disease and otitis media, prospective studies will be needed to establish whether there is a link between the genital infection in the mother and the subsequent development of pneumonia and otitis media in the children. This would include serotyping to establish that the same type of chlamydia is involved in mother and child. If that turns out to be the case, then screening of women for genital chlamydia infection followed by a course of the appropriate antibiotic should lead to eradication of the reservoir of infection in mothers and children.

The investigation of the role of chlamydial infection in pneumonia and middle ear disease requires a laboratory which is equipped to be able to identify the chlamydia organism in sputum, middle ear fluid, and cervical smears through fluoriescence microscopy. Culturing of the organism for testing the sensitivity of antibiotics in order to be able to identify the type of antibiotic and the dose needed to kill the organism in vitro is essential as are serotyping facilities. These laboratory facilities do not exist at Thursday Island Hospital and could be established and staffed by a microbiology technician at Horn Island if funds were available. The eradication of genital chlamydial infection, middle ear disease and a reduction in the incidence of respiratory disease would make an enormous contribution to the health of Torres Strait Islanders.

In March this year, the Anton Breinl Centre requested $200,000 a year for approximately three years to provide technical support for the project, which would allow for the development of cultures and serotyping together with antibody sensitivity testing. If the funding were made available it would be possible to isolate the causes of these diseases which have long term debilitating effects on the Torres Strait Islanders. However, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) advised me approximately two weeks ago that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs does not fund research into Aboriginal health as this is the function of the National Health and Medical Research Council. It is a great disappointment to me that this urgently needed funding has yet to be approved. The health and welfare of the people of the Torres Strait Island are far more important than any other prospective program for their development. No amount of money, no so-called worthwhile project can take the place of the health and life of one Torres Strait Island person. This program, by any yardstick, is fundamental to the health and welfare of the people of the Torres Straits and I again call on the Government to provide the money sought by the Anton Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine so that this important program can get under way as soon as possible. To delay the program in the face of the continuing presence of the diseases is intolerable.

Last year the James Cook University of North Queensland also established the Centre for Studies in Travel and Tourism and Australia's first academic chair of tourism. The centre, which this year received its inaugural intake of students, offers a full time four-year program leading to the degree of Bachelor of Administration (Tourism). Established as a direct response to the growing need for qualified professionals in Australia's tourism industry, the centre aims to attract students and research projects throughout Australia and its South Pacific neighbours. In Queensland alone, tourism has created approximately 40 per cent of new jobs over the last five years. This is an important initiative for the development of the fastest growing industry in my state of Queensland. The new chair of tourism has been well supported by the Australian tourism industry. Primary funding has been received from the Australian Tourism Industry Association, the Australian Federation of Travel Agents and the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation.

James Cook University of North Queensland has also given priority to studies and research into tropical ecosystems and their conservation and management and human adaption and cultures in the region. For example, in 1987 the university established the Australian Centre for Tropical Freshwater Research. It is Australia's first centre to study freshwater in the tropics. Funding for the centre is provided by a $250,000 a year grant from the Federal Government and, through the Australian Water Research Advisory Council, the centre is receiving additional assistance. It also receives $75,000 a year from the Queensland Water Resources Commission. Funds have been guaranteed for three years in the first instance, with extensions likely beyond that period. The Australian Centre for Tropical Freshwater Research has three initial objectives. The first is to help to understand the physical, chemical and biological behaviour of tropical water storage such as at the Ross River and Burdekin dams. The second is to study run-off, erosion and the soil leeching processes in tropical environments; and the third is to improve information currently available on tropical freshwater streams and waterways.

As tropical Australia accounts for an extremely large part of the continent's freshwater resources, the centre in Townsville is of great importance, not only for the study of freshwater in the tropical environment, but also for its ecosystems. The Australian Centre for Tropical Freshwater Research is uniquely placed to undertake research into both wet and dry tropics. The development of expertise in these areas, studies and research will be of enormous benefit not only to northern Australia but also will have potential for export to South East Asia and Africa. In its early years the university sought to serve the educational and research needs of north Queensland, by providing courses of relevance to north Queensland whose economic importance is only now being exploited. Now James Cook University has broadened its focus away from just north Queensland. In a very proud way and more than ever before it is serving the needs of Australia. To fulfil this role of service to Australia, James Cook University must receive adequate funding. Like all other Australian universities, it has seen no major increase in funding levels. At the moment, James Cook University is exploring ways of obtaining money from non-government sources to enable it to continue to develop teaching and research programs to meet the needs of a range of industries.

The James Cook University of North Queensland has enthusiastically accepted the challenge of the nation to provide worthwhile and fundamentally sound higher education. It has the ability and academic excellence to achieve this objective-and more. James Cook's Vice-Chancellor, Professor Ray Golding, has recently assured this Government:

The development by each institution of an educational profile which describes the institution's existing course mix, and its future strategies building upon its strengths, is essential if each institution is to meet the higher education needs of its community and contribute to the national priorities.

James Cook University has shown successfully that individual entity does not mean a narrow prospective or approach, but is a way for an institution to contribute effectively to the higher education needs of the nation. A great deal still needs to be accomplished, but James Cook shows that a major series of developments can be successfully initiated.
I am proud to have within my electorate the James Cook University of North Queensland. While it continues to exist, Australia will continue to build and be a stronger and much better nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are discussing the Appropriation Bills. I would particularly like to concentrate on the section on foreign aid which, I believe, is relevant to the recent trip of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) when he visited Africa earlier this year. During that trip he pledged $100m in aid over the next three years to African states. This will go to states mainly that border South Africa which is a country which the Minister has labelled with some relish as the `great international leper of our time'. So apparently most of this money will go to the so-called front line states of Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe, as well as Angola, Botswana and Tanzania.

SPEECH.PARA: Africa is several thousand miles away, across the other side of the Indian Ocean. I think it ironic that we are giving that aid at the same time as, nearer to home, Papua New Guinea is having foreign aid money withdrawn. Papua New Guinea, I remind honourable members, is a parliamentary democracy which upholds principles similar to our own. This is in contrast, for example, to the money given to Mozambique which is a one-party dictatorship, set up on Marxist-Leninist lines and closely allied with the Soviet bloc. Mozambique allows no opposition parties, no expression of dissent and has trouble with border disputes with even a most moderate independent country such as Malawi. Ever since Portugal pulled out of Mozambique in 1975 the Government forces there, called Frelimo, have ruled the country ruthlessly. They have a strongly centralised administration which is rife with corruption and incompetence.

The troubles, we must remember, of this once rich country, this beautiful country, are largely of its Government's own making. It blames all its woes on South Africa which, it claims, funds the so-called rebel group Renamo. Let us cast our minds back to 1984 when the Nkomati accord was signed between South Africa and Mozambique. There were a couple of main conditions. One was that Mozambique would not harbour any African National Congress rebels who were attacking South Africa. Secondly, in return South Africa would provide no funding for Renamo rebels. All the evidence points to South Africa having kept its part of the Nkomati Accord but Mozambique has not. Accusations are constantly made that South Africa funds Renamo. I can find no evidence whatsoever of this funding. It all seems to be hearsay from Frelimo sympathisers. The United States Ambassador to Mozambique, Mellisa Wells, reported that she could find no concrete proof to substantiate this claim. Helga Jensen of the Washington Times, and Sharon Behn of the Independent could not find any evidence. Also, Lord Michael Cecil of the Sunday Times could find no evidence. As well, the International Institute of Strategic Studies, which is London based, found when it investigated this claim that Renamo was self-sustaining and depending largely on weaponry captured from the Frelimo forces themselves. It was found that the weaponry was largely Russian. United States correspondent, Richard Grenier, writes that the Renamo soldiers he met had no uniforms, their weapons were old Soviet AKs and grenade launchers and they communicated with an ancient hand-cranked telephone. They also had to walk to get anywhere as they had only one motor cycle between them.

Renamo is led mainly by veterans who have broken away from Frelimo forces in which they fought as freedom fighters against the Portuguese but left when they became disillusioned with Marxist policies after Frelimo came to power. Renamo now controls most of the country. However, Renamo soldiers are in rags, using antiquated weapons with limited ammunition, damaged rifles, and are barefoot. They have only a few radio sets between them and a few SAM-7 anti-aircraft missiles. If South Africa is funding them, it is doing it in a very poor way. In fact, the truth is that South Africa is funding Mozambique. South Africa has transport engineers in the country servicing locomotives and aircraft. That is also done in South Africa itself. There are many legal Mozambican workers in South Africa. In fact, there are 60,000 legal workers as well as 200,000 illegal workers. They remit money to Mozambique. I have been able to trace that 84 million rand was remitted to Mozambique in 1985. South Africa has helped to upgrade with grants the sugar factories in Mozambique. South Africans are working with Mozambicans to revitalise the Cabora Bassa hydro-electricity scheme. They have poured 7 million rand into upgrading the Maputo harbour port facilities. However, Mozambique continues publicly to denounce South Africa. This Government also runs that sort of line.

The Renamo success depends on the deep unpopularity of the Government. When Portugal left Mozambique in 1975 the Frelimo guerillas who fought the long colonial war against Portugal grabbed power. As part of the socialist experiment they put the peasants into collective villages which, as honourable members can guess, has ended in disaster. People have resented and rebelled against this. As in most African countries, the blacks do not get a vote in Mozambique.

The leader of the Renamo freedom fighters, Alfonso Dhlakama, has laid down the conditions that Renamo wants. Basically they are that all foreign troops should lead Mozambique and that the country should have free and internationally supervised elections. To me that sounds totally reasonable and totally democratic. One would think that the Government in this country would support that position, but no, it supports the Soviet-backed dictatorship which denies black people in Mozambique the vote and, at the same time, rejects a popular movement that wants simultaneously to give them the vote and reject communism.

Let us look at the foreign troops in Mozambique propping up the Frelimo government. There are 15,000 Zimbabweans, including the 6th Brigade which takes part in actions against the civilian population known to be sympathetic to Renamo. The 6th Brigade soldiers play a leading offensive role. In fact, on 28 April last year they reoccupied the independent town of Morrumbala, rounding up suspects and beheading them. Like the North Korean trained 5th Brigade in Zimbabwe, which shot over 20,000 civilians in Matabeleland, the behaviour of those soldiers at times has been abysmal. As well there are 5,000 Tanzanians in Mozambique. There are 10,000 Eastern bloc military and technical personnel, including 2,261 Soviets, 1,038 East Germans and 2,202 Cubans. Since 1975 the Soviets have put over $1 billion in military hardware into Mozambique. For example, on 27 August last year they delivered four MI8 helicopters to that country. Frelimo officials regularly visit Moscow for military discussions. As well in Mozambique there are 3,000 Zambians. There are 2,000 Malawians, mainly in defensive positions along the Nacala corridor. Of course, Britain trains Frelimo officers inside Zimbabwe. Portugal, France and Spain have had recent approaches from Frelimo asking for military defence assistance. As well, there are several hundred South African technicians, as I mentioned previously, assisting in ports, harbours, railways, aircraft maintenance, food, electricity and the spare parts area. In spite of all these foreign troops and aid the Frelimo Government is still a corrupt shambles.

The Anglican and Catholic bishops of Maputo, supported by seven other bishops, have written making an impassioned plea for negotiations between the Government and Renamo forces as the only way to peace. So far perhaps 100,000 people have lost their lives in the fighting alone but this reasonable request is rejected by Frelimo. The media in Australia, especially the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which one would think had a duty to report such events, have put a near total news blackout on this. Only the inaccurate pro-Frelimo, anti-South African, anti-Renamo line that fits the ideologies of the ABC hierarchy is run in this country. For example, it always labels the Renamo forces as `rebels', never as `freedom fighters'.

Renamo now controls at least one-third of the population and 85 per cent of the territory. This is a far greater proportion than ever the Mujahideen had in Afghanistan. Renamo has grown from a mere 2,000 guerillas in 1981 to nearly 20,000 today. It is twice the size that the communist Frelimo movement was when the Portuguese pulled out in 1975. Despite this, the country is still in ruins. For example, Maputo, the capital, once the Riviera of Africa with cafes, villas, beaches, fountains, gardens and tourists, now is little more than a picture of desolation and decay. There are no taxis and no buses. There are abandoned railway carriages. Vehicles have been abandoned for lack of spare parts. It is difficult to buy anything there. Shops remain open but there is nothing on their shelves. Houses have no water, no electricity or even glass in the windows. The only relief from this despair are the occasional expensive, air-conditioned limousines gliding around the streets with top bureaucrats and Frelimo officials in them. Such people live in fine houses with many servants and have exclusive access to speciality shops stocked full of fine goods, mainly imported from South Africa.

United States correspondent, Richard Grenier, writes that the government officials and their wives are always beautifully dressed and are as natty as Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev. The present names of once splendid avenues in Maputo are revealing. There is the Karl Marx Avenue, the Friedrich Engels Avenue and Vladimir Lenin Avenue, Mao Tse-tung has an avenue named after him, as do Salvador Allende, Ho Chi Minh and so on. I can report that history is nothing if not consistent and the economic and human rights successes of past socialist luminaries have been faithfully replicated throughout the length and breadth of Mozambique.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the detriment of the people.

—That is correct. As African correspondent Bruce Louden reports, when the Portuguese left Mozambique there was a thriving export-oriented industrial sector. But by late last year this had been reduced to a single factory producing car tyres. Even that has been crippled as a result of an inability to get spare parts for production equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: Frelimo started to go wrong when the original Frelimo freedom fighters, who had battled against the Portuguese, were infiltrated at the leadership level by a Marxist faction that had been trained in Algeria. They became known as the Algerian gang. They still make up the top Frelimo leadership today, including Chissano, the President. This gang grabbed power when the Portuguese fled in 1974 after the socialist coup in Lisbon. The socialist-communist coalition that came to power in Portugal did not grant elections in Mozambique despite the existence of several healthy parties. So Frelimo became installed in 1975 and the infamous Samora Machel set up his equally infamous concentration camps. All property was nationalised and gross human rights abuses soon abounded everywhere. Hunger and unemployment soon followed. The Soviets and other Eastern bloc neo-colonials soon plundered Mozambique's natural resources, including its human resources. Children were sent overseas for indoctrination. Slave labour was exported. Ten thousand were sent to East Germany.

When many decent Frelimo members saw what the Algerian gang was doing they felt that their independence, for which they had fought so hard, had been betrayed. The Portuguese colonialism had simply been exchanged for an even worse Soviet colonialism. Today there is increasing tension and disillusionment between Frelimo's political and military wings. The political wing consists predominantly of non-black communist party members. However, the army is almost exclusively black and more concerned about Mozambique itself and the promise of freedom rather than the oppressive communist ideology they are being ordered to defend. Both Presidents Machel and Chissano have had to conduct numerous purges and shake-ups of the military to avoid a consolidation of Renamo collaborating elements.

A defector from Frelimo, Jose Francisco, who escaped the country and gave testimony to the United States Senate last year, has retold the story of how Renamo came into being. An Andre Matsangaisse, one of the former President Machel's own officers, raised a protest at the sending of his countrymen overseas as slave labour. He was immediately sent to the Sacuze concentration camp, along with his sympathising colleagues, for eventual execution. However, he and his men escaped by overpowering the guards, stealing their weapons and taking to the bush. They regrouped at Gorongosa from where they initiated attacks against other concentration camps, capturing the weapons and liberating the detainees. So the armed resistance was born, called the Resistencia National Mocambicana or Renamo for short. Matsangaisse was killed in battle five years later and Alfonso Dhlakama took over command. In their early years they received some logistical support from the Rhodesian Government as retaliation to Frelimo giving sanction to Mugabe's Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army guerillas.

Also South Africa offered them limited assistance in the form of medical supplies, communication equipment and some captured South West Africa People's Organisation weapons. This was done to counter Frelimo's harbouring and supporting the anti-South African African National Congress terrorists. However, this South African assistance ceased with the signing of the Nkomati Accord between South Africa and Mozambique in 1984. Renamo has had to become self-reliant and totally motivated to exist, but this freedom fighting organisation grows in strength every day as the Frelimo atrocities continue unabated.

Let me recount some of the evidence of Jose Francisco to the American Senate last year of what the Frelimo gets up to, so that the Australian people can know what sort of a regime it is that our Foreign Minister is giving their money to. Jose Francisco was a member of Frelimo, but became disgusted with it from seeing what he describes as `unbelievable atrocities' which regularly took place under the authority of the Frelimo banner. This all happened after the moderate founder of Frelimo, Dr Eduardo Mondlane, was murdered and the communists infiltrated the organisation with Samora Machel as President. Machel's defence chief, Alberto Chipande, personally executed his own father in the presence of 1,000 Frelimo cadres as an example for establishing `the new order'. This public murder was committed by stabbing his father in the stomach and ripping upwards until his viscera spilled to the ground. Joaquim Chissano, their chief of security, personally approved the execution as a teaching method, as he did all atrocities that Francisco witnessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is his father?

—Yes, his father. Later, Chissano became Foreign Minister, which made him the de facto head of the state secret police, SNASP. This group implemented the system of concentration camps and political torture that Frelimo used. Their terror network has input from the KGB, East German intelligence and the Cubans. Chissano, of course, is now the President of Mozambique, since Machel's death in an air crash in a Russian plane, and Chissano is the person our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) met with and had his arm around on his recent visit there while discussing how much Australian taxpayers' money he can give this vile murderer. He gave Mozambique an extra $6m, bringing the total aid for this year up to $9.5m, a 30 per cent increase over what was given in 1987. As well, the Minister has committed more taxpayers' money to a Commonwealth fund to assist Mozambique and a substantial slice of the $100m promised to the front line states.

SPEECH.PARA: Jose Francisco's description of what happened to another moderate Frelimo leader, Silveiro Nungo, is possibly the most shocking story I have ever heard. A Fremilo leader, Mariano Matsinhe, now Security Minister, and also a member of the International Socialist Party since he was a student in Portugal, ordered soldiers in Francisco's unit to carry out a gang torture-execution session on Silveiro Nungo. Let Francisco's words tell the story:

I say my officers take diabolic glee in flogging Nungo repeatedly for 12 hours. He was left overnight tied to a tree. The next day he was beaten again until unconscious. The third day after he regained consciousness, the most gruesome part followed. Nungo was dismembered, joint by joint, starting with his fingers, going up to the shoulders, Using crude machetes to do the hacking, Nungo died by mid-day.

I am ashamed to think that our Foreign Minister would not even think to raise such brutal human rights violations with Chissano, but instead lavished him with money. These atrocities are not isolated incidents. Francisco also described how he witnessed mass executions as well. Young Frelimo cadres returning from indoctrination camps in Russia and other Eastern bloc countries were secretly identified by their instructors as `converted communists' or as `unconverted'. The unconverted were met at the airport at Dar es Salaam with orders for `special missions'. They were then taken to a detention centre at Cabo Delgardo and executed by bayonet after first being sexually dismembered. Apparently that was a regular occurrence. The largest single massacre Francisco witnessed involved 120 individuals.

That is the sort of thing that is going on in Mozambique. The same Frelimo officials who presided over these barbaric massacres meet foreign aid delegations and Ministers in Maputo these days and spin the line that Mozambique is now moderate and moving away from Marxism and towards the West. Amazingly, some are believing it. The Australian Council for Overseas Aid believes it-it recently put out a brochure saying so. The trendy Left believes it. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation believes it. Even our Foreign Minister believes it. I happen to be one who has yet to be convinced. I spoke in this chamber some time ago of my visit to a refugee camp only last year at Phalaborwa in South Africa. Some 30,000 refugees had fled from Mozambique and passed through this camp. They told me of dreadful things the Frelimo Government had done both to their families and to their country. The trouble the Frelimo Government finds itself in is largely of its own making. However, they continue to blame everything and anyone but themselves. Any aid we give them, regrettably, is acting to prop up this corrupt regime. The Australian taxpayers would not approve of that if they were told these facts. I believe our efforts would be better directed towards putting pressure on the Frelimo regime to uphold the requests of the Renamo popular movement-namely, dismiss all foreign troops from the country and hold an internationally supervised general election.
