SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), and to oppose the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), I make the observation that the Appropriation Bills provide an opportunity for a wide-ranging debate, but they also provide an opportunity to review the Government's economic strategy and to contrast it with the economic proposals of the coalition. These economic proposals of the coalition can be divided into two basic categories: those who want to introduce a consumption tax and those who would like to but feel that it would be politically unpalatable. The driving force of the former is the extra-parliamentary leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott. John Elliott is an open admirer of Margaret Thatcher. He is a fervent advocate of privatisation. He is an international pedlar of the tired old myth that Australia is a high-taxing country. Last year he called on the Government to slash $6 billion in government spending as a tough economic medicine. This year's panacea is a cut in the company tax rate, financed by a consumption tax.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points should again be placed on the public record. Australia is not a high-taxing country. Our total tax burden is 30 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), compared with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average of 37 per cent. Our corporate tax rate is 2.8 per cent of GDP, compared with the OECD average of 3 per cent. Moreover, since the 1960s the contribution of the corporate sector to our overall taxation revenue has fallen sharply. In 1965 the corporate sector contributed 16 per cent of total tax revenue. By 1983 this had fallen to 8 per cent. That is a decline of something like 50 per cent in the course of two decades. What of the performance of Mr John Elliott's company, Elders-IXL? Elders-IXL's after-tax profit for the first half of the financial year to 31 December-that is, the current financial year-was $272m. This was an 83 per cent increase on the previous six months. Given the company tax rate of 49 per cent, Elders paid 11.64 per cent in 1986 and 10.4 per cent in 1987. According to Mr Elliott, however, we require a further redistribution from the poor to the rich. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has indicated in this House, for Australia to reduce its corporate tax rate to the level of that in Thatcher's Britain-that is, 35 per cent-a new additional consumption tax of about 5.8 per cent will have to be introduced.

In March last year Mr Elliott nominated a 7.5 per cent consumption tax as his preferred option. The reasons he offered at that time for the introduction of such a tax are worthy of further consideration. First, he contended that without a consumption tax we cannot achieve what he considers to be an ideal personal tax rate of 30 per cent, or 20 per cent for low income earners. Remembering that in this same interview Mr Elliott nominated a level of $5 billion or $6 billion worth of expenditure cuts to go part of the way towards achieving the same end, it is hardly surprising that the Opposition suffered an extreme lack of tax credibility at the last election. It is probably worth speculating what order of expenditure cuts would be required to reduce personal tax to those levels. It is also of note to refer to an article in today's Australian Financial Review-to which the Treasurer referred in Question Time-under the heading `BCA pushes for tougher cuts'. That article states:

The Business Council of Australia yesterday put pressure on the Government to make tougher cuts in the May mini-Budget, outlining a detailed series of spending reductions worth $3.5 billion across a broad spectrum of sensitive programs.
What was the Opposition's reaction to this proposal? The article states:
The shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, last night supported the thrust of the BCA submission but said it did not go far enough in cutting spending.

Let us consider some of the options for cuts as outlined in these proposals: tertiary education fees set at 10 per cent of the full cost of course; the phasing out of war veterans acute hospital facilities; tougher means testing of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, with a 50c levy on pensioner prescriptions; inclusion of the value of the family home in the aged pension assets test; a 6 per cent reduction in road funding; and more unspecified rapid reductions in Public Service staffing. That is not what one would call a politically appetising recipe for any form of economic salvation.

I return to the consumption tax. Mr Elliott's second reason for favouring a consumption tax was that tourists will have to pay that tax. Thirdly, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) arrangements whereby indirect taxes are deducted for the purposes of export, a clearly defined consumption tax would increase the competitiveness of Australian products overseas. This point takes no account of the fact that a consumption tax would send inflation through the roof, adding 6 or 7 percentage points overnight, at the very time when the Government's economic policies have begun to bring about a recovery in our competitiveness in terms of the current account deficit.

Finally, Mr Elliott says that a consumption tax would force `people who can minimise their personal tax legally, who are usually the wealthier people, to pay a larger share of the tax burden simply because they are the biggest spenders. For that reason, it is very equitable'. That is a remarkable position. A consumption tax is a pernicious tax in that it applies indiscriminately without any recognition of capacity to pay. What that means is that the consumer pays an additional 5 per cent to 7 per cent for all items, including the basic necessities of life, regardless of whether that consumer earns $15,000 or $50,000 per annum or, undoubtedly, a great deal more if the consumer happens to be Mr Elliott. By their very nature indirect taxes impact most severely on the poorest sections of the community. Therefore, it comes down to this: the Federal President of the Liberal Party, an international corporate baron, considers that it is equitable for average Australians to pay an extra 7.5 per cent on all items both to finance a tax cut for him personally and to ensure that his corporation pays less tax.

This is all the more perverse when considered in the context of Australia's existing low tax regime. John Elliott's stand has attracted wide support on the extreme fringe of the dark side of politics. In the Melbourne Herald of 6 April, for example, a letter from John J. Hay of the Australian Free Enterprise Foundation offered the wholehearted support of that organisation to `Mr John Elliott's call for a consumption tax' which it-the Free Enterprise Foundation-sees as `an integral part of a new, innovative taxation system. Such a program could include corporate tax of 30 per cent, personal tax of 20 per cent, plus a consumption tax on items classified as essential'.

What else did John Hay have to say? In addition to this economic blueprint for a utopia of the super rich, Mr Hay lists other policy objectives of his Foundation, including the elimination of land rights and the closure of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; a work for the dole scheme; the elimination of the fringe benefits tax; and the elimination of the policy of multiculturalism. It should be remembered that Mr Elliott himself is a vocal critic of the concept of multiculturalism. The Australian people should think long and hard before they allow the Elliott Liberal faction to get its hands on the economy; but neither should the Australian people believe that the Howard Liberal faction opposes a consumption tax.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is on record as supporting such a tax in the past. His current position is dictated purely by political opportunism. The recent decision of the Federal Liberal Council highlights that the door for the introduction of such a tax is wide open-but the public simply will not be told about it before an election. It is time the Opposition came clean on a number of points. Honourable members opposite talk incessantly about a flat, or flatter, personal tax regime as well as lower levels of corporate tax and the removal of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and so on. Without canvassing the merits or otherwise of these objectives, I point out that the Australian people have a right to know how they would be financed. Would it be by horrendous expenditure cuts, as instanced today by the Business Council of Australia? If so, what programs would be cut to fund this proposed windfall for the super rich? Where is the equity in any of these proposals? Will Thatcher's Britain provide the model for the wholesale dismantling of the welfare system, or is it to be financed by a new consumption tax, or perhaps by a combination of both? It should be stressed again that only last year John Elliott was calling for $5 billion to $6 billion worth of expenditure cuts and a 7.5 per cent consumption tax.

The Leader of the Opposition may succeed in the short term in stifling debate on these issues in the coalition but he cannot alter the public record. How long will it be before John Elliott proposes a poll tax such as that favoured by his much loved Thatcher Conservative Government, a tax under which property rating is replaced by a simple head count so that it matters little whether people live in a mansion in Higgins-an electorate in which Mr Elliott has some overt interest-or a Housing Commission home in Scullin; they pay a tax according to the size of the family, to finance a tax regime that benefits the rich. Let us dwell a little on Thatcher's Great Britain and the poll tax that will take effect from 1 April 1990. This proposal is based on a crude ideology. The Government's own Green Paper outlines that the proposal was conceived in the context of the `pressing need to reduce the burden which the public sector imposes on the private sector and on taxpayers'. The proposal is that domestic rates will be phased out over a 10-year period `and replaced by a flat rate community charge payable by all adults'. In its Economics Notebook, the Guardian of 28 September 1987, states:

It is the most ill-conceived tax this century. It is called a community charge rather than a poll tax because the last poll tax was introduced in the fourteenth century. It triggered a revolt and a mass exodus from the electoral roll resulting in actual destruction of the political `community'.

Perhaps it is warranted to note that as a result of the rebellion, both the Treasurer and the Commissioner for levying the tax were beheaded. The effects of the poll tax will be, to quote the Guardian further:

. . . to further reward Mrs Thatcher's own political base. There is an element of gerrymander about it since the poor people who will be tempted by reason of financial deprivation to evade the electoral register will be mainly people who do not vote conservative.

Mrs Thatcher's Conservative Government wants to drag Britain back to feudalism. Australia had not been discovered by Europeans when Britain struggled through the dark ages of absolutism but it seems that some of our citizens yearn for feudal government. After all it was Mr Elliott who stated in a recent speech in London:
I hope Australia gets with Thatcherism in the near future . . . good government needs strong leadership and limited democracy.

Mr Elliott undoubtedly sees himself as a benevolent despot. Opposition bickering over economic and taxation policy comes at a time when the economic outlook for Australia is the brightest it has been for some time. Many of the economic fundamentals are showing positive signs. Inflation is expected to fall significantly below 6 per cent and possibly below 5 per cent in the course of the 1988-89 financial year.

Seasonally adjusted employment rose by nearly 50,000 last month, a rise which boosted job growth in the first quarter of 1988 to 1.8 per cent. Annual job growth is running at 3.6 per cent, which means 250,000 additional jobs, and this includes a strong growth of 4.8 per cent in female employment. These figures lend confirmation to the downward trend in the unemployment rate from over 8 per cent to 7.4 per cent. This is the lowest figure in six years. The March figures represent the second successive month in which unemployment has fallen below 600,000 and compare favourably with the figure of 647,600 Australians who were out of work in March last year. Housing loan interest rates are now 2 per cent lower than at this time last year, and there is evidence of a further downward trend. The Australian Financial Review noted a few weeks back in an article headed `Rise in approvals signals continuing boom for housing':

The housing boom looks set to continue, with building approvals showing a strong upward trend in February . . . the strong figures for the housing sector reflect the unleashing of pent-up demand, fueled by record lending and recent falls in mortgage rates.

For the first time in several years in the run up to a major economic statement, the speculation is not over the size of the Government deficit but the size of the surplus. It is important to recall that this economic turnaround under Labor has been paid for largely by unprecedented wage restraint. I refer honourable members to a letter to the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday of last week in which Philip Lewis, senior lecturer in economics at the Curtin University of Technology, quoted a study undertaken by Michael Kirby and himself which estimated that real wages have been 10 per cent below what they would have been without the accord. The study credited the accord with helping to increase employment by about 8 per cent or 600,000 jobs, so it can be seen that the economic turnaround has been paid for largely by workers through the trade union movement under the accord.

It is time for those who have sacrificed to reap some of the benefits. Perhaps it is time that the belts were loosened. Wages must keep pace with inflation to ensure that living standards are maintained, even improved, and the objectives of fighting rising poverty and inequality and achieving greater social justice should now take priority in any discussion of a surplus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On hearing the previous speaker, the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), I wonder what is the Government's position on economic and tax matters. The honourable member spent most of his speech criticising the Opposition's positive proposals for the Australian people and gave no support for the Government's position. However, as the Hawke Government moves towards yet another May mini-Budget statement, which will most likely incorporate and consolidate further tax raising measures, it can be seen that this will be done with a backdrop of a national debt in excess of $110 billion and current balance of payments figures indicating an annual deficit of $13.6 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has pointed out on numerous occasions in the past few months, it now takes 64c of every export dollar to pay the interest on this huge overseas debt. When the Hawke Government came to power in 1983, only 23c in each export dollar was required to service our overseas commitments. With this disturbing background of an economic performance of disastrous proportions, indicators published in the Budget Monitor of February 1988, by ACIL Australia, show that the Commonwealth Budget is likely to record a surplus of $1 billion in 1987-88 and a $2.5 billion dollar surplus in 1988-89. These predictions are made on a no policy change basis. However, they confirm the people of Australia's suspicions that the Labor Government is extracting the last cent of every taxable dollar from each individual.

Australians are painfully aware of the impact of bracket-creep as their salaries and wages increase. The Budget Monitor indicates that total taxation revenue is expected to grow by 10.1 per cent this year and 9.1 per cent in 1988-89. The projected inflation rate for 1987-88 is 8.3 per cent and the Government is hoping for a figure of 6.5 to 7 per cent in 1988-89. Australians faced with the tax rip-off by the Federal Government created by bracket creep, compare it with accepted inflation rates and are rebelling against the Hawke Labor Government.

Not only has their standard of living dropped but they now have less money in their pockets after they have paid their income tax and other hidden charges. Over 51 per cent of the Federal Government's revenue is raised by the downtrodden pay as you earn taxpayers. These beleaguered middle income earners bear the burden of raising ever-increasing revenue requirements. While incentive and effort is being penalised under this tax regime, the insidious attack upon individual taxpayers goes on against a background of demands by business for company taxation rates to fall in line with international counterparts.

Investment in Australia is retarded by our excessively high company tax rate of 49c in the dollar. International investors are not encouraged to place their money with Australian companies when they compare the alternative tax rates offering: 39 per cent in the United States; 45 per cent in Japan; 48 per cent in Malaysia; 33 per cent in Singapore; 25 per cent in Taiwan; 18 per cent in Hong Kong; 44 per cent in South Korea; and now 28 per cent in New Zealand. Margaret Thatcher has led the way in the tax debate and, in her recent Budget she not only held company tax rates at 35 per cent but she reduced personal income tax rates to 40 per cent for the higher income group and 25 per cent for the middle income earners.

The Thatcher Government has been utterly determined to reduce the level of direct tax for individuals. Having achieved this objective, a revolutionary change in attitude is apparent. English men and women are keener to work hard and achieve a better standard of living for themselves and their families. Along with taxation incentives, the Thatcher Government has created a nation of capitalists by its successful program of enabling workers to become shareholders in their own enterprises as well as making it possible for them to purchase their own houses. By innovative tax reform and creating incentive, the Thatcher Government has turned the English nation around from a debt-ridden, poverty-stricken country to a nation which not only is increasing its standard of living but also is now a banker to the world.

At a time when other Western nations are lowering their tax rates and simplifying their tax systems, Australia, under the Hawke Labor Government, is adding taxes to the statute book. In the Government's haste to reform the Australian tax system and increase government revenue, it has forced through legislation which is incomprehensible, incomplete, and proving to be a goldmine for tax lawyers and accountants. I need hardly remind the House of the utter chaos the fringe benefits tax legislation created for employers and small businessmen. It was a sad joke that the Government had to reissue instructions time and again, and waste taxpayers' money even further, before it got it anywhere near right, if it ever will, for the final interpretation is not yet clear.

In the desire of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to implement the quarterly instalment system for provisional tax, the administrative and technical requirements of the Australian Taxation Office are giving tax agents enduring headaches. The provisional tax quarterly instalment payment system provides that payments are made in September, December and March, with a final adjustment being made in June. This results in adjusted figures being paid in March and a further adjusted figure being paid in June. This creates difficulties in trying to explain to taxpayers how much tax they have paid and what their final assessment will be in June. Accountants around Australia are suggesting that there would be mutual advantage to the Taxation Office and taxpayers if the final provisional tax payments were made in March each year. This would set the scene for finalising taxpayers' liabilities in June each year.

I now wish to draw the attention of the House to the capital gains tax. This tax has been incorporated into the Government's tax policy against the better judgment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), if we can believe his earlier statements, the Treasurer, and Taxation Office officials. It was a pay-off to the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. The Prime Minister campaigned strongly on the issue that there would be no capital gains tax and yet when the pressure of the left wing in the parliamentary Party and the Party machine were brought to bear, he crumbled. The Prime Minister went to unusual lengths to put his position on the record. And although he seems to be suffering from political amnesia these days over exactly what he did say during the July election campaign, let me remind honourable members of his exact words. In his election speech on 16 February, 1983, he said:
. . . let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.''
We now have in place a complicated, unworkable piece of legislation which will raise very little revenue.

Capital gains tax fails on every count. Any new form of tax should be judged against the five canons of taxation: simplicity, administration, equity, efficiency and revenue. In fulfilling the first canon-simplicity-legislators throughout the world have had great difficulty in framing laws for capital gains tax that both the Taxation Office and taxpayer can understand. Capital gains tax legislation in Australia is no exception. Tax accountants, tax lawyers, and even the Australian Tax Office itself, are unable to interpret some clauses in the capital gains tax act.

Again, as in the second canon, the administration of the capital gains tax Act will be a nightmare. The cut-off point of 19 September 1985 has helped in the problems of valuing assets as a benchmark to establish future capital gains. On examination, however, the establishment of the value of assets will prove to be a matter of great argument and litigation between the taxpayer and the Tax Office. For instance, the exact value of share issues, options, and bonus share issues will be a matter of dispute when the Commissioner assesses capital gains tax at a time distant from the issue of such shares. The taxpayer is being asked to keep minute records which she or he could have difficulty in substantiating some five or 10 years on. Hopefully this will not arise. And why not? Because a Howard-led government will abolish capital gains tax.

We come to the third canon-equity. Capital gains tax will fall upon those who are least prepared to pay it. The Prime Minister's own admission that there are `unintended consequences' demonstrates that the Government is aware that the legislation contains inequities. Mr Matt Walsh, a partner in the national law firm, Mallesons Stephen Jaques, confirmed the difficulties facing taxpayers in interpreting the capital gains legislation. In addressing a conference organised by the Taxation Institute of Australia, Mr Walsh said:
. . . the capital gains tax has brought confusion and headaches to the business world because of lack of clarity and ambiguities in the drafting of the legislation.
He went on to say:
No other tax in modern times has had such a dramatic effect on business and business organisations.

Mr Walsh focused on capital gains tax mainly in the field of acquisitions and mergers. He drew the contrast between Mr Hawke's undertaking to provide a tax regime that everyone would understand and the complicated legislation that no-one seems able to comprehend, tax advisers included.

World experience indicates considerable difficulties in collecting revenue from capital gains tax efficiently. The law is complex and with various offsets and provisions of capital gains tax, some governments have questioned whether the revenue gain has been worth the effort. In Australia, there will need to be a new battalion of public servants to administer and interpret capital gains tax liabilities.

The fifth and final canon of taxation states that revenue should be substantial, given that the other criteria have been followed. The Hawke-Keating Government cannot even justify the capital gains tax on a revenue basis. At the 1985 Tax Summit, Treasurer Keating forecast a figure of $25m as the likely yield from capital gains tax raised in the first year, rising to a modest $100m in the fourth or fifth years. However, the 1987-88 Budget Papers estimate it will raise revenue of between $50m and $100m. Budget Paper No. 1 admits:
There is, as yet, considerable uncertainty as to the extent of realised capital gains on which capital gains tax is to be paid in 1987-88.

The Budget Papers estimate that these gains would be `based principally on substantial past increases in sharemarket prices'. These guesstimate figures are incorporated in fine print in an addendum to the Budget Papers which further adds to the belief that Treasury has no real idea of the revenue from capital gains tax, either in the short term sharemarket boom conditions or in the longer term. Not only does this Government's capital gains tax not adhere to the five canons of good taxation practice, but also it is, in itself, a double taxation measure. Australian taxpayers pay high rates of income tax, and having accumulated some capital, are being hit yet again if they realise one form of capital investment in order to reinvest or rearrange their financial affairs or sell an asset. Australians pay one of the highest marginal rates of income tax in the world. As if that is not bad enough, this same high rate of 49c in the dollar is applied to capital gains.

I wish to refer to two other major aspects of this iniquitous tax which make it a problem for Australians. Currently the tax is indexed for inflation. At least this measure ensures that real gains are being taxed, rather than an extra tax being levied on inflation. While this seems obvious, other nations have used the tax without the indexation component. In England there has been a capital gains tax since 1965. In the 1976 Budget the Labour Chancellor, Mr Healey, declined to index the tax. He argued:

. . . insulation against inflation could not logically be confined to capital gains taxpayers; if they enjoyed it, in principle inflation-proofing ought to extend to holders of building society and savings bank deposits. But we cannot afford to go down this road.

In 1982, Sir Geoffrey Howe, Prime Minister Thatcher's then Chancellor of the Exchequer, introduced indexation of capital gains tax. This proves the point that indexation can be imposed or removed at the whim of the Treasurer of the day. We have no guarantee whatsoever that either the current Treasurer or any future Labor government would not remove this vital buffer against inflation.

Principal dwellings are exempt from capital gains. Because of the political pressures in the electorate, even the left wing of the Labor Party was not prepared to place a tax on the family home. There is absolutely no logic in this and all this exemption achieves is an extraordinary boom in real estate values. The real irony is that supporters of the Labor Party are now being disadvantaged. The Australian dream of owning a home is quickly becoming an impossibility. It is an outrageous distortion of the market that Susan Renouf's house sold for a reported $19.2m. Obviously Sir Frank will not have to pay capital gains tax on a house which he claimed as his principal residence, on which he made about 150 per cent profit, and which he owned for less than three years. It would appear from Press reports that the Renoufs did live there from time to time. Although behind Sydney, Melbourne residential real estate values have soared, with a recent sale of a residential establishment for $7.5m topping the market. Those who have had their fingers burnt in the share market are investing in residential property which gives them an obviously favourable tax position.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 20 per cent exemption on the sale of business goodwill on a business worth less than $1m is at least an acknowledgment that a capital gains tax is a disincentive to enterprise and hard work. Goodwill is built up by years of hard work. As any entrepreneur will know, very often one starts with nothing and builds up an enterprise worth thousands of dollars. The impact of a capital gains tax on goodwill is disastrous because of the no value base on which the tax is calculated.

SPEECH.PARA: In the latest issue of the Australian Director, Mr Michael Inglis, a Sydney barrister who specialises in tax advising and who has written a book, Australian Capital Gains Tax, is critical of the use of taxation rulings to implement this tax and, in particular, the ruling on goodwill. Tax accountants tend to treat the taxation rulings as gospel, but this is not necessarily so. Mr Inglis points out in his article that tax ruling No. 1 clearly states that `in using taxation rulings it should be recognised that they cannot supplant the terms of the law'. He criticises the Taxation Office's interpretation of when the goodwill was acquired for the purposes of capital gains tax. Mr Inglis says:
Broadly stated, a capital gain arises when the gross proceeds of a sale exceed the cost base, as appropriate, of the asset to the taxpayer.
He went on to say:
In the goodwill context, it is proving virtually impossible to establish any cost, or indexed cost base, where the goodwill was not purchased from a third party.
That is to say, where the taxpayers:

. . . acquired the relevant goodwill, by founding the relevant business, there is virtually nothing that can be used to establish a cost base or indexed cost base for the goodwill. In particular, the `blood, sweat and tears' associated with the establishment and nurturing of a profitable enterprise, are irrelevant for the purposes of Capital Gains Tax computations.

Australians who purchase farms, small businesses, shares and property after 19 September 1985 will be facing the prospect of a de facto death duty through capital gains legislation. It would appear from learned legal interpretation that the cost base of these acquisitions is deemed to be the purchase cost for capital gains tax calculations, even though the assets are passed to executors, who in turn, transfer the assets to beneficiaries.

Probate duty was removed by the Fraser Government in 1980. Consequently, Australians faced death, confident that all they had worked for all their lives would pass to their families or designated beneficiaries. They could die happy in the knowledge that the Government would not force a dispersal of their enterprises, farms or whatever, through iniquitous death duties. Now they are being forced to reassess their position very carefully, otherwise Mr Hawke's `unintended consequences' could see their life's work dissolve.

Honourable members may be interested to know that taxation rulings in the life of the Hawke Government number 2,349 in volume No. 1 alone. Volume 2 is already up to 2,460, and there have been numerous miscellaneous rulings as well. The tax Act has increased from 1,100 pages to approximately 1,700 pages. The Treasurer's bent for inflation has spread to the tax Act, quite literally. Tax professionals are hard pressed to keep up with the shifting sands of the Hawke-Keating tax policy.

There is no sound, logical argument to support a capital gains tax which is a positive deterrent to overseas investors at a time when Australia should be encouraging as much investment as possible. The coalition is totally against the capital gains tax and will throw it out lock, stock and barrel. Unlike the Hawke Labor Government which has allowed, even encouraged, bracket creep, and boasts of increasing wages while at the same time grabbing a bigger tax take, the coalition is undertaking a total review of direct and indirect taxation to reduce the burden on individual taxpayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.
