SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to speak about railways. As most people would be well aware, my electorate of Grey has a close relationship with railways. For the last 100 years, railways have provided the backbone for development not only in my electorate but in Australia. They still provide the backbone for the economy of my electorate. I know that railways in Australia have been allowed to fall into bad practices. From the early 1950s they began to decline through competition from road transport and air travel and the failure of railway managements universally to adapt to the tremendous economic changes that have taken place. Clocks simply stopped. Steam age management remained, as did steam age technology. Today, the State railway systems, in New South Wales and Victoria in particular, are draining the taxpayers' pockets at a ridiculous rate and governments are denied the opportunity to invest money in productive railway enterprises.

Things are changing slowly in some areas but, fortunately, quickly in others. Australian National (AN) is a magnificent exception, though, I understand, Westrail has made great improvements, too. I must say that fair dinkum improvements have been made. In this competitive world, it is very important that public enterprises like railways become competitive. The people involved in Australian National have really seized the opportunity to make the operation a glowing example to the other railway systems of the States which have used freight operations to cross-subsidise all of their inefficiencies.

With much of the Australian National network in my electorate and the location of the workshops in Port Augusta, I am only too aware of the pain that is involved in dragging a railway system into the twentieth century. Under conservative governments, Commonwealth Railways, as it was known, was allowed to languish. No attempt was made to invest in new technology or to address seriously the issues of inefficiency and productivity. That was too hard. This Government, though, has done it and the results speak for themselves.

Let us look at the record since 1983. In little more than five years, Australian National has improved its financial position by 60 per cent. In real terms, its current revenue supplement is $54.9m against $106m in 1982-83. It is expected to break even on its commercial services in the next financial year and is aiming at a cost recovery target of 60 per cent on passenger services. That has involved many difficult decisions. It has required much adjustment involving management, employees and unions. It has also caused some personal disruption. As a local member I know that only too well. However, if the hard decisions had not been made, Australian National would not have become the organisation it is today. All railway people deserve credit for the way in which they have supported Australian National. If there is one great loyalty railway people always have had, it is to their railway.

It is too easy to take things for granted. No matter how realistic one tries to be, self-interest always surfaces first. For those Australian National employees being transferred to different jobs, with different skill requirements in different locations it is distressing, and understandably so. I say as a reminder to AN management that personnel management skills, sensitivity and understanding are too often lacking. We are dealing with hardworking committed railway people and they deserve better treatment. They need to be kept informed of change and helped to understand it. If that does not occur, they will resent it, and an unhappy worker is an unproductive one.

I will be taking up this very important matter with the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris). I know from his record that he will see that people are treated fairly and with dignity. More and more every day it is brought to my attention that management says to workers, `Next week you will be transferred to Adelaide', or, `You will become redundant', and so on, without any consultation or discussion of what will happen to them and their families in the future. That is very distressing. In this day and age it is appalling that Australian National management does not have the nous to have discussions with AN employees before some of these tough decisions are taken. I call on the Minister to intervene in situations where communication has broken down between management and employees and management is not meeting its side of the agreement to seek rapport with workers.

Let me return to this Government's record on railways, particularly Australian National. This year alone, more of the $18.7m provided over four years for non-interest bearing loans will be made available so that the Islington workshops can be modernised for more efficient operations and a safer working environment. That is a proper investment, bringing newer technology and higher productivity to the railway. It will bring the railway, at last, out of the steam age-replacing old workshops equipped to maintain steam age rolling stock. Another $1m is being provided over the next two years to fund the upgrading of the Adelaide-Alice Springs piggyback service for trucks-a real winner since it started. The Government ought to be applauded for that constructive step, which has opened up markets to the north.

Looking back over the last five years, there are good examples of the investment behind AN's improved performance. For example, since 1983 we have provided $24.6m to Tasrail for rehabilitation of the track in that State-an investment that has transformed that system into one which I understand is now capable of rescue, instead of the graveyard to which the Fraser Government directed it. In 1984-85 this Government invested $2.3m in the piggyback facilities in Adelaide for the Adelaide-Alice Springs route. I have already referred to that more recent addition. Also in 1984-85, $16m was invested to assist an early retirement scheme which had huge flow-on effects within AN. In total 850 employees took the chance and thereby helped AN improve its efficiency.

Australian National has supplemented this record with its own earnings, which would not have been possible without the substantial investment previously made by the Government. More recently, in late 1987, AN instituted a further early retirement scheme of its own which realised another 335 retirements. In a similar vein, Australian National has also invested heavily in new technology. Last week it was announced that $19m would be made available for a new fibre optics system and $34m for a new DL locomotive construction program. The first locomotive, appropriately named the Peter Morris, was handed over in Adelaide last Wednesday by Clyde Industries, which is in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons). This is a fantastic turnabout for AN, and I must say that the sight of the bright green and gold colours is very heartening.

Of course, there are problems in all of this and I have already referred to them. However, I am confident that, with the continuation of the sound management of this Government, AN will continue to improve. Of course, it takes more than an investment of cash; it also needs the investment of goodwill and good management. Hopefully, one day we will see Australian National as the core of a coast to coast freight network. We said before the last election that in our next term of government we would begin work on the plan to negotiate running rights for interstate tracks. Already negotiations are well advanced with Westrail. For places such as Port Augusta and for this nation's economic infrastructure, this is a vital issue. Our railways were great once; they can be again. They have a very real role to play in an efficient transport mode, doing what they do best-carrying heavy freight over long distances. But they must be given a chance. They need more good management, which they will not get from the nincompoops opposite.

As this is a broad-ranging debate, I will turn to a couple of other issues. I am pleased to see in the appropriations for 1987-88 an allocation of $5.3m for marriage guidance counselling. This represents an increase of 9 per cent. Whilst this is a significant increase in a tight budgetary situation and the Government is to be applauded for giving marriage guidance counselling a priority, much more money is required to finance an adequate counselling service. Undoubtedly, there is a strong recognition by the Government that marriage guidance counselling is of great service, not only for young couples contemplating marriage but also for a large number of Australians trying to retain existing marriages.

Marriage guidance counselling is basically carried out by a group of dedicated people on a voluntary basis who realise the importance of retaining the family unit and the necessity of marriages being retained on a solid, loving basis. The costs incurred are of an administrative nature, involving telephone charges, office rental and general clerical costs. I know that, in my electorate of Grey, various church leaders take their marriage guidance counselling very seriously and do a tremendous job. I am very pleased that this Government has seen fit to increase funding to a variety of counselling services. I trust that in the future much more money will be made available for the necessary and important service of marriage guidance counselling.

I conclude by referring to the first home owners scheme, a subject on which the honourable member for Corangamite gave us a bucketing when he spoke last. In my electorate, the first home owners scheme has helped over 1,300 families to purchase their own homes. The latest figures show that 1,387 applications for a first home owners grant have been successful in Grey, representing $5.06m in Commonwealth grants since October 1983. Of the total applications received in Grey, 89 per cent have been approved. That is an exceptionally high figure. Since its inception in October 1983, over 24,700 South Australians have received assistance, representing some $107.8m in approved Commonwealth grants. The first home owners scheme assists low to middle income earners to purchase their first home by providing a grant of up to $6,000 over five years. Last year the Federal Government raised the income qualifying limit to $34,000 per annum go give middle income earners a greater chance to qualify for the grant. The first home owners scheme has proved to be an outstanding success in assisting Australian families to purchase their own home. Many of the successful applicants in South Australia have been able to escape the rental trap and move into their own home. The scheme has turned the dream of home ownership into a reality for many Australians. The scheme also plays an important role in stimulating activity and employment in the building industry. I certainly hope that that answers some of the negative comments that are coming from the other side regarding our first home owners scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commencing my remarks on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, which I want to confine primarily to the health vote, I would like to respond to the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) by giving him some examples of the problems that maybe the Westrail system has not yet resolved. I own a farming property about 100 miles from a port in Western Australia. With 50 gallons of fuel and a relatively old truck, I can shift 40 tonnes of wheat legally in each trip. To pay Westrail to do the same job would cost me $500. We must wonder why it is now managing to balance its books. The principal contributors to that are, of course, the wheatgrowers and some miners in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I made a submission to the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport on behalf of my constituents. I pointed out that in Western Australia 1,200 tonnes of grain is shifted for every kilometre of railway line laid, yet in the Pilbara 80,000 tonnes of iron ore is shifted per kilometre of track laid. As much as we might like to defend our railways, it is time we asked ourselves, irrespective of the efficiencies achieved, whether that very low freight level on many of the lines within Australia can be tolerated in terms of capital investment, when in fact we generally build a bitumen road alongside them. Bitumen roads are constructed out of a very small proportion of the total taxes paid by road users. On a number of occasions I have brought this House's attention to the fact that owner-driver truckies pay about 30 per cent of their revenues in one tax or another.

It is interesting to note that in the second reading speech on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) states that these additional appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget as well as requirements of an ongoing nature. In other words, these are appropriations for additional expenditure by Government to that which was generally brought to the notice of the Parliament in the Budget.

With my responsibility, I wish to talk particularly about health. There are some interesting figures. The health budget is mentioned in both Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). In Appropriation Bill (No. 4) we find that plant and equipment is mentioned and there is an additional allocation of $5,100,000 for computer equipment. That is something that is now becoming of grave concern to many people in the community. Naturally, an organisation such as Medicare, which is where most of that computer equipment would be going, needs that. It has now become the means by which the Government stores information and many people are deeply concerned at the allegations of certain people as to how that is being used. I might come back to that point later.

Item 08 refers to the Health Insurance Act 1973 and an additional $11,278,000 in Medicare grants. This is quite surprising because the responsible Minister and I have been having a sort of contest through the Press Gallery with Press releases-none of which is being published in more recent times-throwing allegations at each other as to who has got it right in terms of the additional money being spent by the Government in the arena of health. The facts are that this year the Medicare levy, according to the Budget Papers, will raise $2,065m, whereas according to the previous Budget Paper, the Government proposes to spend $5,212m on Medicare related expenditures. That is not a levy of 1.25 per cent; the expenditure is equivalent to a levy of 3.15 per cent.

If we look at the statement of cumulative outlays until the end of February put out by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), we find that things are getting worse. The Minister for Finance tells us that the cumulative outlays to February 1987 were $5,012m in the health arena whereas for this year, to February 1988, they are $5,894m, an increase of over $800m. This is an increase in percentage terms of 17.6 per cent when in fact, as these documents tell us, the Budget allowed only an increase of 9.5 per cent. When that has worked its way through the system by the end of the year, it could be argued-especially as the same document points out that growth in medical services and benefits, the principal activity of Medicare, has grown from $2,139.7m to $2,624.3m-that that is a growth of 22.6 per cent instead of the 8.8 per cent predicted in the Budget. No wonder the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) was sent to try to make a case against doctors when that sort of expenditure is confronting the community in terms of taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. The honourable member for O'Connor has just made an allegation against me which is totally untrue and I ask him to withdraw it.
—It was not unparliamentary, and that is the point--
—It was untrue.
—The honourable member for Canning has made his point. I think he might be a little touchy.

—In regard to this particular issue, we are looking at costs and outlays. The Minister put out one Press release telling us that I had overlooked-and that I was so foolish as not to be able to read it in this document provided to us as a Press release from the Minister for Finance-that somewhere in there there is an additional payment for the month of March. I think he said that it was on page 3. Let me inform the Parliament that I have checked the document as closely as I can and I cannot find the additional payment. I ask why the Minister for Finance-considering the accuracy of his particular Department-would bother to give me a document that says `cumulative outlays to February 1988' if in one case an outlay for March is included. There is nothing within these documents that indicates that. The Minister might then answer why we would be paying to that particular organisation a month in advance other than that it might be having some financial difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: The more important thing about that area of expenditure is that we are now questioning what the public is getting for its money. For a long time, irrespective of the type of health program and health services program that is provided in the country, Australians go on spending about 7.6 per cent of gross domestic product on health. A socialist government comes along and decides that only the Government can provide it properly and cheaply and it makes those sorts of claims. Then conservative governments come along and try to return the spending power to the people. But the whole thing is that the cost is roughly the same. We really have to decide what is the level of service.

It is an interesting thing to note that all the major newspapers and magazines in recent times are wanting to write about health, and there is a good reason for that. They, like political parties in this day and age, do polling, and their polls are telling them that people are becoming more and more concerned about health delivery in the community and that generally they are grossly dissatisfied with the service they are receiving from Medicare. All sorts of people get the blame for the fact that in Victoria-by admission of the Premier, a man who is sufficiently honest to admit it-we have nearly 29,000 people on waiting lists. That is probably a conservative figure, as was discovered with the new computer program in South Australia recently where it was thought that 6,000 people were on waiting lists, and when the matter was properly recorded it was found that an additional 1,000 people were on waiting lists. These people are not waiting so that they can have a facelift or some moderate form of medical treatment in a hospital. Many of them are waiting to have treated quite severe illnesses, pain, suffering and blindness. A lady wrote to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) the other day and chose to send me a copy of the letter. She is under 60 years of age, has rapidly advancing cateracts of the eye and, to use her words, `has been told to grope around in the dark for another two years' until late 1989 before the Medicare system, which, as she said, she trusted the Government to deliver, can assist her. I could go on.

As a result of my shadow portfolio responsibility, the other day I attended a conference in Sydney. The keynote speaker was Dame Dorothy Fraser, a woman highly regarded in health administration circles in New Zealand and a person consequently selected by the Labour Government there to be one of the three persons, I think, on the Gibbs inquiry looking into that hospital system-and they have produced the Gibbs report. I read from page 5 of her prepared address, which was made available to me:
The public would identify access as the greatest failing of the present system-
she is talking about the New Zealand system-

Unless you are an accident victim, covered by Accident Compensation or develop an acute condition such as cancer, you join the 50,000 people on waiting lists who need hospitalisation. Waiting lists vary between regions and according to the operation. On average last year the waiting time for hip replacements, kidney stones, cataracts, heart by-pass operations, and osteoarthritis, was at least two years.

Has anyone in this place heard those sorts of words recently here in Australia? That sounds exactly like what is happening here. Almost as many people are waiting for outpatient appointments. She went on to say:

The New Zealand public hospital system uses waiting lists to ration its services and encounters great difficulty in determining patients' priorities. It tends to respond to pressure from patients, family doctors, politicians or the media rather than develop criteria for priority. Uncomplaining, less articulate and poorer members of society tend to gravitate to the end of queues.

That is the Australian health system today in a nutshell. It has been said about New Zealand. It is a perfect example of what is happening here. Let me repeat the honesty of that lady. It was not for New Zealand to try to blame the doctors, the greed of doctors, the lack of nurses-and let us agree that it probably has all the same problems as we have; New Zealand said that its public hospital system uses waiting lists to ration its services. That is what is happening here in Australia because the Government made a promise it could not keep, to give everybody free, universal health cover-and it is not working. Strangely enough, the people whom this Government claims as its constituency are the ones that Dame Dorothy Fraser refers to-uncomplaining, less articulate, the poorer members of society. They tend to gravitate to the end of the queues.

This Government has done to them exactly what it promised to lift them out of. When they were the so-called two million uninsured they at least could get into hospital. The reality is that they can do so no longer. We have two classes of Australians established under the Medicare system. We have those who can afford to pay their levy and to take out top private cover. They have immediate access to some 9,000 empty private hospital beds and they are being welcomed by that sector, which is desperate for their business. All the rest of the people, even those on basic private cover, are obliged to get on to hospital waiting lists. If they happen to be some of those people who do not know the system well enough, they are in trouble.

The Medicare card is an insult to the national colours because it is not delivered for Australians and, what is more, it is labelling people as poor and undeserving, telling them to wait. I said the other day that it should be coloured red. Red is the sign for stop and wait. And the most disconcerting thing that strikes me at the moment is the frequent examples coming forward of people borrowing money, either elderly people on their own behalf, or their children, with their own family problems, to ensure that their elderly parents get certain operations. If honourable members do not think it is true they should ask the Commonwealth car drivers, who will give an example of one of their members who has just been obliged to do that.

When the Minister said the other day, `I have one of these Medicare cards and it does not label me poor', he was absolutely right. He happens to be of the new socialist elite. He is not one of those uncomplaining, less articulate and poorer members of society. Just as occurs in communist countries, he is one of those people, irrespective of his own efforts, who will get wonderful service from Medicare, just as other members of the Cabinet have received amazing service-wives have been attended to by doctors of their choice and have had private rooms for serious operations. I do not say this was organised by the Minister: it just happens. And, of course, it shunts a few more poorer people down the queue.

Frequently, when I read these letters-and they are usually copies of those addressed to Minister Blewett, and they come to me day after day-my first impression is: I must do something for this person. I must go out and try to help him. Then I constrain myself because I know that if I push that person up the queue, as I may be able to, I push some other person back down. If that is what those opposite want from the health system they should keep this up. But it is not what I want for the health system and as the next Minister I will not tolerate the present situation. It is not all costs; it is the fact that people are getting very bad service for their money. It is time that people took note of that.

There is another aspect. It was mentioned in these documents today that we are buying some more computers. I talked about the problems of people's privacy. That has resurfaced today, with the opinion of Mr Temby that the actions of the Minister were not a breach of section 130. It is time that people cast their minds back to 1973 when the current Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) brought to this Parliament the original health insurance legislation. He told this Parliament:

The Government will insist that complete confidentiality regarding individual patients and doctors is maintained by the Commission. The information required for the processing of claims will be less than is now required by private health insurance funds. A special committee has been established by the Government to recommend steps necessary to guarantee the privacy of individuals.
What is more, I have that committee's report and the terms of reference. At one stage the report points out:

The Terms of Reference were amended by the deletion of the underlined words `medical and hospital' to put beyond doubt that the Committee's work might extend to cover the possible invasion of the privacy of the medical practitioner.

That was the intent of section 130. When we read the recommendations we find them translated into law. Now the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) has told us that apparently that legislation is badly flawed. Legislation we have relied on since 1973 to protect the privacy of all those people is flawed. He tells us that the Minister is not guilty because he is not an officer as defined in the legislation and nor are members of his staff. The implication of his opinion is that as long as one can get an officer of the Department to provide, in the course of his normal duties, confidential information to the Minister's office, and not know where it is going, that is legal and because these other people, in the terms of the Director of Public Prosecutions, are not officers, they are not bound by that law and they can pass that information on to anyone else. I bet that was not the intention of the legislators in 1973 but that is the statement made by the Director of Public Prosecutions. That is the basis on which he says:
In slightly expanded form, for the reasons that follow, my conclusions are that:
(a) Section 130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973 relates only to officers as defined in the Act.

He goes on to say that the Minister and his staff are not officers and therefore cannot be blamed for handing stuff out to the newspapers. I ask the House: if that is the case, are we to be confronted again with an example such as the one we protested about today in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade where anybody who chooses to criticise this Government can have information released through this loophole in the law? The DPP does not bother to say to us that he thinks that this loophole should be closed. He seems more inclined to devote a whole paragraph to the different prices that doctors charge. I still cannot see what that had to do with his opinion.

Let me say to honourable members beyond any doubt that if we are going to have a situation in which journalists and others can be threatened with the release of their private medical information because this Government, with the assistance of the Director of Public Prosecutions, has found a loophole, that is a scandalous situation for Australia and one that cannot be tolerated. It is another excellent reason why we do not need Medicare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) claim that he was going to talk tonight about his responsibility in his shadow portfolio of health. However, for 20 minutes he did nothing but knock Medicare. He did not tell us even briefly what his health policy is. Are we going to go back to the time when two million Australians were not covered by health insurance? Is that his policy? Is he going to introduce compulsory health insurance? Is he going to drive Australian families into the clutches of private insurers and rip them off for thousands of dollars every year? Is that his policy? We have seen his act. It will be a long time before he will have the opportunity to carry out such a policy.

SPEECH.PARA: However, tonight I would like to speak to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. I would like to ask whether our parliamentary system deserves the expenditure allocated to it. It is well known that, while the parliamentary system is still respected by the public, we, the members of parliament-the essential and integral part of such a system-are not regarded very highly, to say the least. It is as though the Australian public at large could sense that we are not part of the important decision making process in our society. I applaud the insight of the intuition of the ordinary Australians who somehow discern that our importance as member of parliament is very peripheral to the decision making in our system of so-called two-party democracy or the Westminster system.

When I was first elected to this House I had the same opinion as any average Australian about the importance or otherwise of the Parliament. I respected some individual members and senators, while having a less than high opinion of politicians as a whole. In general, I was slightly sceptical about the decision making power of the Parliament. However, the air of self-importance assumed by many of my colleagues quickly confused me into thinking that my initial belief and scepticism may have been wrong.

For a while, as I was sucked into the daily parliamentary routine, I had no time to reflect on how the system operated. The daily routine of any parliamentarian consists of so much work that it keeps one not only out of mischief but also away from politics. The policy formulation of my Party which was so important to me as an ordinary party member became somehow more remote once I became a parliamentarian. In the routine policy committee meetings which more often than not avoid even a mention of policies, let alone recommend or insist on their implementation, policy formulation is lost. As time went on I became more and more aware that decision making is not only not vested in the Parliament, but also is not vested in the Cabinet. It is vested only in the Establishment. The established order itself is through the bureaucracy; its tool, the media-through which it creates public opinion-guides the Government to arrive at the desired decisions. If a government does not toe the line, we only have to look at what happened in 1975 to see what results.

I am trying in a few sentences to express my opinion about the political system. I know how inadequate my eloquence is to try to explain in a simple way a complex and complicated system of checks and balances needed to preserve the status quo. My thoughts on the subject have been so much better expressed by a British playwright and literary genius, George Bernard Shaw, through Colonel Undershaft in Major Barbara, who said:

The Government of your country! I am the government of your country. Do you suppose that you and half a dozen amateurs like you, sitting in a row in that foolish gabble shop, can govern us? No, my friend: you will do what pays us. You will make war when it suits us, and keep peace when it doesn't. You will find out that trade requires certain measures. When we have decided on those measures. When I want anything to keep my dividends up, you will discover that my want is a national need. When other people want something to keep my dividends down, you will call out the police and military. And in return, you shall have the support and applause of my newspapers, and the delight of imagining that you are a great statesman.

Government of your country! Be off with you . . . and play with your caucuses and leading articles and historic parties and great leaders and burning questions and the rest of your toys. I am going back to my counting-house to pay the piper and call the tune.

While I pride myself that my perception is as good as Bernard Shaw's, I admit that I lack the talent to express myself so clearly, simply and beautifully. Having professed the views that I have, one could rightly ask me what I am doing in the Parliament, having so little faith in the institution. My answer to that question is that while I am aware and conscious of the imperfection of the parliamentary democracy, nonetheless I consider it still the best political system put into practice anywhere in the world up to this stage of human history. With all its imperfections, the Westminster system allows public scrutiny and public debate of Executive decisions, wherever they are made. That system allows me, a back bench member, to criticise publicly the decisions of the Executive, and criticise I did.

Honourable members will know that, at my own peril, I stood here and criticised decisions of my own Government whenever I considered that they were at odds with the majority thinking of the ordinary members of the Australian Labor Party, or at a least substantial part of it-be it on the issue of uranium exports, the introduction of identity cards or privatisation. As one who has spoken up when I have felt that criticism is justified, let me now pay tribute where tribute is due. I do that especially in view of the latest vogue to accuse the Hawke Labor Government of abandoning its base and not caring about the ordinary working people. Let me say at the outset that such an accusation cannot be further from the truth.

However, before I examine the substance of the allegation let us look at who is promoting it. It is taken up by journalists in the media whose editors and owners are not known for championing the welfare of ordinary working people of Australia. In every industrial dispute throughout the last three decades I have never known the same media to come down on the side of the workers. They were inevitably on the side of the bosses and on the side of the companies. Did any honourable member every read an editorial supporting the thousands of striking workers? Could it be that there has not been one just and justified strike in the past three decades since I began reading the newspapers here? Could it be that just once the workers were right and the bosses wrong? I believe it was so on many occasions. However, somehow the truth about the matter never found its way into newspaper editorials.

When we read in the papers today that the Hawke Labor Government is not looking after the working people and their families, one wonders how much credibility to give to the media scribblers, who never had the guts to stand up for the workers. So we can disregard such accusations voiced in sanctimonious articles and editorials, but of course we have the same platitudes parroted by the Opposition. Of all people the honourable member for Bennelong and Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the millionaire Elliott, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), and other millionaires suddenly became the champions of the Australian worker and with great sensitivity declared that Labor had abandoned its base.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has, and you cannot deny it.

—Let me remind those who may be so gullible that they forget that only just over five years ago, Fraser as Prime Minister, the honourable member for Bennelong as Treasurer, and John Stone as head of the Treasury, were doing their damndest to throw the workers out of their jobs and ruin the economy of this country. They had no time for people in poverty; they had no time for the Australian workers and their families. Time and again they declared that their policy was to deal with the balance of payments, to deal with the deficit and inflation first, and to fight unemployment afterwards. Their policies led to record inflation, a deficit of nearly $10 billion, and over a million unemployed Australians. Their achievement was to add another million Australian families to the scrapheap of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to understand that the monetarist policies pursued by the honourable member for Bennelong and his acolyte, John Stone, then the head of the Treasury and now the Opposition's economic expert, led to the ruin of a million workers and their families and nearly ruined the economy of the whole country. In late 1982 and early 1983 I had people coming to my office to ask me to find jobs for them. They were not only ordinary factory hands and unskilled workers; many of them were skilled metal workers, fitters, and even plumbers, who lost their jobs because of the policies of the Fraser, Howard and Peacock Government. So do not give me the bullshit that they care about the worker.

Finally, the Government of Fraser, Howard and Peacock, which came into being in 1975 by entering through a back door of the Governor-General's residence, then occupied by a sot, was thrown out unceremoniously by the Australian people in 1983. The Government of Bob Hawke, which is now being accused of not looking after the worker, inherited a collapsed economy, record inflation, a $10 billion deficit, over a million unemployed and untold misery caused to scores of ordinary Australian families by those opposite who now want to masquerade as the workers' friends.

Let me remind the members of the Labor Party, as well as the public at large, that the first thing the Hawke Labor Government undertook was to fight inflation and to fight unemployment simultaneously. The Hawke Labor Government succeeded in bringing down the inflation rate and also in reducing unemployment. We reduced inflation by half and created over a million new jobs. We have given one million Australians back their jobs, jobs that were taken away from them by the Fraser-Howard Government. To workers and their families it is of the utmost importance to have a job to go to and to receive a pay envelope, a fair pay after a fair week's work. Thanks to our Labor Government I seldom now have anyone asking me to assist him or her to find work. To me the one million jobs created by the Hawke Government are not mere statistics--

TALK.START.PARA: —One million one hundred thousand.

—As the honourable member for La Trobe says, it is now 1,100,000, to be exact. The 1,100,000 jobs created by the Hawke Government are not mere statistics, but a noticeable and actual improvement of the living standards of workers and their families in my electorate. One has only to go out into the main shopping centre in Springvale to see how busy it is. The tills and cash registers are turning over at a fast rate and one can sense that things are vastly improved since the depression created by the conservative government's mismanagement of the economy in the early 1980s. I would like the members of this House to visit the industrial areas of Moorabbin, Cheltenham, Springvale and Clayton to see the bustling industrial traffic on the roads and the vacancy signs on the factories.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite probably do not know that to those who live from honest work their weekly or fortnightly pay is extremely important, for it is from their pay envelope that the rent or payment for the house comes, as well as the children's school shoes and the family's weekly food bill. I know this only too well as being a worker all my life before I entered parliament I and my family depended on that pay envelope. So when I say that the Australian worker is vastly better off under Hawke than under Fraser, Howard and company, believe me I know what I am talking about. After all, look who is saying that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has lost touch-the Elliotts, the Julian Beales and other millionaires. All his public life, the Prime Minister, first as an industrial advocate and later as the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has done nothing but fight for the pay and better conditions for the Australian worker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this for you?

—You can have the manuscript. People opposite, like the honourable member who interjected and his Leader, are now accusing the Prime Minister, saying that he is not looking after the workers, while in the same breath they are whingeing that wages are too high and repeating the idiotic platitude that the Australian worker is pricing himself out of the job. You cannot have it both ways, even if you have the thick hide of a politician. You cannot say that the Prime Minister is not looking after the worker and then turn around and say that the worker has it too good. Whoever tries to say that will be picked up even by an eight-year-old kid.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the million jobs created that I, as a member of the Bob Hawke team, am proud of. There are a number of policies and reforms introduced by this Government that have not been attempted by any other government in our history. The tax reform introduced by this Labor Government stands by itself as a monument of fairness. For the first time in many years the distortion of our tax system is being rectified and the rich are now called on to contribute their share. Capital gains tax has been introduced, despite the opposition of those who are protecting the rich and yet claiming that Labor has abandoned its base. They accuse us of hobnobbing with millionaires, yet we made the rich pay for their dinners through introduction of the fringe benefits tax.

Because we have such policies I am proud to be a member of the Hawke Labor team. We are looking after the low income earners. We introduced the family assistance scheme whereby we supplement the income of the poor workers and their families by $66 a week tax free. But we are not looking after the workers only, whether poor or better off; we are also looking after those who are on pensions or other benefits. The real value of pensions has increased to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings since we became the Government and the value of single parent benefit and unemployment benefits have also been increased. In education, we have increased students' assistance through Austudy. We have also increased the retention of students in our schools to levels never previously expected. In health, we brought in Medicare and thus secured free medical and hospital care for all Australians.

In defence, we are the first Australian Government to take on an independent defence posture. In the past the conservative governments became aware of our defence needs only during election campaigns. Only now under the Hawke Labor Government can our people in the north feel safe and relaxed. The building of the new air base at Tindal, the F18s, the building of our new submarines, the acquisition of new Sikorsky helicopters, the development of our over-the-horizon radar system Jindalee, and other measures will ensure that we can independently take on and hit the enemy in case of a regional conflict. No longer have we to seek cover under the apron of Mother Britain or Uncle Sam. Whatever field we look at, the achievements of the Hawke Labor Government are considerable. Take, for instance, the environment. One of our first actions when elected in 1983 was to stop the ecological vandalism of the Tasmanian conservative Government. We preserved the Tasmanian wilderness for the generations of Australians to come. Kakadu, Daintree and the stopping of the logging in the Lemonthyme are only a few instances to remind us that this Government cares about the environment.

Now contrast these policies and achievements with those of the Opposition when in government and what honourable members opposite have to offer as an Opposition. As I said previously, when in government Fraser, Howard and Peacock threw one million Australians out of their jobs and left us with a record inflation rate and a $10 billion deficit. What have they to offer now in opposition? They have no policies whatsoever. As I said in the House only a few weeks ago, if the Australian people are so gullible as to trust them ever again they will be in for a rude awakening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it almost unbelievable that the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) should impress upon this House at the commencement of his diatribe his credentials as a man of conscience and independence and then turn into the most mealy-mouthed apologist imaginable for the Hawke Government. He put to shame a number of those careerist, ambitious, New South Wales Labor right wing young members who want a position on the front bench as soon as they can arrange the departure of a few of the tired, old, worn, long overstaying their welcome members. It is absolutely incredible-so much so that even the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who together with the honourable member for Hotham make up the uranium troika, rolled their eyes several times in disbelief that the supposed defender of the working class should crawl on his belly to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). His praise was unrestrained, first for the Prime Minister and secondly for his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a meaningless series of class warfare slogans, the sort of jargon that means nothing-so much so that the honourable member for Hotham, as evidence for this economic upsurge under the Hawke Government, cited the undoubted scientific, irrebuttable evidence of heavy traffic on roads around industrial areas and-wait for it, there is more!-a bustling shopping centre. What credibility does the honourable member have? It was fascinating that he recited the accusation that the Hawke Government no longer represents the working class, low income earner, and he blamed journalists and the media for perpetrating what he believes is a myth. It is not a myth. The Premier of Victoria made that comment on the weekend at the Victorian Labor Conference. And he is not the only one. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said that his Government appeared to have double standards. In Brian Howespeak, that means that the Government does have double standards. He is a member of Cabinet. He cannot put the argument any stronger. It is a devastating indictment on his own Government for a Cabinet Minister to accuse the Government of appearing to have double standards.

It is not only the senior members of the Labor Party who accuse the Hawke Government of being out of touch; it is also the electorate. Do those opposite remember the electorate, the people it is supposed to represent? The New South Wales election was a landslide rejection of the Labor machine in that State and all that it represents, as well as the way it dominates this Federal Government. New South Wales is not the only example, although it is the most dramatic. What about Port Adelaide? What about the Adelaide by-election?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Barambah?

—The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business refers to Barambah. The Labor vote in that electorate was 16 per cent. That is the Labor Party's representation in the bush. Apart from Broken Hill, the Labor Party in New South Wales does not hold one rural seat.
—And only by a handful.
—And then only just, literally by a handful of votes.
—What about the by-elections in Western Australia?

—In the by-elections in Western Australia swings of 20 per cent and 24 per cent were recorded against the Labor Party. If the honourable member for Hotham is the best advocate the Government can present, it had better go back to the drawing board. The honourable member tried to portray all this as a giant conspiracy of, to use his words, the `bosses dominated media'. For heaven's sake! And he is serious.
—Who are the bosses' mates?

—Who are the bosses' mates? They are not mates of ours. I do not mix in black tie circles where people drink from brandy balloons, as the new New South Wales Opposition Leader says, and smoke cigars. Instead, the Opposition wants to represent those below the poverty line, and they number 700,000 more since the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983. What conscience does any member of the Government have? I would far prefer a member of the Government to come in here and say, `Mistakes have been made, we have drifted from our grass roots, we are not representing the aspirations of the working man and woman', and get down to a sensible debate. Those opposite should not come in here and try to pull the wool over our eyes. They have not even pulled the wool over the eyes of the people. The naivety with which Government members think the Opposition and the electorate can be fooled is quite remarkable.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the extraordinary claims of the honourable member for Hotham was that the Hawke Government has brought in a tax system that is a model of fairness. The tax system is suddenly a model of fairness! Is that not remarkable for a government that introduced the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the assets test, and is about to introduce a superannuation tax? Members opposite should not try to deny it. Barrie Unsworth tried to get the Labor Government to rule that out, and it let him down. Mind you, that was only one of a number of contributing causes to his stunning defeat but, nonetheless, the Government is committed to a superannuation tax-there is no doubt about that. For evidence of that we only have to go to that good old reliable slammer of the Government, the betrayer of the Government, the Minister for Social Security. On 10 March this year in the Sydney Morning Herald the Minister for Social Security had this to say about major businesses not paying tax:
What strikes me about the industry-
and the Minister was referring to superannuation funds-

is that they are accepting that their appropriate status is going to have to change. What they'll be looking at is what are the elements of the total package that's being considered. . . . Of course they'll kick and scream, but I think that's reasonable.

There is no doubt at all that, although the Prime Minister prior to the 19 March New South Wales election tried to hose down the debate, initiated primarily by Barrie Unsworth himself, the Minister for Social Security stated clearly that the Government had plans for taxing superannuation funds, not just as part of a review but actually for implementation. Thus, no member of the Government should pretend that this Government has clean hands when it comes to tax. Remember that, regarding the assets test, the capital gains tax and superannuation, the burden will fall principally on the shoulders of those whom the Government tries desperately to pretend it represents-blue-collar workers who are drifting away from the Government in droves.

It should be said that Labor is losing the blue-collar worker but so is the trade union movement. In the past few years the percentage of the work force that is unionised has dropped to 46 per cent from about 56 per cent. That is a dramatic fall and it is now accepted by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that that percentage of the work force that is unionised will continue to fall. That is what Australia Reconstructed is all about. Power has fundamentally changed in the trade union movement away from the individual trade unions, no matter how large, to the ACTU-that ever-expanding bureaucracy, a home place, indeed a training ground, for a career as a politician. That will increase the sense of alienation of the average worker and make him even more removed from the decision-making process. The ACTU in all its negotiations, its rationalisation, and its move towards industry-based unions rather than craft-based unions acknowledges that unionism in this country is declining. The reason is obvious: the trade unions, with all their punitive requirements, particularly compulsory unionism, no longer represent the average working man and woman.

The honourable member for Hotham has, as have other Government members in this debate, made much of the supposed 1,100,000 jobs that have been created by the Hawke Government. Anyone can juggle figures, but there are some which stand alone and which are unambiguous and evidence in themselves. Let us consider some of the plain, straightforward figures. First, the rate of youth unemployment in this country remains at over 21 per cent. There is nothing more disheartening for any member of parliament, any parent or the young person concerned than for that young person to be unemployed, particularly for prolonged periods. That is totally unacceptable and, as long as the Government refuses to deregulate the labour market, it will be more difficult in future for young people to find jobs. The average duration of unemployment has increased from 33 weeks in 1982-83 under a coalition government to an extraordinary 47 weeks in 1986-87 under this supposedly saving Hawke Government which, allegedly, concentrates on the welfare of the unemployed. Nothing could be further from the truth. Let us talk not in the bureaucratic Public Service jargon of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who comes into this place after he is briefed every morning and mindlessly repeats the phrases and some of the figures that have been taught to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unrelated to reality.

—Yes, unrelated to reality. He repeats them parrot-like and they are indecipherable by most people and economists. However, let us get down to the plain language that members of the Government must employ if they are to have any hope-I do not believe there is any-of regaining some sort of communication with the people they are supposed to represent.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members know, the Government, because of its particularly close, cosy relationship with the ACTU-for want of a better expression-has caved in and supported wage increases without productivity offsets. Everybody knows that to do such a deal leaves everybody worse off because inflation inevitably increases. Inflation, which worries every person because it decreases purchasing power, remains more than double the rate of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) trading partners. This is proof in itself that almost no progress has been made in lowering the high cost structure.

Interest rates affect all members of the community: young people seeking to buy a house; people seeking personal loans; and those trying to get ahead who do not sit and wait for a government handout. Interest rates are fundamental to their ability to improve their lot in life. Under the Labor Government interest rates continue at historically high levels. Fortunately, there has been some decrease but it is only marginal. We in this country have been conditioned to accept as major victories slight reductions in the unemployment rate and minuscule reductions in interest rates. We cannot accept any longer the snake oil salesmanship of the Treasurer and the way that the Prime Minister manipulates and tries desperately to paper over the structural cracks in his economic policy.

I turn now to an even larger problem that is looming on the horizon because of Labor's huge budget deficits. As long as we have huge Budget deficits, coupled with a failure to lower inflation, a massive build-up in the foreign debt will result. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) does not care about the foreign debt. I have never heard him make a valid point in relation to the foreign debt, and he cannot explain his Government's policies for reducing it. There is only one way to reduce the foreign debt and it involves a long-term adjustment process. Imports must be held down and exports must be increased. This requires a sustained period of non-inflationary growth, which the honourable member for Calwell would acknowledge. In this country, we have not been successful in achieving non-inflationary growth for any extended period.

In addition, the Economic Planning Advisory Council has advised that Australia needs growth of between 2.75 and 3 per cent until the early 1990s to stabilise the foreign debt. Australia is not anywhere near that figure. It is expected that growth will flatten to about 1.5 per cent through 1988. The Government is not reining in its deficit; nor is it addressing successfully some of the fundamental planks of economic policy. As a result, the nation's foreign debt is exploding.

The result is very obvious. Early in March of this year Moody's Investor Services made an assessment of the Australian economy. The honourable member for Calwell seeks to interject, but it was the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) who said at the time that, unless Australia gets its house in order and reduces the foreign debt, the International Monetary Fund is likely to intervene. As a result, overnight Australians would have to accept a 20 per cent reduction in wages and a reduction in social services spending of about 30 per cent. The Government's senior economic Minister in the other place made the same point, and reflected the analysis of Moody's Investor Services. As honourable members are aware, in September 1986 Moody's downgraded Australia's credit rating from AAA to AA1. Since that time, the Australian economy has continued to deteriorate as the level of the overseas debt has increased.

I do not rely on one internationally known and respected assessment agency. The international credit agency Standard and Poors, which downgraded Australia's credit rating from AAA to AA-plus in December 1986, soon after Moody's downgrading, agreed with Moody's assessment of March of this year. In their decisions, both agencies mentioned the structural weaknesses in the Australian economy and the growing foreign debt. When Moody's made its assessments, it relied on a number of facts. Let any member of the Government, particularly the honourable member for Calwell who will follow me in this debate, address these points.

First, Australia's high current account deficit and foreign debt accumulation are likely to persist for several years, and I have already explained why that is so. This Government's heavy anti-business tax regime does not allow for proper growth and investment. Secondly, in the short term, comparatively-I stress that-high inflation and unemployment rates will persist. Thirdly, Australia's debt service ratio will climb to 40.9 per cent in 1988 compared with the OECD average of 17.6 per cent. Fourthly, the current account deficit, as a percentage of gross domestic product, will improve to only 3.9 per cent compared with the OECD figure of 0.4 per cent.

The Government is totally out of touch with ordinary Australians who are trying desperately to carve out a living for themselves and, through their own initiative and hard work, reap the rewards. Government members are cynical, opportunistic and only interested in holding on to the treasury bench. Hardly one of them has a social conscience. How can they apologise for a government that has increased the number living below the poverty line by 700,000 in five years? What about those people who go into their electorate offices? They certainly come into our offices. They cannot pay the mortgage, they lose their house, they lose their job or their kids lose their job. Members opposite should not pretend that they have a mortgage on compassion or an understanding of the aspirations and worries of working men and women in this country. We who represent country people and Liberal Party members who represent urban people deal with these people every day. They do not go to honourable members opposite because they do not give them any understanding, let alone any promised course of action.

A superannuation tax will be the final nail in the coffin of this Government. If it thinks that it can impose arbitrarily a tax on the profits of superannuation funds so that annuities to superannuants are correspondingly reduced, it has rocks in its head. No member of the Opposition wants to see people suffer so that we can return to the treasury bench; but that is what it will mean. If it means that people have to bleed, then we will rectify that when we return to government. People should understand that this is a high taxing government which does not seek to reward initiative or hard work and does not try to put money back into the pockets of people so that they can make decisions affecting their lifestyles-their education, health services and so on-in the way that we would want them to. We have here a major difference in the fundamental approach to rectifying the economic problems which we all acknowledge this country faces. At the next election the people will have a clear choice between conflicting and irreconcilable political philosophies. I welcome the judgment of the Australian people as to that choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard an extraordinary diatribe from the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) which was distinguished by being totally uncharitable, totally unfair and based on a total ignorance of economics. The honourable member should go and study a bit of economics. I was trying to follow his convoluted arguments. I was amazed that those in the Opposition parties who talk about the introduction of a consumption tax should be talking about the problem of inflation as well. What would happen to inflation if we introduced a consumption tax on food and basic necessities? I will tell honourable members what would happen. The cost of living for the ordinary person would skyrocket as a result of a consumption tax. Let us get past this nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gippsland was totally uncharitable because he failed to recognise that we have created more than one million jobs in five years. That is a fact. Opposition members can rave on as much as they like but it is still a fundamental fact and it contrasts with the situation when they were in government under Fraser when half a million people lost their jobs in two years. Factories were closing down around the country every day as a consequence of their kinds of policies. Have they learnt anything from that? No, as I shall illustrate, they have learnt nothing. Let us come to the point that the honourable member mentioned. Let us give him a bit of a lesson. He said that the unemployment rate had gone down by only one to 1 1/2 per cent. But let us get that situation in perspective. The fact is that the participation rate has increased dramatically since we came into government. In other words, people who had previously given up any chance of being employed are now going into the work force, not in their thousands, not in their tens of thousands but in their hundreds of thousands as a result of the increased participation rate. In addition, more than half a million people have come to Australia and added to the population-another factor that should be taken into account when looking at these figures, rather than talking gobbledegook.

Let us assume that we return to the participation rate which existed when we came into government in 1983. What would happen if one looked at those figures? What would the unemployment rate be if the participation rate was taken as the one that existed at that particular time. It would be 4.3 per cent which is historically low-an amazing level in any Western country at the moment. Honourable members opposite cannot get past that important fact. If one is going to make criticisms let them be made where they are valid and due. One should not make criticisms in areas which are invalid. Honourable members opposite cannot criticise this Government's job creation program which, by the way, they repeatedly opposed, saying that it would not work. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that half a million jobs would be created in three years, honourable members opposite laughed and said it was impossible. But we did much better than that.

We are a growing nation. We are bringing in people and we are developing this nation. I would have thought that people from the National Party of Australia, supposedly representing the country areas, would be supporting not only the immigration program and the development program that has been put down by this Government but also the employment program which is creating jobs for people coming in as well as for other Australians. That is the record and that is what stands. We should all get together and talk about how to bring Australia forward and how to develop this nation instead of engaging in this kind of uncharitable rhetoric which we have heard from the honourable member for Gippsland.

The honourable member for Gippsland seems to think that he knows everything about economics. He reckons that growth in the economy is only going to be 1 1/2 per cent. That is the prediction. But there is something that the honourable member for Gippsland has not looked at--

TALK.START.PARA: —The oracle from Gippsland!

—Yes, the oracle from Gippsland. There is something that he has not looked at. In the last three years every prediction of the level of growth has been wrong because it has been surpassed. Has the honourable member for Gippsland noticed that? Has he noticed that we have, in fact, surpassed the predicted level of growth? Has he looked at the growth created even during a time when we were squeezing the economy? Of course he has not. He does not know much about these things but he pretends to lecture us about them. He then said that we need to further rein in the deficit. How does one rein in a Budget surplus? We have already reined it in and achieved a surplus. Given this fact, what are we supposed to do after that?
—You have sold off some property. You are in deficit.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will not interject. He is also out of his seat.

—The honourable member says that we are not really in surplus-we are really in deficit. I am not surprised that he is getting excited because we are exposing him. He has specifically asked me to make some comments on his speech. All I am saying is how can one rein in the deficit when it is a surplus? But leaving that point aside, the honourable member then made some comments and quoted Senator Button. Of course, he did not say that Senator Button's comments were made about 12 to 15 months ago when we were in a very different economic situation from that which we are in now-an economic situation which we have pulled out of remarkably in terms of the current account and the collapsing Australian dollar. Of course, the honourable member for Gippsland did not mention the Australian dollar. I remind him that the Australian dollar is now valued at in excess of US74c, so we are in a very different situation from the one to which he referred. At the time Senator Button was expressing some concerns in his usual frank way but if one were to ask Senator Button today whether he thought there was any problem of that kind he would say, `Certainly not, because we have completely transformed the situation and have passed those problems'.
—What happened in New South Wales?

—Do not worry; I will come to New South Wales. Obviously, the honourable member for Gippsland wants to talk about the electoral fortunes of the National Party. I am really tempted, but I will proceed to deal with the other issue that was raised by him-the structural weaknesses in the economy. What an impertinence for the Opposition to talk about the structural weaknesses of the economy. In the period when honourable members opposite were in government they kept telling us, `Don't worry about the manufacturing sector of Australia. It doesn't matter if it is destroyed. It doesn't matter if factories are closing all over Australia. That's not a worry because we're going to be saved by the resources boom'. Do honourable members remember the fictional resources boom? According to Sir Phillip Lynch and other people, $30 billion would go into all these projects in Australia. We were told that we did not have to worry, that we would be sitting pretty because we did not need to develop our manufacturing resources or our high technology industries. All we had to do was sit tight and sell off our metals to other countries. According to Sir Phillip Lynch and other people, if we did that we would be right.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember the repeated claim that the future of Australia would lie in the resources boom. We were told that we should not look at the other situations in terms of manufacturing. What rubbish! If any government has addressed the questions of the real problems of structural change, it has been this Government. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), other senior Ministers and the Government in general have addressed the question of industry reconstruction. Honourable members opposite might think that this is an easy question, but it is a very difficult one.

The honourable member for Gippsland mentioned Australia Reconstructed. He threw this proposal out as though there was something dramatically wrong with it. The fact of the matter is that Australia Reconstructed provides a blueprint for getting around structural weakness problems, for restructuring Australian industry and for building up the manufacturing and technological resources of this country. The honourable member for Gippsland, in pretending that there is something particularly wrong with discussing the concepts and approaches of Australia Reconstructed, could not be further away from where the economic and industry debate in this country has to take place. Having said all of that, let me say some positive things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good. Can I go?

—The honourable member can go. One of the positive things that I want to talk about is the need for a comprehensive development strategy for Australia. We need to think about the fact that we are still a young nation and that we still have to develop ourselves in a number of ways. I have talked about the need for economic development. Members of the Opposition have been getting up and, in a false sort of way, trying to talk about the so-called employment problems, the so-called inflation problems and the so-called investment problems, none of which exist at the moment. What we ought to be looking at are ways and means in which we can positively increase the pace of development of Australia. There are some problems that we need to address if we are to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we are addressing the structural reconstruction issue. But some issues need to be looked at, one of which is regional development. We are a very large continent within which development is uneven. We need to think about how we can get economic development in depressed areas which have high levels of unemployment and in new areas which are undeveloped but which have potential for development and to which we can move sections of our population or encourage new immigrants to go into. We need to build factories, offices and cities in those areas. Less than 8 per cent of the population of Australia live in the top half of our country. We are underpopulated and we do not have enough economic and human resources in that area. We need to think about the development of the north of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?

—I can tell the honourable member that we are going to do a lot more than he would. At least we are talking about this matter and working out a strategy for regional development. All that members of the Opposition do is talk in negative terms. I have never heard one Opposition spokesman speak in this House about this very important issue. All we hear is the sort of nonsense that we heard from the honourable member for Gippsland in his speech. Let me say this about regional development: we need to direct resources--
—What is your plan? I am asking you. What is your plan?

—The honourable member asks what we are going to do about it. We need to discuss these issues as a parliament. We need to put down policies to encourage regional development. I am saying that to this House and to our Government. It is a very important matter.
—They aren't listening.

—The honourable member says that the Government is not listening. Unlike the Opposition, that is totally divided amongst itself and does not know whether it is Arthur or Martha, we have an excellent system under which the Caucus and members of the back bench are able to have their ideas heard in the Cabinet and are listened to. This happens to a greater extent than honourable members realise.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to think about this issue of regional development in two ways. As I said, Australia has underpopulated areas. Incentives need to be given for the development of industry in those areas. We also have to look at areas such as the steel cities, which have been dependent, perhaps excessively dependent, on a particular industry. We have to think about ways and means of encouraging new industries and taking up the populations. There are also problems in some areas of the larger cities of Melbourne and Sydney where new industries have not been replacing industries which have closed. What we have is a disjuncture between the population pattern and the industry pattern. Australia is a country of home owners. People who have bought houses in particular areas do not want to have to go to the other side of a city to get employment. They want employment close to their homes. So we need to look at regional development not only in the broad sense but even within cities. We have to zero in on that sort of problem.

In addition to an economic policy we must develop a population policy. We have heard recently criticisms about the need for and the importance of immigration irrespective of the very controversial issue of the composition of our immigration program, about which I will have a lot more to say in this House this year, the population issue has yet to be met. It is good that sections of the Opposition have recognised the importance of the population issue. Let us hope that we can get a bipartisan approach on the need for an increase in immigration that can be sustained in the nation. It is important that there be an increase that can be economically and socially sustained. That is why we have to be very careful about how we fashion our new immigration program.

Having said that, let me say something about the need for population. Our population is ageing. In the next 15 years the number of old people will double. I know that this point has been mentioned, but it is still valid. We need to ask ourselves how we are going to afford to sustain older citizens at the level of pensions and benefits that we have at the moment or even at an improved level of pensions or benefits? If we are to achieve that, it becomes important that we impact on our population by adopting an immigration program that is orientated towards young people who can come, work and make a contribution here. The last population report to the Parliament clearly indicated that the program which we have had in place for the last four or five years, and which has been orientated towards young people, has had a clear and demonstrable impact on the ageing of the population. In other words, if we had not orientated our program in the last four or five years towards younger people-and most migrants are younger-we would be in a much more serious position in relation to the population getting older.

So, if we are to have a growth and development program, we have to be concerned not only with the economic issue but also with human resources. The human resources that we need in particular must be based on the immigration to Australia of younger people who will work and contribute. This does not mean that all immigrants have to be highly skilled computer programmers or something like that. What they have to be is motivated to work and thus to contribute to the development of the nation. I think we are all agreed on that. If that is the case, we may be able to achieve an agreed position on the composition of an increased immigration program that will contribute to Australia's development. I hope that we can get some agreement across this House on the need for an overall framework of development-that is, economic, social and population development. If we agree upon such a framework of development in Australia, Australia's future will be great.
