SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to address, briefly, a couple of defence matters. Last week two submissions were put before the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is looking at wastage rates in the Australian Defence Force. The submissions are quite devastating in terms of the information they contain. They show that the Australian Defence Force is literally withering away. I take the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to task on this matter. It seems to me that, for some time now, the Minister has been posing as the man who would restructure the Australian Defence Force. What he is doing, in fact, is presiding over the dismemberment of that Force as we know it. I regret to say that in this matter the Minister is assisted largely by the Press. With some notable exceptions, the Press seems neither to know nor to care what is happening to this country's defence forces. I invite the Press to read those two submissions-one by Admiral Hudson and the other by General O'Donnell-which were submitted to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on, I think, Monday of last week.

The Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) did not put in a written submission. I am not quite sure of the reason for that. I find it difficult to understand because, of the three Services, the RAAF has probably the most pressing problem with the resignations of its pilots. I hope that it will put in a submission, perhaps by way of the general Australian Defence Force submission, so that it can place on record just where it sees the problems and outline its attempts to identify solutions to them. Many of our operational units are barely operational. In most of those units experience levels are very low. Enormous resources are being directed from operational matters to the training of recruits as members of the Defence Force vote with their feet.

I wish quickly to go through some of the main points of the Royal Australian Navy's (RAN) submission. At present, the RAN has a shortage of 500 personnel. Despite the closure of several bases and the paying off of ships, there will be a shortfall of 1,200 men and women in the RAN in the next five years. Operational capabilities are being severely reduced because of high wastage rates and low levels of experience. This year there will be a 58 per cent increase in officer wastage of the rank of commander and below. There is a 45 per cent shortfall in engineer officers of lieutenant-commander rank. This year there has been a loss of 30 ships commanders against a long term average of seven. Among those 30 were five frigate or destroyer commanding officers. There are only seven frigates and destroyers in the whole fleet and five men who were commanding those ships have left in the last year. In past years it was almost unheard of for commanding officers to resign from the service. The ambition of officers as they enter the service is to command a unit. To have five resign while in command or shortly after they have left is unheard of.

There is a 22 per cent shortfall in specialised sailor categories. There is a shortfall in experienced submarine personnel. In the last year or so, almost half the people in the submarine service have been under training. Admiral Hudson went on to identify the likelihood of increased numbers of groundings, collisions and accidents at sea, with the trend worsening. There is a low level of proficiency in ships, including declining standards in weapons practice. This trend is accelerating. There are insufficient ships in which to train officers. There is low morale due to poor pay, poor conditions of service, low job satisfaction and lack of Government interest. Those are not my words; they are the words of the Chief of the Naval Staff in a submission which is not a week old.

On the same day, the Chief of the General Staff, General O'Donnell, also put in a submission on behalf of the Army. He reinforced many of the points made by Admiral Hudson. I shall outline the main points in the Army's submission. In two years the Army has lost 10,000 soldiers and 1,200 officers from a base force of 32,000. In two years it has lost more than one-third of its total personnel. The Army's operational readiness has been reduced because of high wastage rates, inexperienced officers and soldiers, and increased administration and training costs. The core of the Army-the six infantry battalions which are the heart and guts of the Australian Army-are all under strength. Some are as low as 30 per cent under strength, including the under-strength battalions in the Operational Deployment Force, the cutting edge of the Army in Australia. Communication units are running at about 10 to 13 per cent short. Also, the Army's submission identified a shortfall of 421 officers with an increased workload being carried by fewer officers and experienced non-commissioned officers; a shortage of qualified and experienced officers and NCOs for promotion; an officer training system that has no hope of making up the shortfall because its capacity is limited; and general dissatisfaction caused by long hours, poor career management, poor pay and conditions, inadequate housing and allowances and, again, lack of interest by the Government in personnel matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your solution?

—I am glad that the honourable member asks; I will tell him in a minute. With that sort of record, the man who poses as the Minister for Defence-he might have some claim to be called the Minister for defence equipment-should hang his head in shame. To pretend that he is commanding the Australian Defence Force, is responsible for it, is a disgrace. Any man who has lost something like a third of his force in three years should resign. For example, today the Minister was talking grandly about purchasing two new submarines. He cannot even get one built. He talks about purchasing an additional two submarines with his usual obsession about equipment while the 70,000 men and women are laughing. They are saying, `Here we go again. He has big, new, grand equipment schemes, but what about us?'.

SPEECH.PARA: The question was asked: what should be done? Let me spell out what should be done in personnel matters. The Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal must be beefed up so that it can review pay and allowances regularly. It is already far behind any reasonable program and some of the allowances are taking years to put through. The Tribunal must treat the Services as a unique profession. The Government should throw out the guidelines that constrain that Tribunal. The guidelines I am referring to are those adopted by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Services are a unique profession. They have a unique task, and they must be treated as a separate entity. To force the Remuneration Tribunal to treat the Services as though they are just another bunch of public servants in uniform will never solve the problem.

An amount of $75m has been allocated by the Government over the next 10 years for housing. This is simply not going to be enough. As well as allocating more money for housing, which is one of the most contentious problems facing the Services, the Government must free up the bureaucracy which apparently is starting to stifle the operations of the Defence Force Housing Authority. I suggest that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) take a closer look at what is happening to Defence Force Housing Authority operations in his area. I understand that in the Sydney area the Authority has been given quite a lot of money. It has been told to go out and identify the houses it wants, and there the whole thing comes to a grinding halt because the bureaucracy steps in and the purchases are not allowed to proceed. It is no use setting up an authority if its operations will be blocked by unnecessary bureaucracy.

We must put realistic family allowances into place. We must upgrade the education allowance. At last count, I think 87 people in the whole of the Defence Force were getting an educational allowance for their kids. No wonder they were getting browned off. They had to leave their children to ensure that they got a decent education, but they could not get an allowance to cover it. The disturbance allowance for families is ludicrous. We should ensure that child care facilities are made available and that units contribute to the maintenance of those child care units on Defence Force property. We should set up a system-the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service could probably do the job-to help wives get jobs. Most Service wives work or want to work, but they find it very difficult as they follow their husbands around Australia. As soon as they apply for a job, for example in Townsville, they are asked where they live, what they do and where they come from. When they say they are Service wives, more often than not the prospective employer--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not as bad as it used to be.

—Well, it is not. But the prospective employer will say that he wants someone permanent. It would be a very simple matter to set up a system whereby those wives are helped to get jobs through a local organisation around the big bases.

SPEECH.PARA: We must look at remote area travel. It is no good putting people in remote places like Tindal and expecting that they will serve on happily without getting special attention in terms of returning to their families and cheap travel home. We must look at putting decent shopping facilities in some of these bases. For example, at Pearce in Western Australia there are no shopping facilities at all. It would not be a very difficult operation for the Department of Defence to go to a local private entrepreneur and offer him a concession on that base, instead of forcing people to go 40 miles down the road to shop when often they do not have a car or they are at work, or both.

In terms of removals, it is high time that we allowed proper allowances to cover the costs of removals instead of forcing people to be out of pocket for the cost of new curtains, carpets, school uniforms, registration of cars and of dogs and cats, et cetera, every time they move. We must look after our single members, not just those who happen to be living out at the time. There should be a removal allowance for all those single members. We must set up a military compensation scheme instead of forcing servicemen to go through the Commonwealth employees compensation scheme, which is not relevant to the work or the dangers faced by servicemen.

We must review the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme. We must remove the anomalies, for example, that apply to officers who are penalised if they retire prior to a nominal retiring age, as distinct from non-commissioned officers, soldiers, airmen and sailors, who have no penalty at all having done their 20 years. There are other anomalies in that scheme which also need to be reviewed. We must consider giving those people access to their lump sum superannuation before they leave the Service, instead of forcing them to leave the Service before they can get that lump sum. That is why many of them leave. They want that money to build or buy a house or to educate their children.

We must look at a system of bonuses for certain people who wish to remain in the Services. I do not say this with any pleasure because it is something that we want to avoid if we can. Of course, at the moment, that would include pilots. It does not make any sense to spend up to $6m on a pilot over a period of, say, six to eight years, only to see him leave the Service at the end of that period. Then we have to start the whole system over again. The system has just about ground to a halt. This year we will lose probably 130 to 140 pilots. The system can train only about 70. On that subject I note with some apprehension that the Government is proposing to integrate our pilot training system with New Zealand's. I believe that it would be an absolute disaster to lose control of our own system. In the first place I would have no faith in New Zealand under the Lange Government remaining a reliable ally. We have seen what it has done to ANZUS. We have seen the expense it has caused this country in looking after them in separate arrangements and exercises, and now we are proposing to hand over the initial training of our RAAF pilots to New Zealand. We will lose control of the system altogether. It is a crazy notion. I very much hope that the Government does not persevere with that proposal.

We must look at Defence Force housing and ensure that the upper limit is realistic. We must look at the working hours that our service men and women are expected to put in. We must look at the lack of job satisfaction, about which they complain so much. And so it goes on.

I wish to deal with some of the capital equipment projects which the Government has in hand. It is a valiant attempt to get some of these projects built in Australia. I fully support that, as does this side of the House. I only hope that the Government has the guts to take on the unions and, if necessary, introduce some essential service legislation to make sure that those projects, such as the submarine and frigate projects, take place here in Australia and do not have to be sent overseas to be completed. It is a fallacy and a fraud for anyone to pretend that the Australian Defence Force is in good shape. It is not. The Chief of the Naval Staff and the Chief of the General Staff indicated that last week. I very much hope that action is taken before it is too late.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I wish to cover in tonight's debate on the Appropriation Bills is the whole question of Anzac Day, which is celebrated next Monday. In my electorate of Dobell there are 9,510 repatriation beneficiaries. That is the largest number of repatriation beneficiaries in any electorate in Australia. Next Monday morning I will be honoured to participate in the dawn service at The Entrance, to be conducted by the Tuggerah Lakes Memorial Club and The Entrance-Long Jetty Returned Services League sub-branch. In addition, sub-branches at Toukley, Wyong, Wamberal and other places in the central coast will commemorate those who served their country in time of war, whether in the First World War, the Second World War, or the Korean, Malaysian or Vietnam conflicts. Next Monday, residents of the central coast, I am sure, will commemorate those who have served Australia.

In addition, Anzac Day allows us to remember those people who were injured and, in particular, those who made the ultimate sacrifice for their country. It is also important that we remember the families of Australian ex-servicemen who fought overseas and the sacrifices which the wives and children of ex-servicemen have made for Australia. As all of us in this chamber know, Anzac Day commemorates the landing at Gallipoli on 25 April 1915, a battle which proved to be unsuccessful, yet a battle which allowed Australia to forge a reputation for courage, determination and valour whenever they were fighting for their country. At Gallipoli and in other conflicts we were often involved in engagements where all the odds were greatly in favour of our opponents, particularly in Gallipoli where the Turks were defending a peninsula, which gave them the advantage, the beaches being dominated by very steep cliffs.

Australians at Gallipoli won the respect of their opponents during that battle. I am very proud of the fact that in the years since the battle at Anzac Cove in Gallipoli, Australians and Turks have grown close. In recent years, the Turkish Government has given us the great honour of renaming the cove at Gallipoli Anzac Cove, in honour of the Australians who fought and died on that peninsula. In return, Australia has renamed a bay near Albany in Western Australia from where the Australian Imperial Force convoys sailed in 1914. We have renamed that bay Ataturk Bay, after Kemal Ataturk who was the leader of the Turkish forces at Gallipoli. I have not had the privilege of visiting Anzac Cove in Gallipoli but I am told by my brother and other people who have visited Gallipoli that the impression which strikes every Australian who visits that cove is of the very young age of the Australians who died and are buried at Gallipoli, Australians with average ages of only 16 or 17.

Given that I am, I think, now the third youngest member of this chamber and the second and fourth youngest members of the chamber are sitting at the table right now, the fact that young Australians aged 16 and 17 were making the ultimate sacrifice for their country is something we need to remember on Anzac Day. I am sure that all members of this chamber will do their best to attend ceremonies next Monday. I emphasise that our repatriation system, which continues to be one of the most generous in the world, is something that we must ensure is not allowed to deteriorate as the years go by and the number of veterans in our community decreases as our elderly veterans pass away. It is important that we acknowledge that our repatriation system is compensation, not some form of welfare.

One other issue that affects not only veterans receiving service pensions but invalid and age pensioners is the pensioner rebate which the Treasury provides to those pensioners each year when they are filling out their tax returns. This year, 1987-88, the base single rate of pension, will add up to $6,093. Next year, 1988-89, given approximately a 6 per cent inflation rate, a single pensioner will receive $6,500. While the tax free threshold for ordinary taxpayers such as us is $5,100, for pensioners there is a rebate of up to $250. The problem is that at the moment any pensioner earning more than $6,142 starts to pay income tax. As I have explained, next year pensioners will probably receive about $6,500, which means they will be forced to pay about $131 in tax-which is unacceptable.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) should increase the pensioner rebate which is payable to service, age and invalid pensioners. It is simply unacceptable to expect any pensioner who has no income apart from the pension from the Departments of Social Security or Veterans' Affairs to start paying income tax. Along with such people as the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), who is at the table, I will do all in my power to make sure that the Treasurer takes action on this very important issue.

The second matter which affects pensioners in my electorate and many others is provisional tax. At the moment the provisional tax threshold is $1,000. Any person, whether a pensioner or ordinary income taxpayer, starts to pay provisional tax if the non-wage income exceeds $1,000. At the moment the provisional tax net is starting to catch ordinary pensioners who, in many cases, become confused and simply cannot understand the details involved in completing provisional tax forms. They become very worried and concerned. Pensioners with only about $6,000 in savings in a building society account can be forced to pay provisional tax. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table demonstrating the erosion by inflation of the provisional tax threshold since 1963.

SPEECH.PARA: One other item on which I want to spend some time tonight relates to violence on television news programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—There is too much of it.

—Several honourable members are interjecting to say that there is too much violence on television news programs. I agree. There was a recent program on South Africa, I think produced by a former British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) correspondent in South Africa. The program commenced at 8.30 on a Monday evening. It contained approximately 60 seconds of film of a black citizen of South Africa being stabbed with knives and hacked to death with butchers' cleavers. The BBC camera zoomed in as the blood flowed and the gentleman's eyes slowly lost focus as he died. I felt that this was something that was totally inappropriate, even though it was 8.30 at night, for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) or a commercial television station to screen at that time of night. The reporter explained that he believed the footage was censored and not shown on British television because it was too violent. Yet several weeks ago we allowed the ABC to show that footage at 8.30 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Sunday at 6 p.m., again on the ABC-I am not picking on the ABC because all of the commercial television stations are equally to blame-we were treated to the sight of a heroin addict injecting his arm, with the camera zooming in to show the syringe contents being pushed into the addict's arm. Again, I believe that that is something that is inappropriate at 6 p.m. shortly after sporting coverage, Inspector Gadget or, perhaps, The Goodies shows. I think that people who are determining television programming have to realise that many young children are watching television at that time of the evening. It is quite common these days for people to be scanning the different television stations and for children to end up watching these news services.

In addition, in recent days we have seen bodies thrown from a Kuwait Airlines jumbo jet, Israeli soldiers in occupied territories with blood flowing from shattered skulls and, of course, horrific violence in Northern Ireland. Tonight I would like to call on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) to order television stations to be more responsible and to cut back on these examples of shocking violence. I do not believe that we should prevent television stations from showing these types of news stories but I believe it is inappropriate for this sort of footage to be shown before 10 p.m. I would hope that if the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal took action against the television stations the ABC, while not being directly responsible to the ABT, would take the lead and ensure that this sort of violence was not shown on television.

My next point refers to the criticism which has been made by some honourable members opposite that this is not a true Labor Government. I must say that I felt quite ill having to sit through the contribution of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) this evening-the spoilt son of a member of the ruling class in Victoria giving the members of this Labor Government a lecture on what our social responsibilities are. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has been attempting to interject. I advise him not to say too much or we will bring up the doll's house again. That more than anything demonstrates that this is a Labor government committed to helping traditional Labor voters. That is one million Australians, most of them traditional blue collar Labor people, who now have jobs and who did not have jobs when the honourable member's Party was in government. In fact, in the last two years when the honourable member worked for Fraser Government Ministers, half a million Australians lost their jobs. That was a great record, a record of which the honourable member can be proud. It is a record of helping traditional Labor voters by tossing them out of jobs. That was the contribution of the honourable member's government to the traditional Labor voters of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not any.

—The honourable member does not believe that there are any traditional Labor voters. I can assure the honourable member that the traditional Labor voters of Port Adelaide and Adelaide might have different views. SPEECH.PARA: They know what honourable members opposite would do if ever Australia were unlucky enough to have them back on the government benches. Honourable members opposite would bring in a consumption tax, provide no compensation for the poor and prices would go through the roof. They would use a consumption tax to pay for the abolition of the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax for all their business mates. That would be the way they would help traditional Labor voters-the traditional Labor voting pensioners they want to do so much to help. They must choose whether they want a government that takes the tough decisions that are right for Australia, like floating the dollar, letting in the foreign banks to ensure we have more competition and making Australia's manufacturing industry more lean, hungry and efficient so that we have got jobs for our young people in the years to come.

The traditional Labor voters know that honourable members opposite will let pensions erode back to 22.7 per cent, just as they did in the Fraser years. Traditional Labor voters know that honourable members opposite do not represent their interests. They represent the interests of people such as Mr John Elliott who wants a consumption tax so that he can cut the amount of tax his business pays, so that he can take his assets and jobs overseas and do anything he wants so long as he can maximise his own personal profits. I know that the traditional Labor voters of Australia at the next chance they get will reject the Opposition, regardless of who happens to lead it at that time, because they know who really represents their interests. SPEECH.PARA: That is the precise point. The Adelaide electorate-a traditional safe Labor seat and not a seat where we have spent a great deal of money in the past in election campaigns-is a seat where the traditional Labor base just evaporated. When one looks at the hardest, strongest Labor booth in the electorate of Adelaide, one sees in that booth that there was a swing of 22 per cent to the Liberal Party. That says something about my contention that there are no traditional Labor voters left anywhere, including South Australia.

I do not want to enter into these sorts of party political tirades tonight. I want to spend a little time talking about an issue that I think is more important than going around pretending that traditional Labor voters are happy with the Labor Government, or some such thing. I want to talk about the issue of Commonwealth-State financial relations, which I think is a very important aspect of economic discussion in this country, though it is not debated much in this Parliament. One of the reasons why it is not discussed much in this Parliament is that I suspect people think it is politically-whatever that may mean-too difficult to put forward any constructive alternative to the way that relationship currently works.

We have a unique Australian fiscal federalism which in reality is lacking any underlying rationale or philosophy. It is something that has simply evolved to meet external problems and a series of crises. For example, massive Commonwealth borrowings during World War I, which were obviously made necessary because of the war, led to the Australian Loan Council being established in 1923 to co-ordinate those borrowings. The Great Depression led to the Grants Commission being established. During World War II, because of the exigencies of the time, there was a transfer of income tax powers from the States to the Commonwealth. The result, of course, is that we have in Australia a financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the States which is simply an ad hoc response to the problems resulting from a whole lot of external factors. Consequently we have a structure that suffers from a poor division of powers and responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States.

Let me just give the House some examples. Accountability for the expenditure of moneys and the borrowing of moneys is simply obscured because of the nature of the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States. Secondly, the States are encouraged to seek help from others for their financial problems, not to go out and fix those problems themselves. Thirdly, I think as most members of this House know, there is a duplication of functions between the Commonwealth and the States and that leads to obvious inefficiencies and administrative burdens in both those levels of government, which in many cases are simply trying to do the same thing. We have two departments in many areas of activity which are simply set up to do something that is very similar, if not identical, at both Commonwealth and State levels.

Furthermore, the Commonwealth does not have effective control over the State sector's net borrowing requirement, in spite of the occasional protestations from the present Treasurer (Mr Keating). Probably some of his predecessors have tried to argue that they do have that control, but the reality is that that control, or perhaps one should say coordination, does not exist sufficiently effectively. Under the current Loan Council arrangements there are global limits set for each State's borrowings. Theoretically this system should work, but in practice these limits can be evaded. I have with me a very interesting letter that the South Australian Government Financing Authority's chief executive sent to the South Australian Government's State Government Insurance Commission in which the Chief Executive of SAFA, as it is often referred to, said:
. . . off-shore borrowings by the central borrowing authorities of a State . . . do not count against the limit-
that is, the Loan Council limit-
if the borrowings are undertaken on behalf of one of the State's financial institutions:
The letter went on:
The Treasurer-
that is referring to the Treasurer of South Australia, who is the President of the Labor Party, Mr Bannon-
has asked us to develop an arrangement between SAFA and the SGIC-
the State Government Insurance Commission-
which would enable maximum advantage to be taken of this advantage to the financial benefit of both organisations.

It is perfectly clear from that letter that the Government of South Australia was trying at that time-November 1986-to use an artificial means of circumventing the Loan Council guidelines. I know very well, for I once asked the Treasurer a question about this letter and he undertook to investigate this particular scheme. So far, not surprisingly for the present Treasurer, I have not heard the results of those investigations, which seems to suggest that the Treasurer was dissatisfied with the scheme but decided not to tell the House, because South Australia has a Labor government. If the Commonwealth took the view that it should hold firm and make its Loan Council limits stick, I think the reality is from the Commonwealth's point of view that they would end up with an all-out brawl between the Commonwealth and the States in an obviously political arena where the Commonwealth could come out suffering a very high political cost. Bearing that in mind, it is debatable that the Commonwealth would hold firm. This particular exercise relating to SAFA in South Australia I think is a clear example of politics overwhelming sound economic management.

A further aspect of our Federal-State financial arrangements is that the States' revenue base for tax raising is, as I think honourable members would realise, very narrow and consequently there are some aspects of the economies of States that are taxed very severely and in many respects I think very irrationally. The taxes that are forced effectively on the States are taxes such as stamp duties, excises and perhaps one of the most pernicious of all taxes in Australia, the payroll tax, which is really a quite irrational tax in a country that has nearly 8 per cent unemployment-a tax on employment. It is quite an extraordinary thing really for a government to do.

When one looks at the structure of the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States from that point of view, one can see that there is a whole series of anomalies. What makes the need for reform of the Commonwealth-States financial relationships so pressing is the fact that the present system has operated in such a fashion that the level and the efficiency of overall public sector outlays in Australia has been adversely affected. We are spending more in our public sector and we are getting less value from it than we could if we sensibly considered, not in a party political way but as a community and as a parliament, the financial relationships and arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States.

If we are really serious about the issue of reducing the size of government in Australia-and I suppose on the other side of the House they are not, but on this side of the House we are-then we have to look at some options for reform in this area. I am not pretending for a minute that those options for reform will ever be easy-I think they will be difficult, particularly for political reasons-but I do think we need to look very carefully at a series of different things that we can do. There needs to be a rational re-allocation of expenditure responsibilities to start with between the States and the Commonwealth. We have to try to find ways of eliminating a lot of the duplication that exists on the spending side between the Commonwealth and the States. Perhaps the Liberal-National Party government that will be formed after the next election could undertake a voluntary cutback in the powers of the Commonwealth on that front in order to try to cease the sort of duplication that we have at the moment. A whole range of other issues need to be considered, but at this time of the night I shall defer consideration of them until tomorrow.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advertising: Selling-Australian Taxation Office-Australian Craftsmen-Floricultural Industry-Consumption Tax-Bass Strait Oilfields

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the attention of this House to a business malpractice whereby false and misleading information is given to people in small business in the hope that they will pay out hard-earned money for advertising which may well prove to be of no value. This is the telephone scam. Last week a member of my staff was contacted by a Mr Peter Hallinan, who runs a panel-beating business not far from my office. Mr Hallinan said he had just received a phone call from a man who gave him the very clear impression that he represented the New South Wales Government. He had said that the new Government in New South Wales was seeking to boost employment in areas outside metropolitan Sydney by offering government business to local firms, and that Mr Hallinan's panel-beating business was one of four chosen for all government work in the Illawarra area from Helensburgh to Nowra. Mr Hallinan was told that he would be contacted by a representative of the Government Printing Office who would make arrangements for him to advertise in a government publication. This would cost approximately $350.

SPEECH.PARA: The following day Mr Hallinan received a phone call from a second person, a woman, who said his advertisement would be placed in a publication called `The New South Wales Country Government Directory'. Mr Hallinan asked her whether he could return her call and was given a Sydney phone number. On checking with the New South Wales Government Printing Office, I was informed that it had no knowledge of any publication called `The New South Wales Country Government Directory' and that it most certainly was not a government publication. I then contacted the woman who had phoned Mr Hallinan and gathered that she was expecting phone calls from a number of Wollongong businesses. Rather than answer my questions, she referred me to a person on another phone number. This person proved to be the manager of a printing company in Sydney. He gave me a very different story. He said the publication was, in fact, called `The Local Government Supplies and Services Purchasing Directory, New South Wales Country' and that it most certainly was not a government publication but was run by private enterprise. It is a directory which is produced annually and which lists private businesses and services and is circulated to some New South Wales Government departments but especially to local governments.

The same firm publishes similar directories for metropolitan Sydney and for metropolitan and country areas of other States. I have no reason to believe that this firm is anything but a well-established and reputable firm of many years standing. The problem would seem to be that firms such as this rely on sales contractors, who work on a commission basis, for the advertising they carry in their publications. In this case it would seem that the sales contractor is not as reputable as the printing firm.

The manager was most concerned by the information I gave him and assured me that he would follow it up. It is, of course, in his own best interests to do so and I am sure he will. He made the point that his industry is relying increasingly on sales contractors who sell advertising space over the phone. This practice is, of course, very much open to abuse. He also told me that it is becoming a common practice for bogus contractors to claim to be selling advertising for a particular publication without the knowledge of the publisher. They work the scam in such a way that they pocket the money but the advertisement never appears.

I might add that a senior representative of a local municipal council told me that, since the recent New South Wales election, his council had received a number of glossy brochures advertising various publications and playing on the fact that, with the new Government in New South Wales, theirs is a publication the council cannot afford to be without. In most cases, he said, these publications are of little value. I should add that the publication in question does not fall into this category and is, in fact, used by a number of councils. I was also told that, in the case of panel-beating, it would be pointless for a local firm to advertise through a directory because his council had well-established methods for handling its motor vehicle repairs, mainly through its own works depot.

I would therefore strongly caution people in small business to be wary of telephone advertising and to check the facts very carefully. Most importantly, they should contact the printing firm and establish that it is a reputable firm and that they know exactly what they are paying for, otherwise they may be wasting their money. May I conclude by commending Mr Peter Hallinan for his initiative, his sense of justice and his concern for the common good in approaching my office in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a mixture of anger and disappointment that tonight I have to bring to the attention of the House an unfortunate incident involving the Australian Taxation Office, an incident that has harmed Australia's reputation as a fair minded and compassionate nation. I am sure that fairness and compassion are virtues we would all like to see in ourselves and our country. But it seems they do not exist in our taxation system. The actions of the Taxation Office severely damaged our reputation last October when it sent a tax bill to the parents of a young British woman brutally stabbed to death while on a working holiday in Australia. As if it were not enough that 23-year-old Susan Frost should die so violently so far from home, just six months after the murder her parents received a tax bill for $339, assessed on income Susan earned doing casual work while in Australia. The bill was sent even after the Taxation Office had been advised in writing of the tragic circumstances of her death at the time a family friend in Perth lodged her return.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members would appreciate the enormous distress that this caused Susan's parents. And the callous attitude of the Taxation Office has angered the people of Albany, the town in Western Australia where Susan Frost was killed, not to mention what it has done to our reputation overseas as a fair minded and reasonable nation. After the murder, the people of Albany responded by contributing thousands of dollars to a special fund to send Susan's body back to Britain for burial. The Albany community did much to ease the pain for Susan Frost's parents. Now they justifiably feel that the Taxation Office has let the side down. I am advised that the Taxation Office last week reacted to the widespread condemnation of its action with a decision to refund the money to Mr and Mrs Frost. But I believe the matter should be taken further. I urge the Government to send an apology to the family, appropriately worded with the compassion that has so far been lacking in this case. Some days ago, I requested the Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself to instigate a review of the Taxation Office procedures which enabled this situation to arise. I sincerely hope that this action is taken and that an incident such as this is never repeated.

The matter is compounded by the fact that the murderer was on parole from another State on a charge of attempted murder and assault. This matter has been spread all over Britain by television and the newspapers, and it has severely damaged Australia's reputation. It has damaged the perception of British people that Australia is a fair minded and safe place. I hope that the Treasurer will at least write to Miss Susan Frost's parents to point out to them that this is not the norm in Australia, that the Australian Taxation Office normally does not seek to recover $339 from the families of people who have died in this country under such tragic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably on no other issue is the coalition more divided than on the issue of a consumption tax. His argument was that his mates would pay a greater amount of tax if a consumption tax was imposed. SPEECH.PARA: But I mean in terms of running the country to me it is one of those essential things.

This Government has brought in very many measures of tax reform which make the imposition of a consumption tax irrelevant. We have brought in a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. Business entertainment has its rightful value now that it is no longer a tax dodge. Because of that, those who were evading their tax by constructing their affairs so as to claim for quasi or semi-business matters are now required to pay their full tax.

It is true that at the National Taxation Summit in 1985 this Government put up option C, a component of which was a consumption tax. However, we got clear messages from the electorate that this was not what it wanted on the grounds of inequity and hardship for pensioners, low income earners and poor families. That message got through to the Government and option C was rejected. We believe that the introduction of capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tougher substantiation rules for employment expenses and the denial of taxation deductions for business entertainment, as well as improved tax operations, have filled the gap and will raise between $2.5 billion and $2.75 billion in 1987-88. That is about twice as much as would be raised by a consumption tax, which the Treasury has estimated would raise about $1.5 billion. One wonders whether Mr Elliott and his mates would pay the right amount of tax if we relied on a consumption tax. Of course they want to trade off the consumption tax for this range of other tax nets that we have imposed and which have caught them undone.

If we were to introduce a consumption tax we would suffer, perhaps, a one-off and probably extended jump in the inflation rate. The lowest level I have heard is 6.5 per cent, but I think it would more likely be 8 or 9 per cent. When one does the sums of the Liberal Party of Australia in raising money through the consumption tax and offsetting the losses in revenue through getting rid of the taxes that we have brought in and them wishing somehow to lower company tax and personal income tax, one finds a shortfall of almost $2 billion. When one adds that to the size of the consumption tax that must be raised, one can predict that the inflation rate due to, say, a 20 per cent rate of consumption tax, would be of the order of 15 or 16 per cent. One can imagine the impact that would have, quite rightly, on the trade union movement which would want somehow to recoup its loss of standards and purchasing power by going to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and asking for a rise in wages. One could not blame it for that.

So when we go into this argument of whether we should have a consumption tax let us remember that it is inequitable; that it hits the low income earners and the poor people most; that it would bring about industrial disputation and a clamour for increased wages; and ultimately it would bring about an inflation rate that would probably cripple this country in its fight to have economic competitiveness on an international scale.

But there is one issue which this House has not considered and which I think it ought to. I think we need to be discussing it now because by the year 2000 the problems will be a reality and the community will have to determine which legislation will be passed, particularly in this place, to make sure that those oil rigs are removed in some way. So far as I can find out, there appear to be four options. The first is to decommission the rigs and to maintain them with warning lights and markers. The second is to topple them over in what has been called the rig-to-reef principle. The third is partially to remove them to give reasonable clearance below the waterline for navigation purposes. The fourth is complete removal. In today's values, this would cost in the vicinity of $70m, so by the year 2000 the figure would be much larger. Of course, the community would have to pay for complete removal because the cost would be passed on in one form or another. There is plenty of time to be thinking about this but I think we should start to consider it now rather than later. Tony Hyden, an engineer with the technical division of Esso, said:

The most costly and least desirable option is complete removal. The platforms would be taken to shallow waters, cut up--

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the (a) Australian Income Tax Assessment Act contains 1,197 sections and approximately one million words and (b) Hong Kong Internal Revenue Ordinance contains only 172 sections and approximately 60,000 words.
(2) Why does the regulation of income tax law in Australia require nearly 7 times more statutory provisions and about 15 times more words than such regulation in Hong Kong.

(3) Is he able to say whether the (a) Co-operative Companies Code as applied in the Australian books contains 698 sections and about 375,000 words, (b) consolidated Companies Act 1985 in the UK contains only about 220,000 words, (c) Canadian Business Corporation Act, including regulations, contains only 269 sections and about 110,000 words and (d) Swedish Companies Act contains only 220 sections and about 40,000 words.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to any other analogous statutes regulating income taxation or company law in any Western country that are more voluminous than either of the Australian Income Tax Assessment Act and Companies Code.

(5) Has his attention been drawn to the recent Discussion Paper on Plain English, dated August 1986, prepared by the Law Reform Commission of Victoria; if so, will he take urgent steps to overhaul the complex and wordy drafting of our business law statutes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The volume and complexity of the Australian Income Tax Assessment Act has often been criticised. However, it is necessary to have regard to the social and economic functions which the Act performs, and the history of judicial interpretation to which the Act has been subject.

The volume of the Act results partly from the fact that it is not merely a revenue raising device. Many provisions grant special tax treatment to certain groups and thereby act to redistribute wealth within our society.

The major difficulty has been the tendency, particularly in the past, for Australian courts to interpret the Act narrowly by taking a `black letter' approach to the statute. In an attempt to overcome this approach the practice developed of drafting amendments to the Act with great particularity so as to state, as precisely as possible, the intention of the Parliament.

In particular, the approach of the courts to a generally expressed anti-avoidance provision is well known. The result has been the inclusion in the Act of complex and lengthy anti-avoidance provisions so as to prevent or limit the opportunity for tax avoiders to exploit tax relief conferred by other provisions.

The Hong Kong Inland Revenue Ordinance is a relatively simple taxing measure. It does not purport to perform the same functions or cover the same subject matter as the Australian Income Tax Assessment Act and so cannot fairly be compared with it. However, I would draw the attention of the honourable member to an article by Andrew Halkyard in the September 1986 edition of the Australian Taxation Review which discusses recent anti-avoidance amendments to the Inland Revenue Ordinance. The author makes the observation, with respect to one particular amendment, that ``. . . . the problem in enacting simple legislation is that there is often the risk that it does not cover that with which it is intended to deal''.

(3) (a) and (b) and (4) The Australian Companies Act 1981 contains 634 sections. By contrast, the United Kingdom Companies Act 1985 contains 747 sections. However, it would not be appropriate to compare these statutes simply by reference to the number of sections or words each contains.

The matters dealt with by both Acts are not identical. For example, there are a number of substantial matters dealt with by the Australian companies legislation but not by the United Kingdom companies legislation. These include:
(i) the regime concerning the suspension and cancellation of the registration of auditors and liquidators;
(iv) no liability companies and investment companies.

In addition, the Australian Companies Act 1981 forms a part of a framework of Commonwealth, State and the Northern Territory law. This has required the inclusion of a large number of machinery provisions dealing with the recognition of incorporation and the registration of certain documents in other jurisdictions, the reservation and registration of company names in those jurisdictions, and the transfer of incorporation from one jurisdiction to another.

(3) (c) and (4) The Canada Business Corporations Act has 266 sections. However, the federal legislation in Canada governing companies is not confined to the Business Corporations Act. Other relevant federal Acts include:
(iii) Corporations and Labour Unions Returns Act;

A similar position exists in the Canadian provinces each of which have separate systems of company law. In Ontario, for example, legislation governing companies includes the Business Corporations Act, the Corporations Information Act, the Corporation Securities Registration Act and the Extra-Provincial Corporations Act. The Ontario Securities Act also contains provisions which are dealt with in Australia by the Companies Act 1981 (for example, the distribution of prospectuses and the reporting of material changes in the affairs of a company).

(3) (d) and (4) The Swedish laws and legal system are conceptually different to those of Australia. Sweden is a civil law country. Australia is a common law country. In Sweden, as in most European civil law countries, there is a tendency to formulate principles and broad rules of law rather than to legislate in terms of particular cases. The Swedish courts have a much greater scope for interpreting the law compared with the approach traditionally adopted in the Australian courts entrenched in an Anglo-Saxon legal tradition which is based on detailed specification in legislation and certainty of interpretation.

Apart from cultural and legal differences, the company law structure in Sweden is simpler than in Australia as the Swedish legislation deals with only one type of company and only one jurisdiction. Australian law deals with different classes of companies to which different requirements apply. Furthermore, Sweden regulates companies through multiple Acts rather than one consolidated piece of uniform legislation as in Australia. Apart from the Swedish Companies Act these other Acts include:
(iv) Act on Public Board Representation in Companies;
(vi) Act on Foreigners and Foreign Companies' Rights to carry on Business in Sweden.

(5) I am aware of the Discussion Paper and also of the final report of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria entitled ``Plain English and the Law'' released in June 1987. Both have received close attention within my Department and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. In 1986 the Office of Parliamentary Council recognised that there was room for improvement in its drafting style, as practices adopted by the Commonwealth in the past had resulted in unduly complex language. In December 1986 it began a series of measures to develop a more simple and functional drafting style. This will be a continuing process.

New Commonwealth legislation is being drafted to replace the current co-operative companies legislation. I am confident that the new legislation will reflect as far as possible the current more simplified style of Commonwealth drafters. If the deregulatory initiatives, presently being considered by the Companies and Securities Consultative Group I have established to assist in the development of the new arrangements, are implemented, there will be further scope for simplifying both the policy and drafting of the legislation. However, the extent to which the language of the existing laws may be fully redrafted will depend on time and resources available.
I am also advised that the Australian Taxation Office is currently examining the Income Tax Assessment Act to remove outdated and redundant provisions and thus reduce the length of the Act.

The Government recognises the desirability of business law and other legislation being drafted in a clearer and simpler way. It may reduce the cost to both business and the community of administering those laws. However, plainer drafting cannot bring this about by itself. Practising lawyers and the courts have a crucial part to play in accepting the new disciplines of simpler drafting and developing a new approach to statutory interpretation to focus on the policy intent of the legislation rather than any narrow literal meaning which might be extracted. The enactment of sections 15aa and 15ab of the Commonwealth Acts Interpretation Act (and their counterparts in the cooperative scheme Interpretation Code) directing courts to have regard to the object or purpose of legislation represents a significant step in laying the foundation for a more general drafting approach.

With the greater priority being given to the value of simpler drafting, I am hopeful that future legislation will be increasingly tested in the light of this approach, not only by drafters and policy advisers but also more importantly in the public domain. The objective is to achieve effective legislation that is also comprehensible and readable.
